A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 2: High Activity Staking Rewards - Payout From High Activity Staking Rewards Buffer Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 2: High Activity Staking Rewards - Payout From High Activity Staking Rewards Buffer Core The High Activity Staking Rewards distribution occurs linearly over the course of each month. The total amount distributed equals the lesser of 1) 5% of Step 2 Capital, or 2) 15% of the current High Activity Staking Rewards Buffer, with a minimum floor of 5% of HASRB.
In periods of high profitability, funds build up in the High Activity Staking Rewards Buffer. Then in periods of low profitability these funds are paid out from the High Activity Staking Rewards Buffer, ensuring that there is a continued incentive for active involvement in governance even in periods of low profitability to maintain security.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 2: High Activity Staking Rewards - High Activity Staker Qualification Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 2: High Activity Staking Rewards - High Activity Staker Qualification Core To qualify as High Activity Stakers, SKY stakers must satisfy two criteria as specified in the documents herein.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 2: High Activity Staking Rewards - High Activity Staker Qualification - High Activity Stakers Must Stake Through Compliant Governance Accessibility Frontend Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 2: High Activity Staking Rewards - High Activity Staker Qualification - High Activity Stakers Must Stake Through Compliant Governance Accessibility Frontend Core High Activity Stakers must stake through Governance Accessibility frontends that comply with security and information standards specified in the Atlas.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 2: High Activity Staking Rewards - High Activity Staker Qualification - High Activity Stakers Must Continuously Provide Input On Executor Agents Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 2: High Activity Staking Rewards - High Activity Staker Qualification - High Activity Stakers Must Continuously Provide Input On Executor Agents Core High Activity Stakers must continuously provide input on the work of Executor Agents. In this way High Activity Stakers monitor the performance of Executor Agents just as Executor Agents monitor the performance of Star Agents.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 2: High Activity Staking Rewards - High Activity Staker Qualification - High Activity Stakers Must Continuously Provide Input On Executor Agents - Input Methods Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 2: High Activity Staking Rewards - High Activity Staker Qualification - High Activity Stakers Must Continuously Provide Input On Executor Agents - Input Methods Core The methods for High Activity Stakers to provide their input will be specified in a future iteration of the Atlas, but may for instance include filling out AI generated questionnaires or other easily measurable and easy to complete tasks. The Core Executor Agents must continuously improve these input methods.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 3: Stability Capital Retention Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 3: Stability Capital Retention Core A percentage of the Step 3 Capital equal to the Stability Capital Retention (”SCR”) is allocated to funding the Stability Capital Buffer. The remaining percentage becomes Step 4 Capital.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 3: Stability Capital Retention - Stability Capital Buffer Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 3: Stability Capital Retention - Stability Capital Buffer Core The Stability Capital Buffer is the surplus of the Sky Protocol that is able to be the final absorber of losses in the case of unsuccessful liquidation of failed Star Agents. See A.3.6 - A1 - Surplus Buffer And Smart Burn Engine - Surplus Buffer.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 3: Stability Capital Retention - Stability Capital Retention Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 3: Stability Capital Retention - Stability Capital Retention Core The Stability Capital Retention (SCR) is calculated according to the following formula: SCR = (1 - ((SCB / TS) / TSCB)) * RF. Where: SCB = Current Stability Capital Buffer, TS = Total USDS supply, TSCB = Target Stability Capital Buffer, RF = Retention Factor.
This formula dynamically adjusts capital retention based on the current buffer status: When SCB/TS equals TSCB (buffer at target), SCR equals zero. When SCB/TS is below TSCB, SCR increases proportionally to the shortfall. The maximum possible retention is capped by the Retention Factor (RF).
This ensures that capital retention automatically scales with urgency - the further the Stability Capital Buffer falls below its target percentage of total supply, the greater the portion of capital retained.
The parameters for calculating the SCR are further defined in the documents herein.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 3: Stability Capital Retention - Stability Capital Retention - Current Stability Capital Buffer Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 3: Stability Capital Retention - Stability Capital Retention - Current Stability Capital Buffer Core The Current Stability Capital Buffer (SCB) is the current level of the Stability Capital Buffer.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 3: Stability Capital Retention - Stability Capital Retention - Total USDS Supply Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 3: Stability Capital Retention - Stability Capital Retention - Total USDS Supply Core The total USDS Supply (TS) is the total supply of USDS.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 3: Stability Capital Retention - Stability Capital Retention - Target Stability Capital Buffer Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 3: Stability Capital Retention - Stability Capital Retention - Target Stability Capital Buffer Core The Target Stability Capital Buffer (TSCB) is the Target level of the Stability Capital Buffer, expressed as a percentage of the total supply of USDS. It is calculated according to the following formula: TCSB = 0.75% + (TS * 1.4e-14). The TSCB cannot exceed 5%.
This formula begins with a Target Stability Capital Buffer of 0.75% and gradually increases this as the Total USDS Supply increases, reflecting the fact that a greater capital buffer is required as USDS becomes more systemically important.
For example, with USDS Supply of 8 billion, the Target Stability Capital Buffer would be approximately 0.76%.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 3: Stability Capital Retention - Stability Capital Retention - Retention Factor Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 3: Stability Capital Retention - Stability Capital Retention - Retention Factor Core The Retention Factor is a factor representing how aggressively capital should be retained to fund the Stability Capital Buffer. It is calculated according to the following formula: RF = 25% + (TS * 1.6e-13). The RF cannot exceed 75%.
The Retention Factor starts at 25% and scales upward with Total USDS Supply, recognizing that capital accumulation becomes more critical as USDS gains in systemic importance.
For example, with USDS Supply of 8 billion, the Retention Factor would be approximately 26%.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards Core Any remaining funds in Step 4 Capital are allocated as specified in the documents herein.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Smart Burn Buffer Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Smart Burn Buffer Core 80% of Step 4 Capital is allocated to the Smart Burn Buffer, as specified in the documents herein.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Smart Burn Buffer - Purpose Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Smart Burn Buffer - Purpose Core The Smart Burn Engine uses the Smart Burn Buffer to buy and burn SKY using an intelligent algorithm, buying more when the price is low and retaining capital when the price is high to buy later at favorable prices.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Smart Burn Buffer - Usage Of Smart Burn Buffer Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Smart Burn Buffer - Usage Of Smart Burn Buffer Core The Smart Burn Engine only buys and burns SKY when the Market Capitalization (MC) is below the Target Market Capitalization (TMC). The percentage of the Smart Burn Buffer (Burn Rate) that is used to buy and burn SKY each Monthly Settlement Cycle is calculated according to the following formula: Burn Rate = (1 - MC / TMC) * 50%. The parameters for calculating the Burn Rate are defined in the documents herein.
Conceptually, this formula buys more SKY the further the Market Capitalization is below the Target Market Capitalization.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Smart Burn Buffer - Usage Of Smart Burn Buffer - Target Market Capitalization Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Smart Burn Buffer - Usage Of Smart Burn Buffer - Target Market Capitalization Core The Target Market Capitalization (TMC) is calculated according to the following formula: TMC = 8.5 + (200 * growth_rate) * annual_profits. The growth_rate is the three (3) year moving average historical growth rate of Net Revenue, and annual_profits is the one (1) year moving average of Net Revenue.
Conceptually, this formula calculates a target price based on the current earnings of the Sky Protocol and a price to earnings ratio, where the price to earnings ratio is a function of how quickly the Sky Protocol is growing.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Smart Burn Buffer - Usage Of Smart Burn Buffer - Target Market Capitalization - Continuous Improvement Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Smart Burn Buffer - Usage Of Smart Burn Buffer - Target Market Capitalization - Continuous Improvement Core The Core Executor Agents must continuously improve the Target Market Capitalization formula so that the Smart Burn Engine becomes more efficient over time.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Smart Burn Buffer - Usage Of Smart Burn Buffer - Market Capitalization Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Smart Burn Buffer - Usage Of Smart Burn Buffer - Market Capitalization Core The Market Capitalization is the current market capitalization of Sky. It is calculated by multiplying the price of SKY by the total supply of SKY, treating each MKR on an as-converted basis based on the conversion ratio of 24,000 SKY to 1 MKR.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Standard Activity Staking Rewards Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Standard Activity Staking Rewards Core 20% of Step 4 Capital is allocated to the Standard Activity Staking Rewards Buffer, as specified in the documents herein.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Purpose Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Purpose Core Standard Activity Staking Rewards (SASR) provide rewards to users who contribute to security by staking and delegating their SKY votes at least once.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Payout From Standard Activity Staking Rewards Buffer Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Payout From Standard Activity Staking Rewards Buffer Core The Standard Activity Staking Reward Distribution occurs linearly over the course of each month. The monthly payout from the Standard Activity Staking Rewards Buffer (SASRB) is equal to the lesser of (1) 20% of Step 4 Capital, or (2) 15% of the SASRB, with a minimum floor of 5% of the SASRB.
In periods of high profitability, funds build up in the Standard Activity Staking Rewards Buffer. Then in periods of low profitability these funds are paid out from the Standard Activity Staking Rewards Buffer, ensuring that there is a continued incentive for involvement in governance even in periods of low profitability to maintain security.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Standard Activity Staker Qualification Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Standard Activity Staker Qualification Core SKY that is both staked and delegated to an Aligned Delegate will qualify for Standard Activity Staking Rewards.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Sourcing Of Internal Senior Risk Capital From Surplus Buffers Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Sourcing Of Internal Senior Risk Capital From Surplus Buffers Core Internal Senior Risk Capital (ISRC) consists of a portion of the excess capital of the Sky Protocol that is reinvested in providing Senior Risk Capital to Star Agents. ISRC is sourced from the various Buffers defined in A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps, according to the specifications of the subdocuments below.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Sourcing Of Internal Senior Risk Capital From Surplus Buffers - USDS In High Activity Staking Rewards Buffer Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Sourcing Of Internal Senior Risk Capital From Surplus Buffers - USDS In High Activity Staking Rewards Buffer Core All USDS in the High Activity Staking Rewards Buffer is used for Internal Senior Risk Capital.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Sourcing Of Internal Senior Risk Capital From Surplus Buffers - USDS In Standard Activity Staking Rewards Buffer Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Sourcing Of Internal Senior Risk Capital From Surplus Buffers - USDS In Standard Activity Staking Rewards Buffer Core All USDS in the Standard Activity Staking Rewards Buffer is used for Internal Senior Risk Capital.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Sourcing Of Internal Senior Risk Capital From Surplus Buffers - USDS In Smart Burn Buffer Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Sourcing Of Internal Senior Risk Capital From Surplus Buffers - USDS In Smart Burn Buffer Core All USDS in the Smart Burn Buffer is used for Internal Senior Risk Capital.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Sourcing Of Internal Senior Risk Capital From Surplus Buffers - USDS In Stability Capital Buffer Above Target Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Sourcing Of Internal Senior Risk Capital From Surplus Buffers - USDS In Stability Capital Buffer Above Target Core All USDS in the Stability Capital Buffer above the Stability Capital Buffer Target is used for Internal Senior Risk Capital. Since this capital is already above the optimal target to absorb risk it can be redirected to a more efficient use.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Sourcing Of Internal Senior Risk Capital From Surplus Buffers - USDS In Stability Capital Buffer Below Target Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Sourcing Of Internal Senior Risk Capital From Surplus Buffers - USDS In Stability Capital Buffer Below Target Core One third of the USDS in the Stability Capital Buffer below the Stability Capital Buffer Target is also used for Internal Senior Risk Capital. This ensures that there is always some Internal Senior Risk Capital to drive the growth of the ecosystem.
A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Short Term Transitionary Measures Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Short Term Transitionary Measures Core As a short-term transitionary measure, the net revenue of the Sky Protocol is currently allocated manually through Executive Votes rather than through the allocation steps defined above. This manual process will be removed in a future iteration of the Atlas.
A.2.6 - A1 - Sky Core Monthly Settlement Cycle - Monthly Settlement Cycle Overview Sky Core Monthly Settlement Cycle - Monthly Settlement Cycle Overview Section The documents herein define the Monthly Settlement Cycle (MSC), a standardized, system-wide process executed at the end of each calendar month.
A.2.6 - Sky Core Monthly Settlement Cycle - Monthly Settlement Cycle Overview - Operational Processes Sky Core Monthly Settlement Cycle - Monthly Settlement Cycle Overview - Operational Processes Core The Monthly Settlement Cycle (MSC) synchronizes several key operational processes across the ecosystem, including: (1) Sky Protocol’s net revenue from the previous month is calculated and allocated through the steps of the Treasury Management Function. See A.2.5. (2) The monthly Senior Risk Capital (SRC) origination process is settled: the clearing price is established, costs are deducted from winning Star Agents’ accounts, and their accounts are credited with Originated SRC (OSRC) for the upcoming month. See 3.3 - Settlement Of Origination. (3) Queued conversions between USDS and srUSDS within the SRC system are processed. See A.3.3 - Deposit And Redemption Queues. (4) Pioneer Incentive Pools are funded with an amount equivalent to the Sky Savings Rate applied to unrewarded USDS. See A.2.4 - Pioneer Chain Primitive. (5) The Smart Burn Buffer’s burning operation occurs synchronously with each Monthly Settlement Cycle. At each cycle, the system calculates the appropriate Burn Rate based on current market conditions and executes the burn operation, if applicable, according to the formula specified in the Atlas. See A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Smart Burn Buffer - Usage Of Smart Burn Buffer. (6) Critical Core GovOps functions related to the operationalization of Sky Primitives are executed, including payment/reimbursement processing, compliance monitoring, and the calculation and application of retroactive penalties.
A.2.5 - A1 - Agent Incubation - Support For Agents Agent Incubation - Support For Agents Section This Section defines elements and infrastructure to support Agents.
A.2.6 - A1 - Ecosystem Actor Incubation Ecosystem Actor Incubation Section The Support Scope is responsible for incubating Ecosystem Actors. This Section defines the elements to support this objective.
A.2.6 - Ecosystem Actor Incubation - Incubating Ecosystem Actors Ecosystem Actor Incubation - Incubating Ecosystem Actors Core Incubating Ecosystem Actors are Ecosystem Actors that are being developed to support the Sky Protocol or its current and future Agents. Sky Governance can assign these actors projects that benefit the Sky Protocol or incubating Agents, such as solutions for branding, marketing, user acquisition; referral marketing and revenue share systems; smart contract development; and protocol development.
A.2.6 - Ecosystem Actor Incubation - Budgets Ecosystem Actor Incubation - Budgets Core The Support Facilitators have budgets available to support the tasks described in this Section, including the Incubation Overhead budget and the Incubation budget.
A.2.6 - Ecosystem Actor Incubation - Currently Incubating Ecosystem Actors Ecosystem Actor Incubation - Currently Incubating Ecosystem Actors Active Data Controller Incubating Ecosystem Actors and their current key terms and data are defined as Active Data in A.2.6 - Currently Incubating Ecosystem Actors. The Active Data is updated as follows:• The Responsible Party is the Support Facilitators.• The Update Process must follow the protocol for 'Direct Edit'.
A.2.6 - Ecosystem Actor Incubation - Currently Incubating Ecosystem Actors Template Ecosystem Actor Incubation - Currently Incubating Ecosystem Actors Template Core The list of Incubating Ecosystem Actors must follow this template for each recorded Incubating Ecosystem Actor:• .x: [Incubating Ecosystem Actor name and short description]• .1: [Budget information]• .2: [Deliverables and focus areas]• .3: [Team information, including headcount grouped by skill sets]
A.2.7 - A1 - Ecosystem Communication Channels Ecosystem Communication Channels Section The Support Scope maintains the overall unified communication infrastructure used for governance ecosystem communication. This Section defines key elements and infrastructure supporting this objective.
A.2.7 - Ecosystem Communication Channels - Communications Infrastructure Ecosystem Communication Channels - Communications Infrastructure Core The Support Facilitators are tasked with maintaining an ecosystem-wide communications infrastructure to enable Agent participants and Ecosystem Actors to interact with each other and discuss the Sky Ecosystem.
A.2.7 - Ecosystem Communication Channels - Communications Infrastructure - Forum Ecosystem Communication Channels - Communications Infrastructure - Forum Core The communications infrastructure must include an ecosystem Forum devoted to discussions on Agent-related business proposals, partnerships and interactions, as well as casual conversation for the broader Sky Ecosystem.
A.2.7 - Ecosystem Communication Channels - Communications Infrastructure - Chatroom Ecosystem Communication Channels - Communications Infrastructure - Chatroom Core The communications infrastructure must include a chatroom for broad discussion related to Agents, Ecosystem Actors and Sky. As an initial bootstrapping measure, the Support Facilitators can use Discord.
A.2.7 - Ecosystem Communication Channels - Communications Infrastructure Budget Ecosystem Communication Channels - Communications Infrastructure Budget Core The ecosystem communication infrastructure budget is 0 USDS per quarter.
A.2.8 - A1 - Ecosystem Accords - List Of Active Ecosystem Accords Ecosystem Accords - List Of Active Ecosystem Accords Section The subdocuments herein record currently active Ecosystem Accords.
A.2.10 - Ecosystem Accord 1: Launch Agent 1 And Spark Agent Ecosystem Accord 1: Launch Agent 1 And Spark Agent Core The subdocuments herein record the terms of agreement between Launch Agent 1 and Spark as agreed in Ecosystem Accord 1.
A.2.10 - Accord Key Details Accord Key Details Core The subdocuments herein set out the key details of Ecosystem Accord 1, such as parties to the agreement and the duration of the Accord.
A.2.10 - Parties To The Accord Parties To The Accord Core The Launch Agent 1 and the Spark Agent are the parties to Ecosystem Accord 1. These parties are also referred to as Launch Agent 1 and Spark, respectively, in the terms of this Accord.
A.2.10 - Duration Of The Accord Duration Of The Accord Core The duration of Ecosystem Accord 1 is six (6) months, commencing from May 29, 2025.
A.2.10 - Accord Substantive Terms Accord Substantive Terms Core The subdocuments herein set out the substantive terms of Ecosystem Accord 1.
A.2.10 - Revenue Share Revenue Share Core Launch Agent 1 and Spark agree to a bilateral revenue share, up to 40% maximum with JRC rental, see A.2.4 - Junior Risk Capital Rental Primitive.
A.2.10 - Revenue Share Definition Revenue Share Definition Core Each Agent retains the right to force the other Star Agent to do revenue sharing up to 40% by providing that Star with rented JRC. Sharing is done on the net revenue after deducting the cost to Sky. This is only considered on the spread earned on USDS debt, including any subsidy amounts.
A.2.10 - Launch Agent 1 Agent Exclusivity Launch Agent 1 Agent Exclusivity Core Launch Agent 1 exclusivity includes Real World Assets (RWAs), which exclusivity does not extend to Treasuries used for ASC purposes or stablecoin liquidity provisioning.
A.2.10 - Spark Agent Exclusivity Spark Agent Exclusivity Core Spark Agent exclusivity includes Maple, cryptocurrency OTC lending, and Established DeFi Lending Protocols, as defined in A.2.10 - Established DeFi Lending Protocol Definition.
A.2.10 - Established DeFi Lending Protocol Definition Established DeFi Lending Protocol Definition Core Established DeFi Lending Protocols are defined as DeFi lending protocols deployed six months ago or earlier.
A.2.10 - Right Of First Refusal Right Of First Refusal Core Launch Agent 1 provides the Spark Agent with a right of first refusal for DeFi opportunities on unclaimed chains and new protocols, including bootstrapping incentive programs.
A.2.10 - DeFi Opportunities Right of First Refusal Duration DeFi Opportunities Right of First Refusal Duration Core Launch Agent 1 provides the Spark Agent a right of first refusal for pursuing cross-chain bootstrapping opportunities, which lasts four weeks after notification by Launch Agent 1. If Spark does not wish to deploy SparkLend or provide capital to the protocol in question, Launch Agent 1 retains the right to pursue the opportunity pending security and risk assessments of the target protocol. Upon written notification from Launch Agent 1 of a new DeFi opportunity via a communications channel mutually agreed by the parties, Spark has four weeks to decide whether it wants to deploy SparkLend or lend to the target chain and protocol. If Spark opts not to do so by the end of the four-week period, Launch Agent 1 is permitted to pursue the opportunity.Example: A lending protocol (i.e. Aave, Euler, Morpho, etc) plans on deploying on blockchain X. Launch Agent 1 provides written notification to Spark about the potential new deployment. Spark evaluates the opportunity and decides there are better opportunities to pursue. The opportunity reverts to Launch Agent 1 after Spark's refusal; or, if Spark does not issue a formal refusal, the opportunity reverts to Launch Agent 1 after four weeks.
A.2.10 - DeFi Opportunities Complementary Deployments DeFi Opportunities Complementary Deployments Core Launch Agent 1 and Spark may combine efforts if there is a large enough cross-chain opportunity. For example, Launch Agent 1 may deploy stablecoin liquidity on a target chain and Spark may deploy a SparkLend instance. In this case, complementary efforts are made to mutually benefit the cross-chain deployment, with significant economic benefits received by both parties. This chain would also serve as a new distribution channel for Spark, Launch Agent 1, and Sky products.
A.2.10 - ASC Provision ASC Provision Core Launch Agent 1 retains the right to deploy into repo lending protocols to meet ASC requirements. Deposits must be capped at the lower of either 10% of protocol USDC deposits or the Minimum Actively Stabilizing Collateral, as defined in A.3.4 - Minimum Actively Stabilizing Collateral. The Spark Agent retains the right to use the PSM for ASC, provided it covers the cost to Launch Agent 1.
A.2.10 - Treasuries Provision Treasuries Provision Core The Spark Agent retains the right to deploy into tokenized US Treasury Bills to meet ASC requirements.
A.2.10 - Basis Trade Products Basis Trade Products Core Basis trade products are available to both Launch Agent 1 and Spark.
A.2.10 - Grand Prix Airdrops Grand Prix Airdrops Core Launch Agent 1 receives any airdrops from the Grand Prix.
A.2.10 - Ecosystem Accord 2: Launch Agent 1 And Spark - Star Program Ecosystem Accord 2: Launch Agent 1 And Spark - Star Program Core The subdocuments herein record the terms of agreement between Sky, Launch Agent 1, and Spark as agreed in Ecosystem Accord 2.
A.2.10 - Accord Key Details Accord Key Details Core The subdocuments herein set out the key details of Ecosystem Accord 2, such as parties to the agreement and the duration of the Accord.
A.2.10 - Parties To The Accord Parties To The Accord Core The parties to Ecosystem Accord 2 are Sky, Spark, Launch Agent 1, and Moonbow, as defined in the subdocuments herein.
A.2.10 - Sky Details Sky Details Core The party 'Sky' comprises Sky Core.
A.2.10 - Spark Details Spark Details Core The party 'Spark' comprises the Spark Star Agent, Spark Foundation, and Phoenix Labs.
A.2.10 - Launch Agent 1 Details Launch Agent 1 Details Core The party 'Launch Agent 1' comprises the Launch Agent 1 Star Agent, and Launch Agent 1 Foundation.
A.2.10 - Moonbow Details Moonbow Details Core The party 'Moonbow' is the entity owning relevant intellectual property.
A.2.10 - Duration Of The Accord Duration Of The Accord Core The duration of Ecosystem Accord 2 is indefinite, commencing from May 29, 2025.
A.2.10 - Accord Substantive Terms Accord Substantive Terms Core The subdocuments herein set out the substantive terms of Ecosystem Accord 2.
A.2.10 - Tokenomics Tokenomics Core The subdocuments herein set out agreed terms with respect to tokenomics.
A.2.10 - Total Token Supply Total Token Supply Core The total token supply of each of the SPK and AGENT1 tokens shall be 10,000,000,000 (ten billion).
A.2.10 - Token Allocations Token Allocations Core Specific token allocations are defined in the subdocuments herein.
A.2.10 - Launch Agent 1 Star Treasury Launch Agent 1 Star Treasur Core 3,000,000,000 AGENT1 tokens are allocated to the Launch Agent 1 Star Treasury (Launch Agent 1's SubProxy), with an option to further increase this allocation by 5% (500,000,000 tokens). The additional 5% will be distributed to relevant stakeholders / users from Sky's allocation of AGENT1 tokens, but that distribution will happen from Launch Agent 1's SubProxy. This distribution plan must be approved by Sky before the transfer.
A.2.10 - Liquidity For Market Makers Stipulation Liquidity For Market Makers Stipulation Core The Star Treasury allocations are not intended for direct compensation of market makers. Any incentives for market makers would need to be structured separately, potentially utilizing a portion of the Star Treasury allocation or through other mechanisms.
A.2.10 - Sky Retained Tokens And Reward Pools Sky Retained Tokens And Reward Pools Core Sky retains 7,000,000,000 AGENT1 tokens and 6,500,000,000 SPK tokens, distributing these as token rewards over a 10-year period according to the schedules outlined below.
A.2.10 - Launch Agent 1 Token Reward Distribution Schedule Launch Agent 1 Token Reward Distribution Schedule Core Sky will distribute AGENT1 tokens annually, per the following schedule:| Year | Tokens for USDS Users | Tokens for Staking Users | Total ||------|------------------------|---------------------------|-----------------|| 1 | 1,225,000,000 | 525,000,000 | 1,750,000,000 || 2 | 1,225,000,000 | 525,000,000 | 1,750,000,000 || 3 | 612,500,000 | 262,500,000 | 875,000,000 || 4 | 612,500,000 | 262,500,000 | 875,000,000 || 5 | 306,250,000 | 131,250,000 | 437,500,000 || 6 | 306,250,000 | 131,250,000 | 437,500,000 || 7 | 153,125,000 | 65,625,000 | 218,750,000 || 8 | 153,125,000 | 65,625,000 | 218,750,000 || 9 | 153,125,000 | 65,625,000 | 218,750,000 || 10 | 153,125,000 | 65,625,000 | 218,750,000 || Total| 4,900,000,000 | 2,100,000,000 | 7,000,000,000 |
A.2.10 - Spark Token Reward Distribution Schedule Spark Token Reward Distribution Schedule Core Sky will distribute SPK tokens annually, per the following schedule:| Year | Tokens for USDS Users | Tokens for Staking Users | Total ||------|------------------------|---------------------------|-----------------|| 1 | 1,137,500,000 | 487,500,000 | 1,625,000,000 || 2 | 1,137,500,000 | 487,500,000 | 1,625,000,000 || 3 | 568,750,000 | 243,750,000 | 812,500,000 || 4 | 568,750,000 | 243,750,000 | 812,500,000 || 5 | 284,375,000 | 121,875,000 | 406,250,000 || 6 | 284,375,000 | 121,875,000 | 406,250,000 || 7 | 142,187,500 | 60,937,500 | 203,125,000 || 8 | 142,187,500 | 60,937,500 | 203,125,000 || 9 | 142,187,500 | 60,937,500 | 203,125,000 || 10 | 142,187,500 | 60,937,500 | 203,125,000 || Total| 4,550,000,000 | 1,950,000,000 | 6,500,000,000 |
A.2.10 - Transfer Limit Transfer Limit Core A maximum of 1,000,000,000 tokens can be transferred by Spark and Launch Agent 1 to their respective Foundations in the first year for the purpose of rewarding contributors, and 500,000,000 tokens per year thereafter for the purpose of rewarding contributors.
A.2.10 - Star Token Generation Event Star Token Generation Event Core The respective Star Foundations for Spark and Launch Agent 1, or one of their subsidiaries or affiliate companies, will conduct the token generation event. In the token generation event, the Agent tokens will be split and sent to the Star SubProxy and Sky Proxy. In this process, Sky will receive a universal override over the Star Agent Token in question.
A.2.10 - Minimum Float Minimum Float Core For each of Spark and Launch Agent 1, a minimum of 10% of the total token supply must be in circulation (float) within a year, and maintain that float afterward. If the float goes below the 10% threshold, the Star Agent might have 1 natural year to get the float back to 10% or above. If the float falls below 10%, Sky will mint additional Star Agent tokens until the 10% threshold is reached. Newly minted tokens would be farmed and the revenue from farming would be returned to the Star Agent, net of a penalty for needing to trigger the minimum float.
A.2.10 - Borrowing Capacity And Mechanism Borrowing Capacity And Mechanism Core The subdocuments herein set out agreed terms with respect to borrowing capacity and the borrow rate mechanism.
A.2.10 - Subsidized Borrowing Subsidized Borrowing Core Both Spark and Launch Agent 1 are entitled to borrow up to 1,000,000,000 USDS from Sky at a subsidized rate for an initial period of 2 years. The subsidized loan must be triggered before the end of 2025. This subsidized rate is set out in A.2.10 - Borrow Rate Mechanism.
A.2.10 - Borrow Rate Mechanism Borrow Rate Mechanism Core The borrow rate subsidy for Spark and Launch Agent 1 will be calculated according to the formula: t-bill_rate + ((base_rate - t-bill_rate) * T/24), where T represents elapsed months and is a counter that increases monthly over the 2-year period.
A.2.10 - Base Rate Base Rate Core The Base Rate will be dynamic and aligned with the SSR (Sky Savings Rate).
A.2.10 - Minimum Borrowing Threshold for Grant Eligibility Minimum Borrowing Threshold for Grant Eligibility Core Stars, including Spark and Launch Agent 1, must each maintain a minimum borrowing of 1,000,000,000 USDS from Sky at all times to remain eligible for the full monthly reimbursement grant. If the amount borrowed falls below this threshold, the reimbursement grant will be proportionately slashed. This grant will cover the difference between the borrowing Base Rate and the T-bill rate. Spark and Launch Agent 1 can borrow amounts exceeding the 1,000,000,000 USDS limit at the prevailing Base Rate.
A.2.10 - Borrowing Above Subsidized Limit Borrowing Above Subsidized Limit Core Spark and Launch Agent 1 can borrow amounts exceeding the 1,000,000,000 USDS limit at the prevailing Base Rate.
A.2.10 - Recourse Recourse Core Sky's recourse for bad debt consists of (1) minting Star Agent tokens; (2) terminating a Star's right to further borrowing; and (3) activation of the Resolution Mechanism which includes, without limitation, the authority to suspend all protocol operations, seize or reallocate all of the Star assets, override or disable smart contract functions, initiate managed restructuring, or execute full and permanent liquidation of the affected sub-protocol and all of its assets, in order to contain risk and preserve the stability and solvency of the broader ecosystem.
A.2.10 - Accessibility Reward Accessibility Reward Core The subdocuments herein set out agreed terms with respect to the Accessibility Reward.
A.2.10 - Accessibility Reward Rate Accessibility Reward Rate Core The standard Accessibility Reward rate is set at 0.2%. The Accessibility Reward is divided according to the subdocuments herein.
A.2.10 - Frontend Portion Frontend Portion Core Up to a maximum of 50% of the Accessibility Reward rate is apportioned to frontends.
A.2.10 - Star Portion Star Portion Core A minimum of 50% of the Accessibility Reward rate is apportioned to Star Agents. This percentage can be up to 100%, dependent on reduction from the Frontend Portion.
A.2.10 - Split Specification Split Specification Core Spark and Launch Agent 1 will specify the split of the Star Portion in their respective Agent Artifacts, with an expectation of a 50/50 split (0.1% each).
A.2.10 - 2025 Bonus 2025 Bonus Core An additional 0.4% Accessibility Reward bonus will apply during the calendar year 2025 (ending December 31, 2025). This bonus is strictly limited to the Star and does not extend to the Star Foundation.
A.2.10 - Sky Spread Sky Spread Core A fixed margin of 0.05% (Sky Spread) forms part of the overall differential between the Savings Rate and the Base Rate, representing the premium earned by Sky for facilitating the ecosystem's financing. The total spread between the Savings Rate and the Base Rate is therefore 0.25%.
A.2.10 - Double Distribution Upkeep To Sky Double Distribution Upkeep To Sky Core The subdocuments herein set out agreed terms with respect to distributions to Sky.
A.2.10 - Distribution Requirement Distribution Requirement Core To ensure continuous ecosystem support over the period of years 10 to 30, Star Agents must distribute either 0.5% of the market capitalization of their token per year, if distributed in tokens; or 0.6% of their market capitalization of their token per year if paid in stablecoins as a fee. These amounts include both the Standard Annual Upkeep Payment as set out in A.2.10 - Standard Annual Upkeep Payment and the Additional Incremental Upkeep Payment as set out in A.2.10 - Additional Incremental Upkeep Payment.
A.2.10 - Distribution Structure Distribution Structure Core To ensure continued ecosystem support, Stars, including Spark and Launch Agent 1, are required to make annual upkeep payments to Sky, calculated based on retained funds as set out in the subdocuments herein.
A.2.10 - Standard Annual Upkeep Payment Standard Annual Upkeep Payment Core All Star Agents will pay a standard annual upkeep payment of 25 basis points (bps) (0.25%) per year. This standard upkeep payment applies permanently and is separate from any additional payments explained below.
A.2.10 - Additional Incremental Upkeep Payment Additional Incremental Upkeep Payment Core If a Star Agent elects not to distribute certain funds to Sky, but instead retains those funds in its treasury, the Star incurs an additional incremental upkeep payment. The incremental payment is calculated based on the total retained funds at the rate of 2.5 basis points (bps) (0.025%) per year per $1 million retained, if the payment is made in tokens. If the payment is made in cash (USD) rather than tokens, the incremental payment increases by 20%. This results in a rate of 3 basis points (bps) (0.03%) per year per $1 million retained.
A.2.10 - Genesis Capital Allocation Genesis Capital Allocation Core The subdocuments herein set out agreed terms with respect to genesis capital allocations.
A.2.10 - Spark Initial Allocation Spark Initial Allocation Core The Initial Allocation for Spark is 25,000,000 USDS.
A.2.10 - Launch Agent 1 Initial Allocation Launch Agent 1 Initial Allocation Core The Initial Allocation for Launch Agent 1 is 25,000,000 USDS.
A.2.10 - Initial Allocation Distribution Initial Allocation Distribution Core The Initial Allocation is distributed in USDS to each Star SubProxy (i.e. the Spark SubProxy and Launch Agent 1 SubProxy). Both Launch Agent 1 and Spark elected to distribute 5% of the total token supply over a period of 20 years, lasting from year 10 to year 30, and will receive USDS 25,000,000 each.
A.2.10 - Initial Allocation Mechanism Initial Allocation Mechanism Core Prior to the Agent Token launch, an Atlas Edit Proposal submitted to Sky Governance will allow the respective founding teams of Spark and Launch Agent 1, to propose an initial cash grant to their respective Star Foundation. Sky Governance must consent to this initial cash grant via approving the Sky Atlas modification.
A.2.10 - Intellectual Property Intellectual Property Core The subdocuments herein set out agreed terms with respect to intellectual property.
A.2.10 - License Agreements License Agreements Core Each Star Foundation (i.e. the Spark Foundation and Launch Agent 1 Foundation) must sign a license agreement with Moonbow for all relevant intellectual property. This license agreement must contain the following terms:
  • Worldwide, commercial, exclusive license, revocable for material breach (immediate revocation in severe cases, 30-day notice for non-severe cases).
  • Royalty-free.
  • Perpetual term, subject to termination provisions.
  • Sublicensing allowed in specified cases without approval; any other sublicenses allowed only with Moonbow's explicit approval (not to be unreasonably withheld).
  • Licensee responsible for IP protection and enforcement; license agreement to define specific requirements.
  • Quarterly/annual reporting requirements on fraud cases and brand protection actions.
  • Moonbow's right to audit (at Moonbow's cost).
  • All improvements/developments belong to Moonbow.
  • Monetary penalties for IP violations shall be explicitly defined in the full licensing agreement, with specific thresholds for triggering penalties to be mutually agreed and stipulated therein.
  • Customary mutual indemnification and limitation of liability provisions.
  • Mandatory arbitration except in case of injunctive relief.
  • Other customary terms, conditions, representations and warranties.
A.2.10 - Open Source Protocol Code Open Source Protocol Code Core All components of code that form part of the Star Protocols (i.e. Spark and Launch Agent 1) will be open source.
A.2.10 - Financial Strategies Financial Strategies Core The financial strategies implemented by the Star Foundations (i.e. the Spark Foundation and Launch Agent 1 Foundation) will be closed source. Operational specifics are further defined in the subdocuments herein.
A.2.10 - Role Of Star Foundation Role Of Star Foundation Core The Star Foundation (i.e. the Spark Foundation and Launch Agent 1 Foundation) will retain ownership of the code and strategies that determine how capital is allocated for its Star. They will contract with the Development Company for the development and execution of the strategies.
A.2.10 - Role Of Development Company Role Of Development Company Core The Development Company for each Star Agent will execute the strategy and relay the results to the Operational Executor Agent.
A.2.10 - Role Of Operational Executor Agent Role Of Operational Executor Agent Core The relevant Operational Executor Agent, which is already engaged to the Star in question and bound root access to the SubProxy, will conduct a principled compatibility analysis to ensure the strategy aligns with the Sky Atlas and the relevant Star Artifact. Once validated, the Operational Executor Agent executes the capital allocation in question.
A.2.10 - Star Tokenholder Governance Rights Star Tokenholder Governance Rights Core To ensure accountability, Star token holders will retain governance rights, including the ability to revoke the Operational Executor Agent's root access through a vote if necessary.
A.2.10 - Peg Stability Module Management And Ownership Peg Stability Module Management And Ownership Core The subdocuments herein set out agreed terms with respect to the Peg Stability Module (PSM).
A.2.10 - Current and Future Control Current and Future Control Core The subdocuments herein set out details about the current control and oversight of the PSM, including the transition to ownership by Launch Agent 1.
A.2.10 - Current Control (Until 2026) Current Control (Until 2026) Core The Peg Stability Module (PSM) remains directly managed and controlled by Sky until the full deployment and operationalization of the Actively Stabilizing Collateral (ASC) system. Sky retains responsibility for setting debt ceilings, determining liquidity levels, and overseeing asset management activities within the PSM during this period.
A.2.10 - Transition to Launch Agent 1 (2025) Transition to Launch Agent 1 (2025) Core Beginning in 2025, Launch Agent 1 shall assume operational and accounting ownership of the PSM, incorporating the PSM's assets into its total value locked (TVL). Sky maintains active oversight and retains final control over strategic and operational decision-making within the PSM until full ASC implementation occurs.
A.2.10 - Operational Responsibilities Operational Responsibilities Core The subdocuments herein set out details about operational responsibilities relating to the PSM.
A.2.10 - Base Rate Obligation Base Rate Obligation Core Launch Agent 1 will be required to pay the Base Rate on all assets within the PSM. The Base Rate is dynamic and will align with the SSR (Sky Savings Rate), expected to fluctuate between the Aave and Ethena rates. See A.2.10 - Base Rate.
A.2.10 - Yield on USDC Yield on USDC Core Launch Agent 1 shall earn yield through Coinbase Custody on USDC holdings within the PSM, enabling potential positive carry depending upon the spread between custody yield and the Base Rate.
A.2.10 - Economic Rationale Economic Rationale Core Launch Agent 1 will pay the Base Rate on the PSM for the purpose of meeting ASC requirements, if there are no better alternatives available. Unlike other alternatives, USDC in the PSM will have no capital requirement. If other, better options for ASC are available, Launch Agent 1 should empty the PSM and allocate the assets to those options. It is anticipated that other protocols will also be willing to rent ASC "points", potentially allowing for the management of ASC needs across several Star Agents for a profit.
A.2.10 - Future Transition and Long-Term Vision Future Transition and Long-Term Vision Core The subdocuments herein set out agreed terms with respect to the future transition and long-term vision for the PSM.
A.2.10 - Short Term (2025-2026) Short Term (2025-2026) Core The PSM will remain a central liquidity hub for stablecoin deployment. Launch Agent 1 will manage the PSM, paying the Base Rate while earning USDC yield, under Sky oversight until full ASC implementation. PSM assets will count toward Launch Agent 1's TVL, enhancing its economic standing and collateral efficiency.
A.2.10 - Long Term (Post-2026) Long Term (Post-2026) Core The PSM's role will diminish as the ASC system becomes the primary liquidity management tool. Launch Agent 1 can wind down the PSM entirely if ASC requirements are fulfilled through other mechanisms (e.g., Uniswap positions, Curve pools). If ASC obligations rise significantly, PSM usage will increase, but as the system matures, its relevance will gradually decline.
A.2.10 - Implications for Launch Agent 1 Implications for Launch Agent 1 Core The subdocuments herein set out implications of the PSM terms with respect to Launch Agent 1.
A.2.10 - Positive Carry And Liquidity Balancing Positive Carry And Liquidity Balancing Core Launch Agent 1 can generate positive carry if the USDC yield exceeds the Base Rate. If the Base Rate rises significantly, the PSM may become costly, requiring liquidity balancing.
A.2.10 - Capital Efficiency Capital Efficiency Core Launch Agent 1 can deploy USDC in high-yield strategies while retaining enough ASC to meet requirements. Aave USDC (aUSDC) and Curve LP positions are likely alternatives to direct PSM usage, albeit potentially with higher JRC requirements.
A.2.10 - Risk Management Risk Management Core The PSM serves as a capital buffer, enabling Launch Agent 1 to scale liquidity massively without additional credit enhancement. As ASC obligations fluctuate, the PSM will act as a dynamic backstop, ensuring resilience during periods of high demand.
A.2.10 - Token Launch Penalty, Capital Transfer, And Income Generation Token Launch Penalty, Capital Transfer, And Income Generation Core The subdocuments herein set out agreed terms with respect to a token launch penalty, capital transfer, and income generation.
A.2.10 - Token Launch Penalty Token Launch Penalty Core If either Spark or Launch Agent 1 (each, a "Star") does not complete its Star Token Generation Event ("TGE") at the time the Risk Framework is finalized and approved by Sky Governance and income generation commences, a penalty of thirty percent (30%) will apply. This penalty will be calculated on the income (as defined in A.2.10 - Income Definition) the Star is receiving or is meant to receive (including revenue that has accrued but has not been transferred) until the TGE occurs. The penalty shall be deducted from the Genesis Capital Allocation at the time of the Capital Transfer.
A.2.10 - Transfer Of Capital Funds Transfer Of Capital Funds Core The transfer of the Genesis Capital Allocation to each Star SubProxy (i.e. the Spark SubProxy and Launch Agent 1 SubProxy) shall occur once funding from the Surplus Buffer is approved. This condition ensures that capital deployment is aligned with the successful launch of the Star's token and the commencement of its independent operations. Any penalties applied under A.2.10 - Token Launch Penalty shall be deducted from the Capital Allocation at the time of transfer.
A.2.10 - Cessation Of MKR and SKY Token Flow Cessation Of MKR and SKY Token Flow Core Upon the commencement of Income Generation (as defined in A.2.10 - Income Definition) by a Star, any existing or previously agreed-upon allocation or distribution of MKR or SKY tokens from Sky to that Star shall immediately cease. The intent is for the Stars to transition to financial self-sufficiency upon the initiation of their respective income-generating activities. Furthermore, any token vesting to the Star Foundation will be reduced by 50% until the TGE occurs. Prior to the TGE, Stars agree to share with Sky the Star Agent Token vesting schedules and lock-ups for their teams to ensure they align with the principles of long-term commitment to the Star.
A.2.10 - Treatment of Expenses Paid By Sky Pre-TGE Treatment of Expenses Paid By Sky Pre-TGE Core Any operational or other expenses incurred by a Star and paid directly by Sky 60 days prior to the Risk Framework finalization and commencement of Income Generation shall be treated as an advance against the Star's Genesis Capital Allocation. The total amount of such expenses shall be documented and shall be deducted from the Star's allocated capital funds at the time of the Capital Transfer (as outlined in A.2.10 - Transfer Of Capital Funds).
A.2.10 - Income Generation And Pre-TGE Credit Income Generation And Pre-TGE Credit Core "Income Generation" shall be deemed to commence upon the finalization of the Risk Framework applicable to each respective Star, which is anticipated to be ready by end of May, 2025. The Risk Framework is deemed finalized when the Atlas Edit proposal for the Risk Framework is formally approved via a Sky Governance vote. From the date of Risk Framework finalization until the Star's TGE, seventy percent (70%) of any income generated by the Star's activities shall be credited to its Capital account (net of any expenses paid by Sky as per A.2.10 - Treatment of Expenses Paid By Sky Pre-TGE), subject to any penalties.
A.2.10 - Income Definition Income Definition Core "Income" means all revenues or fees received or accrued by the applicable Star following finalization of its Risk Framework, including: (i) Accessibility Rewards (0.2%), (ii) Accessibility Reward Bonus for 2025 (0.4%), (iii) any Platform Fees charged to users, and (iv) Real World Asset fees charged to users, including any origination, servicing, or related charges, and (v) the blended cost of allocation spread between Junior and Senior Risk Capital.
A.2.9 - A1 - Legal Resilience Legal Resilience Section This Section manages the Resilience Fund (also "RF") and other infrastructure for legal risk management and legal governance.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources Core This document defines the resources available for legal defense. Over time, it can include both Sky Governance-controlled assets and external third-party resources and may be used to cover additional risks.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Core The Resilience Fund (RF) is a self-insurance instrument fully controlled by Sky Governance, which will cover legal defense expenses in case of legal or regulatory action against Sky or active participants in the Sky Ecosystem. The RF will be the primary source for direct legal defense funding. The conditions of use are defined in A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Claim Management Process.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Budget Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Budget Core The budget of the Resilience Fund is defined in A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Current Budget. The Support Facilitator can propose to pay out the budget manually through a Weekly Governance Cycle, according to the rules related to claims described in this Section. The Support Facilitator can propose modifications to the document cited above through the Weekly Governance Cycle.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Current Budget Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Current Budget Core The current active budget for the Resilience Fund is: 5,000,000 USDS per year, with the full amount available at the start of each calendar year.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Transition Funding Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Transition Funding Core Legal defense expenses directly related to Sky may be temporarily financed using the resources of the Resilience Fund. However, a separate Claim Protocol and Standard Operational Protocol must be developed to govern cases where Sky is the target of a legal or regulatory action.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Technical Committee Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Technical Committee Core The Resilience Technical Committee is a group of Ecosystem Actors authorized by Sky to provide operational support such as onboarding new beneficiaries to the RF, approving quotes, and assessing claims to be supported by the RF. Additional operational support includes providing general advice on the further development of the fund, amendments to the claim procedure, resilience measures and other risk-management topics.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Technical Committee Selection And Compensation Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Technical Committee Selection And Compensation Core The Support Facilitator selects the members of the Resilience Technical Committee and manages payments for their services on a project basis. The associated budget is defined in A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Current Budget.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Technical Committee Member Requirements Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Technical Committee Member Requirements Core The individual members of the Resilience Technical Committee who are directly involved in providing operational services on behalf of Sky must fulfill the requirements defined in the subdocuments herein.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Technical Committee Member Skill Set Requirement Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Technical Committee Member Skill Set Requirement Core Members of the Resilience Technical Committee must have relevant experience or current employment in the legal industry, or with a world-leading insurance broker, insurance company, or risk management firm.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Technical Committee Member Experience Requirement Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Technical Committee Member Experience Requirement Core Members of the Resilience Technical Committee must have at least three (3) years of experience managing self-insurance instruments or experience in legal or regulatory risk analysis.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Technical Committee Member Professional Degree Requirement Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Technical Committee Member Professional Degree Requirement Core Members of the Resilience Technical Committee must have a law, management, risk, or insurance professional degree.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Technical Committee Member No Conflicts Requirement Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Technical Committee Member No Conflicts Requirement Core Members of the Resilience Technical Committee must not be involved in any business activity outside Sky or in any role within Sky that could result in a conflict of interest, either directly or indirectly.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Technical Committee Member Technology Experience Requirement Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Technical Committee Member Technology Experience Requirement Core Members of the Resilience Technical Committee must have at least three (3) years of experience in the cryptocurrency, DeFi, Web3, or emerging technology sectors.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Technical Committee Current Membership Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Technical Committee Current Membership Active Data Controller Approved Resilience Technical Committee members are defined as Active Data in A.2.9 - Resilience Fund Technical Committee List Of Current Members.The Active Data is updated as follows:• The Responsible Party is the Support Facilitators.• The Update Process must follow the protocol for 'Direct Edit'.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Policy Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Policy Core This provision and its subdocuments will govern the conditions and terms of use of the Resilience Fund.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Policy Loss Events Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Policy Loss Events Core The Resilience Process covers legal defense or legal representation expenses incurred by a participant of the Sky Ecosystem when they are the defendant or respondent in a legal or regulatory action ("The Loss Event"). There must be a direct relationship between the legal or regulatory action and the Beneficiary's activity at Sky.A (non-exhaustive) list of legal or regulatory actions that may qualify is:• Official requirements, or communications, from a regulatory body, governmental authority, or a court• Subpoenas• Lawsuit• Writs
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Policy Exclusions Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Policy Exclusions Core The cases specified in the following subelements will generally be excluded from coverage by the legal defense process:• Prior or pending claims• Claims between persons involved in the Sky Ecosystem• Loss covered by other insurance• Willful criminal offenses, fraud, or dishonesty• Conflict of interest
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Policy Beneficiaries Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Policy Beneficiaries Core Eligible beneficiaries of the Resilience Fund are persons who fulfill the following requirements: a) act on their own behalf OR b) act on behalf of a legal entity OR c) act on behalf of a collective AND have one of the following roles: Previous Structure: • Recognized Delegates• Core Unit Facilitators• Core Unit Contributors• Dai Foundation Board Members Current Structure: • Active SKY or Agent token holders that participate regularly in governance (e.g., voting, writing proposals)• Alignment Conservers ◦ Aligned Delegates (ADs)• Scope Facilitators• The Guardian (A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - The Guardian) or actors that fulfill an equivalent role.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - No Acquired Right Or Claim For Resilience Fund Policy Beneficiaries Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - No Acquired Right Or Claim For Resilience Fund Policy Beneficiaries Core Persons qualified as beneficiaries do not have any acquired right or claim. The claim decision process is described in A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Processes And Principles, and the payout of a claim is subject to the approval of the Resilience Technical Committee (at their sole and absolute discretion) and further contingent on a SKY vote endorsing payment of the claim.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Policy Geographic Coverage Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Policy Geographic Coverage Core Geographical coverage is worldwide.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Policy Effective Date Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Policy Effective Date Core A Beneficiary's eligibility for coverage under this Artifact will start after ratification of MIP106: 2023-03-27. ("Effective Date") and expire twenty-four (24) months after cessation of their role as a Beneficiary.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Policy Base Of Coverage Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Policy Base Of Coverage Core Coverage is "Claims made". This means the Loss Event (A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Policy Loss Events) must occur after the Effective Date (A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Policy Effective Date).The facts and circumstances that originated the Loss Event may have occurred in the past for a maximum period of up to twenty-four (24) months before the date representing the later of (a) the Effective Date and (b) the date the Beneficiary is first eligible for coverage under this Artifact (the "Retroactivity Period").
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Processes And Principles Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Processes And Principles Core Overview of the related processes and principles:• Application process• Claim management process• Caps and Exclusions• Refund of amounts to the Resilience Fund
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Application Process Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Application Process Core The Resilience Fund application process is defined in the subdocuments of this document.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Proof Of Eligibility Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Proof Of Eligibility Core To become recognized as a Beneficiary, an Applicant must first select an Ethereum address that is linked to their activity at Sky ("Proof of Eligibility" or "POE"). Each Beneficiary type will have specific Proofs of Eligibility that are suitable for their role.Valid PoE:• Address set as owner and used to sign transactions from Sky multisigs, such as Core Unit operational wallets, auditor wallets or SPFs (old structure), or a Facilitator multisig (Endgame Structure) ◦ PoE valid for former Core Unit Contributors, Core Unit Facilitators, and Scope Facilitators.• Address that voted directly or through delegation in at least ten Governance Polls or Executive Votes. ◦ PoE valid for active MKR or SKY holders, former Recognized Delegates (old structure), and Aligned Delegates (new structure)• Address that received compensation from Sky, with the following conditions: ◦ at least six (6) payouts spread over at least six (6) months in Dai or USDS OR ◦ Dai or USDS DssVest stream spanning at least six (6) months OR ◦ 3 MKR or SKY payouts spread over at least three (3) months OR ◦ MKR or SKY DssVest stream spanning at least three (3) months ◦ PoE valid for former Core Unit Contributors and Facilitators• Address that holds >1 MKR or >24,000 SKY• Attestation ◦ If no PoE is available, a verified Beneficiary must attest eligibility on behalf of the applicant. ◦ This PoE will be used exceptionally if no other Proof is available and will be assessed individually by the Resilience Fund Technical Committee.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Proof Of Eligibility Template Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Proof Of Eligibility Template Core Applications for the Resilience Fund must follow this template:• .x: [Application RF]• .x.1: [PoE]• .x.2: [Active Period]• .x.3: [Relevant Executive Proposal: Governance decision ratified by a governance vote]• .x4: [Signature hash]
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Proof Of Eligibility Digital Signature Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Proof Of Eligibility Digital Signature Core The Applicant for the Resilience Fund must additionally sign an application message from the Ethereum Address (Digital Signature) used as PoE A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Proof Of Eligibility.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Application Resilience Fund Application Terms And Conditions Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Application Resilience Fund Application Terms And Conditions Core By signing this message, the Applicant accepts and agrees:• To comply with the terms and rules of A.2.9 (the "Legal Resilience Fund Terms").• That participation in the program is opt-in and voluntary and can be waived anytime by the Beneficiary.• The Legal Resilience Fund Terms can be amended at any time through the established governance processes.• That being registered as Beneficiary does not give rise to any right, benefit, entitlement, or claim, nor creates an obligation on any party to pay the Beneficiary.Additionally, the Beneficiary declares that:• No situation currently involves or appears to involve a conflict of interest, and any emerging potential conflict of interest shall be disclosed as soon as it happens.• Any role change in Sky or termination of active engagement will be immediately communicated to the Resilience Technical Committee.The Resilience Technical Committee will elaborate a user-friendly onboarding manual for the RF.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Application Confirmation Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Application Confirmation Core The Applicant for the Resilience Fund will additionally send an encrypted message to the Resilience Technical Committee Member in charge of the onboarding process to confirm the application.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Approval Process And Verifiability Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Approval Process And Verifiability Core PoEs rely on a governance decision that was ratified by an Executive Vote.The Resilience Technical Committee Member must identify this governance decision by verifying the spell that enacted the Executive Vote ratifying the respective governance decision. This spell contains the hash of the respective Executive Vote. Exceptional circumstances where no direct governance decision is available or difficult to assert will be handled case by case.The Resilience Technical Committee Member will confirm the onboarding decision via an encrypted message to the Applicant.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Claim Management Process Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Claim Management Process Core Overview of the claim management processes:• Legal Counsel Pre-approval• Claim approval / Advance Payment• Reimbursement
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Legal Counsel And Quote Pre-Approval Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Legal Counsel And Quote Pre-Approval Core The first step in the claim management process is to approve the Legal Counsel to undertake legal defense or representation and the quote presented to commence legal work. The Beneficiary must present the quote from the law firm they selected for their legal defense/representation. The request must indicate at least the following:• Name of Legal Counsel• Name of Law Firm• If not in the Lawyer Registry, Proof of Eligibility• QuoteThe quote must include:1. The initial payment required by Counsel to commence work immediately. This is the initial amount to be claimed against the Resilience Fund.2. A global estimated fee based on an hourly rate OR fixed fee OR monthly retainer fee.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Qualified Counsel Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Qualified Counsel Core If the Legal Counsel is RF-qualified in the Lawyer Registry (A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Lawyer Registry), the claim is automatically submitted to the Claim Approval process (A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Claim Approval).
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Not Resilience Fund Qualified Counsel Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Not Resilience Fund Qualified Counsel Core If Legal Counsel is NOT RF-qualified in the Lawyer Registry (A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Lawyer Registry), then the Support Facilitators, or alternatively the Resilience Fund Technical Committee Member, will verify if the Legal Counsel complies with requisites in Lawyer Registry Acceptance Criteria and LR Resilience Fund Acceptance Criteria. See: A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Lawyer Registry Acceptance Criteria and A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Representation Requirements.If the Legal Counsel of the quote is determined by the Resilience Technical Committee to comply with the requirements of this Artifact, the quote is pre-approved and the legal counsel is added to the LR.If the Legal Counsel doesn't comply with the LR requirements, the claim is rejected and the Beneficiary must propose a different Legal Counsel.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Claim Approval Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Claim Approval Core If a Beneficiary incurs a Loss Event, they can submit a Reimbursement Payout Claim against the LD RF according to the process specified in the subdocuments herein.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Claim Approval Payout Claim Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Claim Approval Payout Claim Core The Support Facilitator must review the Reimbursement Claim and decide whether to trigger a Governance Poll to perform a claims payout, by developing an internal model with input from experts and professionals.The Payout Reimbursement Claim must contain the following elements: ◦ Description of Loss Event with relevant commentaries and context ◦ Advance Payment or Reimbursement ◦ Type of process ◦ Date of writ/subpoena/lawsuit ◦ Supportive Documentation ▪ Law firm's proposal and invoice OR quote ▪ Copy of the Lawsuit/writ/ communication OR official requirement issued by a Court or Governmental Agency Supportive documentation is highly sensible. It is required to use encryption tools.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Claim Approval Coverage Framework Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Claim Approval Coverage Framework Core In consultation with the Resilience Technical Committee, the Support Facilitators must develop a framework for establishing limits and coverage amounts per case, and apply these limits to individual claims.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Claim Approval Support Facilitators Review Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Claim Approval Support Facilitators Review Core The Support Facilitators will review the Payout Claim and if it contains all required elements and supportive documentation, will immediately transmit it to the Resilience Fund Technical Committee.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Claim Approval Technical Commitee Review Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Claim Approval Technical Commitee Review Core The Resilience Fund Technical Committee will verify the merits of the claim according to the following substantial criteria (non-exhaustive list):• Absence of Exclusions• Identity and Role of Beneficiary• Time scope• Authenticity of writ/lawsuit• Reasonability of lawyer fees, which must take into account market rates in the respective jurisdiction
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Claim Approval Technical Committee Review Process Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Claim Approval Technical Committee Review Process Core From the moment the Payout Claim is filed, the Resilience Technical Committee will have five (5) working days to provide a payout recommendation. The recommendations of the Technical Committee are made in their sole and absolute discretion, are definitive, and are not subject to appeal.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Claim Approval Quorum And Decision Majorities Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Claim Approval Quorum And Decision Majorities Core Decisions related to claim payouts require a quorum of three (3) experts from the Resilience Technical Committee with a simple majority (>50%).
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Claim Approval Decision Protections Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Claim Approval Decision Protections Core The recommendations of the Resilience Technical Committee are non-binding and will not give rise to any right or claim to the beneficiaries nor give rise to any obligation or responsibility.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Claim Approval Support Facilitators Decision Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Claim Approval Support Facilitators Decision Core Based on the recommendation of the Resilience Technical Committee, the Support Facilitators will decide whether to trigger a Governance Poll through the Weekly Governance Cycle to perform a claim payout.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Payout / Reimbursement Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Payout / Reimbursement Core If the Governance Poll for paying out a claim is successful, an Executive Vote must be created and approved through Sky Governance processes to draw the funds from the Surplus Buffer and send them to the Beneficiary's registered wallet. The spend must be accounted for in the budget in A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Current Budget.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Caps And Exclusions Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Caps And Exclusions Core Unless otherwise approved by a governance vote of Sky, claim funds approved under this Section are subject to the caps and exclusions specified in the subdocuments of this document.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Aggregate Cap Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Aggregate Cap Core Claims will be subject to an aggregate cap for all claims in relation to a Claim Event determined by the risk models elaborated by the Resilience Technical Committee.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Direct Costs And Legal Expenses Cap Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Direct Costs And Legal Expenses Cap Core Claims can only be used to reimburse Beneficiaries for their losses and disbursements directly arising from a Claim Event, and reasonable legal expenses. "Reasonable legal expense" is a variable amount that will be determined taking into account the average market rates of the respective jurisdiction.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Caps Government Or Regulatory Fines Or Damages Exclusion Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Caps Government Or Regulatory Fines Or Damages Exclusion Core Must not be used to reimburse the payment of government or regulatory fines or damages awarded by the court.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Refund Of Amounts To Resilience Fund Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Refund Of Amounts To Resilience Fund Core Where Beneficiaries receive financial benefit or reimbursement of any type as a result of orders of a court, governmental or investigative body or regulatory agency that results in a windfall to the Beneficiary, these windfall amounts will be returned by the Beneficiary to the Resilience Fund within 14 days of receipt.
