A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Refund Of Amounts To Resilience Fund Examples Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Refund Of Amounts To Resilience Fund Examples Core By way of example only and without limiting the generality of the principle described in A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Refund Of Amounts To Resilience Fund, such amounts include, without limitation:• Amounts awarded by a court towards the Beneficiary's legal fees or disbursements;• An award of damages to a Beneficiary in relation to a Claim Event;• Monies or digital assets located by police or other investigative bodies that were identified as the property of Sky; and• Interest payable to a Beneficiary in relation to a Claim Event.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Litigation / Defense Management Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Litigation / Defense Management Core Beneficiaries and their legal teams must, in the conduct of the litigation and as a condition of receiving reimbursement from the Resilience Fund, satisfy all of the conditions listed in the subdocuments of this document.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Good Faith In Resilience Fund Litigation / Defense Management Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Good Faith In Resilience Fund Litigation / Defense Management Core Beneficiaries and their legal teams must act honestly, consistently, and fairly in handling claims and litigation.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Promptness In Resilience Fund Litigation / Defense Management Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Promptness In Resilience Fund Litigation / Defense Management Core Beneficiaries and their legal teams must make an early assessment of the prospects of success and deal with claims promptly.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Cost Control In Resilience Fund Litigation / Defense Management Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Cost Control In Resilience Fund Litigation / Defense Management Core Beneficiaries and their legal teams must keep costs to a minimum and avoid reliance on technical defenses which have low probability of success.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Alternative Dispute Resolution In Resilience Fund Litigation / Defense Management Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Alternative Dispute Resolution In Resilience Fund Litigation / Defense Management Core Beneficiaries and their legal teams must consider alternative dispute resolution (ADR) options at all times.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Lawyer Registry Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Lawyer Registry Core The Lawyer Registry (also "LR") is a registry of specialized Ecosystem Actors who are qualified to perform legal work for Sky Ecosystem or participants in the Sky Ecosystem, including, but not limited to, legal representation or legal defense.Lawyers will be onboarded in the Lawyer Registry covering at least the areas specified in A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Lawyer Registry Covered Areas.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Lawyer Registry Covered Areas Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Lawyer Registry Covered Areas Core | Category | Areas of Law | Examples ||----------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|| Disputes/Investigations | Regulatory Enforcement - Securities/Finance Law | SEC/FinCEN/CFTC/Central Bank matters, Tax authority actions, OFAC Orders, Sanctions || | Securities Law Disputes (private party claims, class actions, etc.) | SKY investor claims, Lawsuits against Sky CORE actors || | Intellectual Property | Patent Claims/Trolls, Trademark Claims/Trolls || | General Litigation - Any other Party-Party Disputes | Disputes between Sky and 3rd party suppliers, Breach of contract disputes, Employment law disputes, Disputes between Sky and Ecosystem actors || Commercial Matters (non-litigious) | Commercial and Contracts | Commercial transactions (Audits, listing agreements, inter-Agent agreements affecting Sky Core etc.), Contracts and Procurement (includes contract management), Competition/Anti-Trust Law, Data protection and Privacy, Insurance Law || | Intellectual Property, Information Technology | IT procurement, licenses, and contracts, Convergent technologies, Intellectual property rights, Data protection and privacy, Trademark/Patent applications || | Corporate Structuring, Entity Formation/Reporting, Corporate Financing and Tax | Entity formation assistance provided to Sky Core, Annual Reporting/Filings, Company Law, Corporate Finance, Tax Law |
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Lawyer Registry Acceptance Criteria Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Lawyer Registry Acceptance Criteria Core To be included in the Lawyer Registry, lawyers must satisfy all requirements described in the following subelements.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Lawyer Registry Licensing Criterion Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Lawyer Registry Licensing Criterion Core Licensed legal professionals in their respective jurisdiction.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Lawyer Registry Technology Experience Criterion Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Lawyer Registry Technology Experience Criterion Core Proven experience with Sky Ecosystem crypto, or emerging technologies.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Lawyer Registry No Conflicts Criterion Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Lawyer Registry No Conflicts Criterion Core No Conflict of Interest in the matter over which they have carriage.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Lawyer Registry Conflict Checks Criterion Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Lawyer Registry Conflict Checks Criterion Core Lawyers must have internal processes to conduct conflict checks prior to any engagement under this Section.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Lawyer Registry Conflict Handling Criterion Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Lawyer Registry Conflict Handling Criterion Core Where conflicts arise within the lawyer's firm, the firm must:1. In the case where a Beneficiary is handling the claim, cease all further work and immediately notify the Resilience Technical Committee in writing and cooperate with the Resilience Technical Committee to avoid a continuing conflict or, where this is not practicable, transfer the matter to another LR registered Lawyer, and2. In the case where the Guardian is handling the claim, cease all further work and immediately notify the Guardian in writing and cooperate with the Guardian to avoid a continuing conflict or, where this is not practicable, transfer the matter to another LR registered Lawyer.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Representation Requirements Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Representation Requirements Core Legal counsel providing services funded through the RF must fulfill additional requirements specified in the subdocuments herein. Legal counsel qualified for RF will be listed as such in the Lawyer Registry.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Representation Experience Requirement Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Representation Experience Requirement Core Lead Counsel, Lead Barristers, and Lead Trial Attorneys (as applicable) must each have a minimum of ten (10) years of relevant legal experience and demonstrable expertise in the specific areas of law, legal processes, and jurisdictions listed on the Lawyer Registry.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Representation Expertise Requirement Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Representation Expertise Requirement Core Lawyers included on the Lawyer Registry for litigious categories, must have been Lead Counsel in at least 15 cases in the relevant area of law, type of process, and jurisdiction for which they are listed. Lawyers included on the Lawyer Registry for non-litigious matters must have demonstrable experience in the relevant area of law, type of process and jurisdiction indicated in the table set out under A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Lawyer Registry Covered Areas.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Lawyer Registry Template Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Lawyer Registry Template Core Entries in the LR must follow this template:• .x: [Advisor name and short description]• .x.1: [Name of Firm]• .x.2: [Specialization Area]• .x.3: [Jurisdiction]• .x.4: [RF qualified (y/n)]
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Requirements For Resilience Technical Committee Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Requirements For Resilience Technical Committee Core The Resilience Technical Committee will verify the eligibility criteria of new candidates in the Lawyer Registry and submit a list of approved candidates to the Support Facilitators.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Lawyer Registry Update Process Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Lawyer Registry Update Process Active Data Controller The current approved lawyers in the Lawyer Registry are defined as Active Data in A.2.9 Lawyer Registry Current Approved Legal Counsels. The Active Data is updated as follows: • The Responsible Party is the Support Facilitators.• The Update Process must follow the protocol for 'Direct Edit'.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - The Guardian Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - The Guardian Core The Guardian is a specialized Ecosystem Actor that will be exclusively mandated to retain and instruct counsel to assist with the legal defense of actors in the Sky Ecosystem that, due to their organizational structure or circumstances, may be unable to obtain legal representation when pursuing or defending claims against adversarial parties.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Legal Defense Standard Operational Protocols Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Legal Defense Standard Operational Protocols Core This document must define the Standard Operational Protocols (SOPs) for reacting against legal or regulatory actions against a participant of the Sky Ecosystem.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Risk Management Legal Resilience - Legal Risk Management Core This document defines the framework for managing, retaining, transferring, and structuring legal risk through instruments such as self-insurance and insurance.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Risk Management - The Policyholder Legal Resilience - Legal Risk Management - The Policyholder Core The Policyholder is a specialized Ecosystem Actor in charge of executing agreements with external entities with the exclusive purpose of structuring and transferring risk to third parties through instruments such as insurances, reinsurances, mutuals, or other types of arrangements. These instruments will provide extended risk coverage for participants of the Sky Ecosystem and Agents. The object of the Policyholder is to • Act as a legal counterparty with insurance brokers, insurance, reinsurance, underwriters, or risk management companies.• Act as a policyholder of insurance contracts, which will have as beneficiaries participants of the Sky Ecosystem.• Hire suppliers and contractors necessary for the operation of self-insurance or insurance instruments, such as ◦ The Resilience Technical Committee for claim management ◦ Managers, Directors, and other executive staff of the legal vehicle. The power of directors will be limited to administrative and operative roles. Sky Governance will have all necessary control mechanisms over the Policyholder: • Sky Governance can designate and remove Directors, Supervisor, and Committees• Sky Governance can instruct the entity to act and ratify decisions• Power of directors is limited to administrative/operative roles• The Policyholder will not manage Sky's assets nor will be legally affiliated with Sky. The setup and operational budget of the legal vehicle will be sourced initially from the A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Defense Resources - Resilience Fund Current Budget. This is intended to move later to a separate budget.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Risk Management - Policyholder Management Legal Resilience - Legal Risk Management - Policyholder Management Core This document governs the adding and removing of Policyholders. SKY holders must first approve the structure and associated costs of the Policyholder, based on a Governance Poll initiated by Facilitators if they deem it necessary.The list of currently approved Policyholders is maintained in A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Risk Management - Current Active Policyholders.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal Risk Management - Current Active Policyholders Legal Resilience - Legal Risk Management - Current Active Policyholders Core There are currently no active Policyholders.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Privacy and Operational Security Legal Resilience - Privacy and Operational Security Core This document must define policies pertaining to operational security, privacy, and pseudonymity for participants in the Sky Ecosystem. The general purpose of this framework is to maximize security and safety for contributors and users and minimize potential attack vectors for the Ecosystem.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Advocacy And Public Policy Legal Resilience - Advocacy And Public Policy Core This document defines the framework and processes for public policy, advocacy, and governmental relations. The general purpose of this framework is to develop innovative regulatory frameworks and standards that protect open source resources and position the Public Good Purpose of the Sky Ecosystem.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Legal And Regulatory Risk Monitoring Legal Resilience - Legal And Regulatory Risk Monitoring Core This document defines the general framework and standard processes for monitoring and assessing risk and implementing responses. Risk assessment will include external/jurisdictional risk monitoring and internal risk monitoring.Responses will be structured as Standard Operational Protocols (SOPs). The categories of Legal and Regulatory Risk Monitoring responses are:• Preventive responses that reduce the likelihood of occurrence of a risk event• Reactive responses that reduce the severity of consequences if the risk event materializes.• Emergency Responses and Contingency Plans.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Public Procurement Framework Legal Resilience - Public Procurement Framework Core This document defines a Public Procurement Framework for contributors and actors involved in the Sky Ecosystem. The purpose is to develop a standard framework that governs the entire lifecycle of service providers, which includes the following processes:• Application process• Selection process (scoring / evaluating proposals or applications)• Hiring and payment process• Performance evaluation and reporting• Terminating involvement and resolving disputes
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Audit Procedure for Atlas Amendments Legal Resilience - Audit Procedure for Atlas Amendments Core This document must define the procedure for performing ex-post legal and technical audits of amended Atlas documents. The general purpose of this procedure is to ensure internal consistency and alignment of the Atlas as a whole.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Technical And Legal Standards Legal Resilience - Technical And Legal Standards Core This document defines the required technical-legal standards and tools such as, but not limited to, legal agreements (A.2.8), templates, and legal structures required to perform specific functions or roles in the Sky Ecosystem. The general purpose of this framework is to minimize trust assumptions and dependencies on specific actors, minimize personal exposure, and increase the accountability and predictability in their behavior.
A.2.9 - Legal Resilience - Code And Asset Licenses Legal Resilience - Code And Asset Licenses Core Ecosystem Actors should generally release code and assets under the Apache 2.0 license, unless there are specific and clear reasons to use a different license, as determined by the Support Facilitators.The Support Facilitators must ensure that a Foundation and other appropriate legal entities exists to properly protect intellectual property and trademarks related to the Sky Ecosystem.Such Foundations or other entities must over time be set up to follow instructions from Sky Governance.All Ecosystem Actors must take steps to protect the brands and trademarks relevant to the Sky Ecosystem, and in doing so must follow guidelines and best practice defined by the Foundations related to Trademarks, Code and Asset licenses.
A.2.10 - A1 - Resilience Research And Preparedness Resilience Research And Preparedness Section The Support Scope is responsible for conducting ongoing resilience and preparedness research.
A.2.10 - Resilience Research And Preparedness - Role Of Support Facilitators Resilience Research And Preparedness - Role Of Support Facilitators Core The Support Facilitators must ensure that resilience research and preparedness efforts are continuously maintained to ensure the ecosystem is well-positioned to handle any legal uncertainty or risk that should arise. These projects must generally be broadly diversified across all jurisdictions where the Sky Ecosystem could be directly or indirectly exposed, but efforts and resources must be prioritized towards jurisdictions where risks are more likely to emerge.
A.2.10 - Resilience Research And Preparedness - Budget Resilience Research And Preparedness - Budget Core The Resilience Research and Preparedness budget is specified in A.2.10 - Resilience Research And Preparedness - Budget - Current Budget. The Support Facilitators can trigger a payout from the budget to a relevant recipient address through a Governance Poll.
A.2.10 - Resilience Research And Preparedness - Budget - Current Budget Resilience Research And Preparedness - Budget - Current Budget Core The Resilience Research and Preparedness budget is• Up to 2,000,000 USDS available per year.The full amount is immediately available at the start of the calendar year.
A.2.10 - Resilience Research And Preparedness - Research Objectives Resilience Research And Preparedness - Research Objectives Core Resilience Research and Preparedness (also "Resilience Research") projects must fulfill at least one of the following objectives:• Bootstrap necessary infrastructure to develop one of the high-order legal resilience objectives as defined in this Article: ◦ Legal Defense ◦ Legal Risk Management ◦ Privacy and Operational Security ◦ Advocacy and Public Policy ◦ Legal and Regulatory Risk Monitoring ◦ Public Procurement Framework ◦ Atlas Amendment and Audit ◦ Technical and Legal Standards• Design and implement processes that contribute directly to one of the high-order legal resilience objectives defined in this Article.• Implement specific preventive or reactive legal risk mitigation tools.• Execute specific activities or tasks necessary to fulfill one of the high-order legal resilience objectives defined in this Article.
A.2.10 - Resilience Research And Preparedness - Application Process Resilience Research And Preparedness - Application Process Core Ecosystem Actors can apply for a Resilience Research Project by submitting a proposal to be processed by the Support Scope. To submit a Resilience Research Proposal, the Ecosystem Actor must make a post on the Sky Forum following the template provided in A.2.10 - Resilience Research And Preparedness - Application Process - Application Template and comply with all requirements described in the subdocuments herein.
A.2.10 - Resilience Research And Preparedness - Application Process - Costs And Benefits Resilience Research And Preparedness - Application Process - Costs And Benefits Core Resilience Research Proposals must provide a clear and detailed account of both direct and indirect costs, as well as the anticipated results and benefits in relation to the Resilience Research Objectives.
A.2.10 - Resilience Research And Preparedness - Application Process - Team Resilience Research And Preparedness - Application Process - Team Core Resilience Research Proposals must detail their headcount, team skillset composition, and reliance on third parties.
A.2.10 - Resilience Research And Preparedness - Application Process - Timeline And Milestones Resilience Research And Preparedness - Application Process - Timeline And Milestones Core Resilience Research Proposals must provide a clear timeline with detailed, granular milestones and the KPIs to review at each milestone.
A.2.10 - Resilience Research And Preparedness - Application Process - Risk Mitigation Impact Resilience Research And Preparedness - Application Process - Risk Mitigation Impact Core Resilience Research Proposals must justify how the project will mitigate a specific risk or help bootstrap resources necessary to improve legal resilience.
A.2.10 - Resilience Research And Preparedness - Application Process - Application Template Resilience Research And Preparedness - Application Process - Application Template Core Applications for Resilience Research projects must follow this template:• .x: [Project Name]• .x.1: [Project Abstract: In 3-5 sentences, what problem are you trying to solve?]• .x.2: [Objectives: What are you hoping to accomplish? How do you define and measure success for this project?]• .x.3: [Outcomes: How does this project benefit the Sky Ecosystem? How does this project help fulfill one of the Legal Resilience Objectives in A.2.9]• .x.4: [Scope: What will you research/build /design/implement? What is the expected output?]• .x.5: [Project Team: How many people are working on this project? Please list their names and roles for the project and how many hours per month each person will work on this project?]• .x.6: [Background: Relevant links, reference to other projects or research papers]• .x.7: [Methodology: How do you plan to achieve your objectives?]• .x.8: [Timeline: Please include a brief explanation of the milestones/roadmap, along with expected deliverables and KPIs.]• .x.9: [Budget: Requested grant amount and how this will be used. Please provide the requested amount and outline how the funds will be used.]
A.2.10 - Resilience Research And Preparedness - Review Process Resilience Research And Preparedness - Review Process Core The Support Facilitators must ensure the highest quality Research Proposals are thoroughly reviewed. The Support Facilitators should document their application evaluations and publish these in the Sky Forum prior to triggering a governance vote to fund a proposal.
A.2.10 - Resilience Research And Preparedness - Review Process - Budget Availability Resilience Research And Preparedness - Review Process - Budget Availability Core Proposals should only be reviewed if there is an available budget in the Resilience Research and Preparedness budget.
A.2.10 - Resilience Research And Preparedness - Review Process - Factors To Consider Resilience Research And Preparedness - Review Process - Factors To Consider Core Multiple factors should be considered holistically when reviewing Resilience Research Proposals, including the amount of remaining budget, the potential impact on the Resilience Research Objectives, and, whether the Resilience Research Proposals help improve legal resilience as described in A.2.9.
A.2.10 - Resilience Research And Preparedness - Review Process - Approval Process Resilience Research And Preparedness - Review Process - Approval Process Core Resilience Research Projects require different approval processes depending on the total cost of the project. Projects with a total cost under 15,000 USDS can be directly approved by the Support Facilitator. Projects with a total cost above 15,000 USDS will require a vote on the Weekly Governance Cycle, which can be triggered by the Support Facilitator.
A.2.10 - Resilience Research And Preparedness - Review Process - Active Projects Resilience Research And Preparedness - Review Process - Active Projects Core There are currently no active resilience research projects.
A.2.11 - A1 - Ecosystem Security Infrastructure Ecosystem Security Infrastructure Section This Section manages Sky Ecosystem security infrastructure and initiatives.
A.2.11 - Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure Core As one of the most important DeFi protocols with a high TVL, the Sky Protocol is a honeypot for hackers and other nefarious actors. The Sky Protocol must always be protected by an active Bug Bounty Program. This document regulates the budget and processes of the Bug Bounty Program, which serves to protect the Sky Protocol and its users from hacks and exploits. The Bug Bounty Program is conducted on the Immunefi platform.
A.2.11 - Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Introduction Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Introduction Core The Bug Bounty Program aims to create incentives for hackers to contribute to the resilience of the Sky Protocol as opposed to exploiting vulnerabilties for personal gain. Immunefi is the party responsible for conducting the Bug Bounty Program; its setup and operations are based on standards set by Immunefi. The Sky Ecosystem must continue to maintain a Bug Bounty Program for SparkLend until the launch of the Spark Agent.
A.2.11 - Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Scope Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Scope Core The subdocuments herein describe the scope of the Sky Bug Bounty Program, which currently includes both Sky Protocol and Spark Protocol.
A.2.11 - Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Assets In Scope Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Assets In Scope Core The Assets In Scope of the Sky Core Bug Bounty Program will be those identified as critical infrastructure for the Sky Ecosystem.For Sky Core, the Assets In Scope accepted for this Bug Bounty Program are specified on Sky's listing on the Immunefi platform, which can be found at (https://immunefi.com/bounty/makerdao/). Assets in Scope include smart contracts, frontend applications, data infrastructure and oracles.For SparkLend, the Assets In Scope for the Bug Bounty Program is specified on SparkLend's listing on the Immunefi platform, which can be found at (https://immunefi.com/bounty/sparklend/). For SparkLend, the Assets In Scope only include smart contracts.The Support Facilitator is responsible for maintaining these lists of Assets In Scope, in consultation with the relevant stakeholders.
A.2.11 - Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Severity Classification Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Severity Classification Core The Immunefi Vulnerability Severity Classification System (https://immunefi.com/severity-updated/) is applicable to both Sky Core and SparkLend. The Support Facilitator is authorized to adopt a new severity system for the Bug Bounty Programs in consultation with relevant technical stakeholders.
A.2.11 - Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Impacts In Scope Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Impacts In Scope Core For Sky Core, the Impacts In Scope accepted for the Bug Bounty Program is specified on Sky's listing on the Immunefi platform, which can be found at (https://immunefi.com/bounty/makerdao/). The impacts are categorized into 'smart contract' and 'websites and applications.'For SparkLend, the Impacts In Scope for the Bug Bounty Program is specified on SparkLend's listing on the Immunefi platform, which can be found at (https://immunefi.com/bounty/sparklend/).
A.2.11 - Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Out Of Scope Vulnerabilities And Other Limitations Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Out Of Scope Vulnerabilities And Other Limitations Core A selection of vulnerabilities is deemed out of scope for the Bug Bounty Program. An overview of these out of scope vulnerabilities can be found on Sky's listing on the Immunefi platform (https://immunefi.com/bounty/makerdao/). Feasibility limitations also apply, which can be found in the aforementioned listing on the Immunefi website.Specific rules applying to the Bug Bounty Program can be found at the website above, listed under the following categories:• Repeatable attack limitations• Restrictions on security researcher eligibility• Public disclosure of known issues• Proof of Concept (PoC) requirements• Other terms and information• Prohibited activitiesFor SparkLend, the rules, terms, and exceptions can be found on SparkLend's listing on the Immunefi platform (https://immunefi.com/bounty/sparklend/).
A.2.11 - Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Rewards Terms And Conditions Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Rewards Terms And Conditions Core The subelements herein describe the Bug Bounty Program's terms and conditions for rewards.
A.2.11 - Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Rewards For Smart Contract Vulnerabilities Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Rewards For Smart Contract Vulnerabilities Core The Rewards per Threat Level for Smart Contract Vulnerabilities, including related terms, conditions and exceptions, are specified in Sky's listing on the Immunefi platform (https://immunefi.com/bounty/makerdao/).For SparkLend, the Rewards per Threat Level for Smart Contract Vulnerabilities, including related terms, conditions and exceptions, are specified on SparkLend's listing on the Immunefi platform (https://immunefi.com/bounty/sparklend/).
A.2.11 - Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Rewards For Website And Application Vulnerabilities Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Rewards For Website And Application Vulnerabilities Core The Rewards per Threat Level for Website and Application Vulnerabilities, including related terms, conditions and exceptions, are specified in Sky's listing on the Immunefi platform (https://immunefi.com/bounty/makerdao/).
A.2.11 - Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Rewards Payment Terms Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Rewards Payment Terms Core The subelements herein describe the payment terms for the Bug Bounty Program for Sky Critical Infrastructure.
A.2.11 - Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Rewards Denomination Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Rewards Denomination Core Payments are denominated in USD. However, payouts are done in USDS assuming a full 1:1 ratio with the USD. However, if the price of USDS deviates from the USD value by more than 1%, the amount of USDS will be adjusted.
A.2.11 - Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Rewards Payout Process Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Rewards Payout Process Core All bounty payouts are handled by Sky Governance. Upon confirmation, bug bounty payouts should be included in the next possible Executive Vote. This would involve sending USDS directly from the protocol's buffer to the whitehat hacker.Immunefi will publicly contact one of the Governance Facilitators with the request, including a specification of the respective vulnerability report, the requested amount and the Ethereum mainnet addresses of the beneficiaries. This should also include the payment details of the Immunefi fee, if it applies. Immunefi and the Sky Governance Facilitators should make sure the payout is made within one full calendar month after the report was approved.For Bug Bounty rewards over USD 1,000,000: after the first million is paid out, the remaining amount is paid out over time with up to USD 1,000,000 per consecutive month until the determined amount for payout is reached.
A.2.11 - Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Rewards Budget Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Rewards Budget Core The Bug Bounty Programs incur fixed and variable costs.• Variable costs: Bug bounty payouts including related fees to Immunefi are considered variable costs and are covered by the process described in A.2.11 - Ecosystem Security Infrastructure - Bug Bounty Program For Critical Infrastructure - Rewards Payment Terms.• Fixed costs: Fixed costs comprise service fees for the Immunefi Premium Triaging Service, and compensation of a part-time Bug Bounty program steward. These costs are funded by the Launch Project budget, as specified in A.5.9 - Launch Project - Budget.
A.2.12 - A1 - Purpose System - Funding Purpose System - Funding Section This Section must define the elements and infrastructure necessary to implement the Purpose System effectively. This includes establishing a process for allocating purpose funds to individual Agents.
A.2.12 - A2 - Purpose System - Direct And Specific Impact Solutions Purpose System - Direct And Specific Impact Solutions Section At all times, at least 10% of the Purpose System funds must be used for more direct and specific impact solutions.
A.3.1 - A1 - Scope Improvement Scope Improvement Section To ensure continuous improvement of the Stability Scope, the Stability Facilitators may retain Scope Advisors, experts with relevant domain expertise. The Stability Scope Advisors shall take on projects identified by the Stability Facilitators. The Scope Advisors will serve under the terms and conditions set forth in an agreement to be negotiated by the Stability Facilitators and each Scope Advisor, which agreement shall be publicly disclosed.
A.3.1 - Scope Improvement - Scope Advisor Requirements Scope Improvement - Scope Advisor Requirements Core Stability Scope Advisors must be Ecosystem Actors who have no involvement in any business, political, or governance-related activities that could create a conflict of interest, either directly or indirectly. Additionally, they must possess the relevant expertise and professional skills necessary to provide informed and objective input on the specific content areas covered by the Stability Scope.
A.3.1 - Scope Improvement - Scope Advisor Requirements - BA Labs Conflict Of Interest Waiver Scope Improvement - Scope Advisor Requirements - BA Labs Conflict Of Interest Waiver Core BA Labs is granted a limited waiver to the rule prohibiting Stability Scope Advisors from engaging in other business activities that could result in a conflict of interest. This waiver applies only to BA Labs' work with Ethena. This waiver provides Sky with greater transparency and responsiveness in the event of any issue with Ethena. It also allows BA Labs to align Ethena's risk strategy with Sky.However, should additional Stability Scope Advisors be appointed, they will be required to assume full responsibility for all risk management activities associated with Ethena.
A.3.1 - Scope Improvement - Current Scope Advisors Scope Improvement - Current Scope Advisors Core The currently active Scope Advisors are: BA LabsETH Address: 0xDfe08A40054685E205Ed527014899d1EDe49B892
A.3.2 - A1 - Core Stability Parameters - Role Of Core Executor Agents Core Stability Parameters - Role Of Core Executor Agents Section This Section defines the role of the Core Executor Agents in managing the Core Stability Parameters.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Role Of Core Executor Agents - Setting Base Rate Core Stability Parameters - Role Of Core Executor Agents - Setting Base Rate Core The Core Executor Agents, in consultation with the Stability Facilitators and the Stability Scope Advisors, must set the Base Rate to ensure (1) a sufficient level of Cash Stablecoins and (2) price stability of USDS and other Stablecoins produced by the Sky Ecosystem. The subdocuments herein define the process that the Core Executor Agents should follow in setting the Base Rate.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Role Of Core Executor Agents - Setting Base Rate - Adjustment Process Core Stability Parameters - Role Of Core Executor Agents - Setting Base Rate - Adjustment Process Core The Core Executor Agents should modify the Base Rate on a daily basis, as necessary, in consultation with the Stability Facilitators and Stability Scope Advisors. In doing so, the Core Executor Agents should consider the factors specified in the documents herein.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Role Of Core Executor Agents - Setting Base Rate - Adjustment Process - Level Of Actively Stabilizing Collateral Core Stability Parameters - Role Of Core Executor Agents - Setting Base Rate - Adjustment Process - Level Of Actively Stabilizing Collateral Core The Core Executor Agents should consider the level of Actively Stabilizing Collateral (see A.3.4 - Actively Stabilizing Collateral) using the following non-binding guidelines:
  • If total ASC is above 30%, consider decreasing the Base Rate by approximately 2%;
  • If total ASC is between 28% and 30%, consider decreasing the Base Rate by approximately 1%;
  • If total ASC is between 26% and 28%, consider decreasing the Base Rate by approximately 0.3%;
  • If total ASC is between 24% and 26%, consider maintaining the Base Rate at approximately its current level;
  • If total ASC is between 22% and 24%, consider increasing the Base Rate by approximately 0.3%;
  • If total ASC is between 20% and 22%, consider increasing the Base Rate by approximately 1%; and
  • If total ASC is below 20%, consider increasing the Base Rate by approximately 2%.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Role Of Core Executor Agents - Setting Base Rates - External Rate Environment Core Stability Parameters - Role Of Core Executor Agents - Setting Base Rates - External Rate Environment Core The Core Executor Agents should consider the external interest-rate environment, including the interest rates offered by competitors and funding rates in decentralized finance and traditional finance markets.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Role Of Core Executor Agents - Setting Base Rates - External Rate Environment - Tools Development Core Stability Parameters - Role Of Core Executor Agents - Setting Base Rates - External Rate Environment - Tools Development Core The Core Executor Agents must develop automated tools to monitor the external interest-rate environment to improve the rate-setting process.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Role Of Core Executor Agents - Setting Base Rate - Other Factors Core Stability Parameters - Role Of Core Executor Agents - Setting Base Rate - Other Factors Core The Core Executor Agents should consider other factors such as supporting long-term market stability, user stability, system sustainability, and growth. In addition, the Core Executor Agents should consider constraints on Stars, including their cost of capital and reaction time, to avoid creating unnecessary volatility in rates.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Role Of Core Executor Agents - Setting Other Core Stability Parameters Core Stability Parameters - Role Of Core Executor Agents - Setting Other Core Stability Parameters Core When setting the Base Rate, the Core Executor Agents must also set all other Core Stability Parameters so that they maintain their specified relationship to the Base Rate. See A.3.2 - A2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters. The only exception is the Dai Savings Rate, which must be gradually reduced to 0% as specified in A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Dai Savings Rate - Dai Savings Rate Modification.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Role Of Core Executor Agents - Implementation Of Rate Changes Core Stability Parameters - Role Of Core Executor Agents - Implementation Of Rate Changes Core The smart contracts that implement all of the Core Stability Parameters must be configured to allow the Core Executor Agents to modify the Core Stability Parameters using the Stability Parameter Bounded External Access Module. See A.3.9 - Measures For Endgame Transition - Stability Parameter Bounded External Access Module.
A.3.2 - A2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters Core Stability Parameters - Parameters Section This Section defines the Core Stability Parameters.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Base Rate Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Base Rate Core The Base Rate is the key interest rate in the system. It defines all other rates by various spreads. It is expressed as an annual percentage rate.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Sky Savings Rate Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Sky Savings Rate Core The Sky Savings Rate ("SSR") is the rate USDS holders can earn on their USDS in the Sky Savings Rate smart contracts.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Sky Savings Rate - Relationship To Base Rate Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Sky Savings Rate - Relationship To Base Rate Core The Sky Savings Rate is 0.25% below the Base Rate. This difference is equal to the sum of (1) the 0.1% Accessibility Reward Fee (see A.2.4 - Fee For USDS and sUSDS Balances), (2) the 0.1% Star Agent Management Fee (see A.2.4 - Star Agent Management Fee), and (3) the 0.05% Sky Spread (see A.3.3 - Sky Spread).
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Sky Savings Rate - Sky Savings Rate Modification Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Sky Savings Rate - Sky Savings Rate Modification Core The Sky Savings Rate can be modified through either Executive Votes or the Stability Parameter Bounded External Access Module. See A.3.9 - Measures For Endgame Transition - Stability Parameter Bounded External Access Module.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Sky Savings Rate - Sky Savings Rate Modification - Sky Savings Rate Stability Parameter Bounded External Access Module Parameters Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Sky Savings Rate - Sky Savings Rate Modification - Sky Savings Rate Stability Parameter Bounded External Access Module Parameters Core The Stability Parameter Bounded External Access Module parameters for the Sky Savings Rate are:
  • max - 3,000 basis points
  • min - 200 basis points
  • step - 400 basis points
  • tau - Globally defined in A.3.9 - Measures For Endgame Transition - Stability Parameter Bounded External Access Module - Definitions - Tau Definition - Tau Current Value.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Rate Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Rate Core The Agent Rate is the rate that Star Agents earn on unrewarded USDS, Dai, and sUSDS balances that they hold.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Rate - Relationship To Base Rate Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Rate - Relationship To Base Rate Core The Agent Rate is 0.05% below the Base Rate. This is equal to the Sky Savings Rate plus (1) the 0.1% Accessibility Reward Fee (see A.2.4 - Fee For USDS and sUSDS Balances) and (2) the 0.1% Star Agent Management Fee (see A.2.4 - Star Agent Management Fee).
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Rate - Treatment Of USDS and Dai Balances Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Rate - Treatment Of USDS and Dai Balances Core Star Agents receive the full Agent Rate on unrewarded USDS and Dai balances through the Monthly Settlement Cycle, as specified in A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Rate - Settlement.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Rate - Treatment Of sUSDS Balances Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Rate - Treatment Of sUSDS Balances Core Star Agents receive the Agent Rate on sUSDS balances in a modified form. sUSDS balances already earn the Sky Savings Rate. In addition to this, sUSDS balances earn additional compensation of 0.20% to account for the 0.1% Accessibility Reward Fee (see A.2.4 - Fee For USDS and sUSDS Balances) and the 0.1% Star Agent Management Fee (see A.2.4 - Star Agent Management Fee) that is paid through the Monthly Settlement Cycle, as specified in A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Rate - Settlement.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Agent Rate - Spark Core Stability Parameters - Agent Rate - Spark Core Spark is entitled to a higher Agent Rate equal to the Base Rate on USDS and sUSDS balances held in Peg Stability Modules. See A.3.4 - Peg Stability Module. The Agent Rate earned by Spark is still subject to the limitations set forth in A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Rate - Limitations For Star Agents Receiving Subsidized Rate.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Rate - Limitations For Star Agents Receiving Subsidized Rate Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Rate - Limitations For Star Agents Receiving Subsidized Rate Core If a Star Agent is borrowing funds from Sky at a Subsidized Rate, as defined in A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Credit Line Borrow Rate - Subsidized Rate, then the Agent Rate earned by that Star Agent shall be limited. Specifically, if the standard Agent Rate would exceed the Star Agent's Subsidized Rate, the Star Agent will earn the Subsidized Rate on those balances. The difference between what would have been the standard Agent Rate earnings and the earnings at the Subsidized Rate is effectively retained by Sky. This adjustment is processed as part of the Monthly Settlement Cycle, as specified in A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Rate - Settlement. If the standard Agent Rate is less than or equal to the Subsidized Rate, the standard Agent Rate applies.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Rate - Settlement Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Rate - Settlement Core Any compensation due to or from Star Agents so that they earn the Agent Rate on USDS, Dai, and sUSDS balances is paid as part of the Monthly Settlement Cycle. See A.2.6.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Dai Savings Rate Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Dai Savings Rate Core The Dai Savings Rate ("DSR") is the rate Dai holders can earn on their Dai in the Dai Savings Rate smart contracts.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Dai Savings Rate - Dai Savings Rate Modification Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Dai Savings Rate - Dai Savings Rate Modification Core The Dai Savings Rate can be modified through either Executive Votes or the Stability Parameter Bounded External Access Module. See A.3.9 - Measures For Endgame Transition - Stability Parameter Bounded External Access Module. The Dai Savings Rate must gradually be reduced to 0% over time.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Dai Savings Rate - Dai Savings Rate Modification - Dai Savings Rate Stability Parameter Bounded External Access Module Parameters Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Dai Savings Rate - Dai Savings Rate Modification - Dai Savings Rate Stability Parameter Bounded External Access Module Parameters Core The Stability Parameter Bounded External Access Module parameters for the Dai Savings Rate are:
  • max - 3,000 basis points
  • min - 0 basis points
  • step - 400 basis points
  • tau - Globally defined in A.3.9 - Measures For Endgame Transition - Stability Parameter Bounded External Access Module - Definitions - Tau Definition - Tau Current Value.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Credit Line Borrow Rate Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Credit Line Borrow Rate Core The Agent Credit Line Borrow Rate is the annual percentage rate that Agents must pay to Sky Core to receive USDS liquidity into their respective vaults.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Credit Line Borrow Rate - Relationship To Base Rate Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Credit Line Borrow Rate - Relationship To Base Rate Core The Agent Credit Line Borrow Rate is equal to the Base Rate.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Credit Line Borrow Rate - Subsidized Rate Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Credit Line Borrow Rate - Subsidized Rate Core Star Agents may temporarily be able to borrow specified amounts from Sky Core at a Subsidized Rate below the Base Rate under the terms of an Ecosystem Accord entered into between Sky and the Star Agent.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Credit Line Borrow Rate - Accrued Interest Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Credit Line Borrow Rate - Accrued Interest Core Funds must be regularly transferred from the SubProxy account of each Star Agent borrowing from Sky Core to the Allocation Vault for the Star Agent so that the Allocation Vault only reflects the principal balance as of the date of transfer. Any accrued interest that has not yet been transferred from the SubProxy account must be deducted from the Star Agent's Total Risk Capital. See A.3.3 - Total Risk Capital Definition.
A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Credit Line Borrow Rate - Star Agent Credit Rating System Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Agent Credit Line Borrow Rate - Star Agent Credit Rating System Core After the development of a Star Agent Credit Rating System, the Agent Credit Line Borrow Rate will vary based on the Credit Rating of each Star Agent. The Credit Rating for a Star Agent will take into account factors including the Risk Tolerance Ratio.
A.3.3 - A1 - Conceptual Framework Conceptual Framework Section This Section defines the conceptual framework for Risk Capital.
A.3.3 - Required Risk Capital Required Risk Capital Core The documents herein define the conceptual framework for determining the Aggregate Required Risk Capital (RRC) that Star Agents are required to hold to protect Sky from risks on their investments.
A.3.3 - Aggregate RRC Aggregate RRC Core The Aggregate RRC that a Star Agent must maintain is equal to the sum of the Instance Total RRC for each Active Instance of the Allocation System Primitive that the Star Agent has deployed.
A.3.3 - Instance Total RRC Instance Total RRC Core The Instance Total RRC for an Instance is equal to the sum of the Instance Financial RRC, Instance Smart Contract Risk RRC, and Instance Admin Risk RRC for that Instance. See A.3.3 - Instance Financial RRC, A.3.3 - Instance Smart Contract RRC, and A.3.3 - Instance Admin RRC.
A.3.3 - Application To Real World Assets Application To Real World Assets Core Investments in Real World Assets, as defined in A.3.3 - Real World Assets, automatically have Instance Smart Contract RRC and Instance Admin RRC of zero. An additional type of Legal RRC, reflecting the unique risks of these assets, will be incorporated in future iterations of the risk framework.
A.3.3 - Incorporation Of Additional Types Of RRC Incorporation Of Additional Types Of RRC Core Additional types of RRC reflecting other risk factors, including legal risk and oracle risk, will be incorporated in future iterations of the risk framework.
A.3.3 - Instance Financial RRC Instance Financial RRC Core The documents herein define the conceptual framework for determining the Instance Financial RRC required to protect Sky from financial risk arising from an Instance of the Allocation System Primitive.
A.3.3 - Introduction Introduction Core The conceptual framework for financial risk is designed to ensure that Star Agents hold sufficient capital to cover potential losses on their investments in case of an extreme market event. The financial risk framework is based on the Basel Accords developed by the Committee on Bank Supervision, including Basel II, Basel III, and Basel IV. These frameworks are then adapted to reflect the differences between traditional finance and decentralized finance.
A.3.3 - Financial Risk Categories Financial Risk Categories Core Financial risk can be divided into three categories, as specified in the documents herein. These categories of risk are interrelated, so Instance Financial RRC is not directly associated with these risk categories. Instead, risk models are developed for different asset classes, as specified in A.3.3 - Financial Risk Models. The development of each of these risk models is informed by considerations regarding how each of the financial risk categories impacts the specific asset.
A.3.3 - Credit Risk Credit Risk Core Credit risk is the risk that a loan or other debt instrument will not be repaid according to agreed terms.
A.3.3 - Market Risk Market Risk Core Market risk is the risk that a financial asset will decline in value due to market conditions or changes in investor perceptions of the asset.
A.3.3 - Liquidity Risk Liquidity Risk Core Liquidity risk is the risk that an asset cannot be sold quickly enough, or in sufficient quantity, at its fair market value without causing a significant price impact.
A.3.3 - Financial Risk Models Financial Risk Models Core The conceptual framework for financial risk is implemented through asset class specific risk models. The documents herein define the asset classes that risk models exist or are being developed for, including the high level approach and examples of relevant assets. Investments may only be made using the Allocation System if they are covered by one of the Financial Risk models herein.
A.3.3 - Fully Implemented Risk Models Fully Implemented Risk Models Core The documents herein define fully implemented asset-class-specific risk models.
A.3.3 - Lending Markets Lending Markets Core The model for lending markets focuses on Credit Risk by incorporating asset volatility and liquidity factors. This model can be applied to lending markets such as SparkLend, Aave, Morpho, Fluid, and Maple. The implementation of the model for lending markets is specified in A.3.3 - Lending Markets.
A.3.3 - Pending Risk Models Pending Risk Models Core The documents herein define pending asset-class-specific risk models along with near-term Instance Financial RRC Ratios to be used until the models are fully implemented.
A.3.3 - Perpetual Positions Perpetual Positions Core The model for perpetual positions uses a modified Credit Risk model to evaluate the risk of tokenized delta-neutral positions, such as Ethena and Resolv. The implementation of the model for perpetual positions will be specified in a future iteration of the Atlas.
A.3.3 - Near Term Treatment Near Term Treatment Core In the near term pending development of the implementation of the model for perpetual positions, the following Instance Financial RRC Ratios will apply:
  • Direct Ethena exposure - 5% Instance Financial RRC Ratio
  • Indirect Ethena exposure through Morpho - 3% Instance Financial RRC Ratio
  • All other protocols - 4% Instance Financial RRC Ratio
A.3.3 - Direct Exposures Direct Exposures Core The model for direct exposures combines Market Risk and Liquidity Risk to evaluate the risk of direct asset holdings of volatile cryptoassets, such as ETH, stETH, and WBTC. The implementation of the model for direct exposures will be specified in a future iteration of the Atlas.
A.3.3 - Near Term Treatment Near Term Treatment Core In the near term pending development of the implementation of the model for direct exposures, a 25% Instance Financial RRC Ratio will be applied to all direct exposures. In the near term, direct exposures will be considered to be any assets held idle in a wallet controlled by a Star Agent.
A.3.3 - Bond-Like Instruments Bond-Like Instruments Core The model for bond-like instruments uses a modified Credit Risk model to evaluate the risk of cryptoassets with duration risk, such as Pendle's PT-tokens. The implementation of the model for bond-like instruments will be specified in a future iteration of the Atlas.
A.3.3 - Near Term Treatment Near Term Treatment Core In the near term pending development of the implementation of the model for bond-like exposures, a 4% Instance Financial RRC Ratio will be applied to all bond-like exposures. In the near term, only Pendle PT tokens will be eligible for investment under this provision.
A.3.3 - Real World Assets Real World Assets Core The model for Real World Assets is based on direct application of existing frameworks to evaluate the risk of tokenized Real World Assets, such as BUIDL, JTRSY, and USTB. The implementation of the model for Real World Assets will be specified in a future iteration of the Atlas.
A.3.3 - Near Term Treatment Near Term Treatment Core In the near term pending development of the implementation of the model for Real World Assets, a 0% Instance Financial RRC Ratio will be applied to Real World Assets. In the near term, only BUIDL, JTRSY, and USTB will be eligible for investment under this provision.
A.3.3 - Cash Stablecoins Cash Stablecoins Core The model for Cash Stablecoins is based on identifying stablecoins, such as USDC and USDT, that do not present significant Market Risk, Credit Risk, or Liquidity Risk. The implementation of the model for Cash Stablecoins will be specified in a future iteration of the Atlas.
A.3.3 - Near Term Treatment Near Term Treatment Core In the near term pending development of the implementation of the model for Cash Stablecoins, a 0% Instance Financial RRC will be applied to Cash Stablecoins. In the near term, only USDS, sUSDS, Dai, sDai, USDC, and USDT (either held directly or through decentralized exchanges such as Curve) will be eligible for investment under this provision.
A.3.3 - Instance Smart Contract RRC Instance Smart Contract RRC Core The documents herein define the conceptual framework for determining the Instance Smart Contract RRC required to protect Sky from smart contract risk arising from an Instance of the Allocation System Primitive.
A.3.3 - Definition Definition Core Smart Contract Risk refers to the risk that an investment through the Allocation System will experience a loss of funds due to a bug or technical exploit. This risk may arise from the protocol invested in or other aspects of the investment such as bridging requirements.
A.3.3 - Risk Rating Risk Rating Core The determination of Smart Contract Risk should initially be based on an evaluation of the risk that the investment could experience losses due to a bug or technical exploit. This determination should take into account factors such as (1) the technical complexity of the code base (e.g. cyclomatic complexity, decision points, number of external calls, lines of code), (2) the number, quality, and recency of audits, and (3) the "Lindiness" of the relevant smart contracts.
A.3.3 - Required Risk Capital Required Risk Capital Core The risk of a technical exploit in one protocol is unlikely to be correlated with the risk of a technical exploit in an unrelated protocol. Therefore, the risks from small exposures to even relatively risky protocols are likely to be diversified away. In contrast, very large exposures to even relatively safe protocols can create a risk to a Star Agent and potentially to Sky itself if there is a technical exploit, especially if multiple Star Agents have the same exposure. To account for this, the calculation of Instance Smart Contract RRC should take into account the risk rating, the level of exposure of the Star, and the level of exposure of the Sky Ecosystem.
A.3.3 - Implementation Implementation Core The implementation of the calculation of Instance Smart Contract RRC is specified in A.3.3 - Instance Smart Contract RRC Implementation.
A.3.3 - Instance Admin RRC Instance Admin RRC Core The documents herein define the conceptual framework for determining the Instance Admin RRC required to protect Sky from admin risk arising from an Instance of the Allocation System Primitive.
A.3.3 - Definition Definition Core Admin Risk refers to the risk that an investment through the Allocation System will experience a loss of funds due to abuse of privileged access to a protocol. This risk may arise from a multisig or another actor that has the ability to modify the protocol or access funds without going through a governance process.
A.3.3 - Risk Rating Risk Rating Core The determination of Admin Risk should initially be based on an evaluation of the risk that an investment could experience losses due to an abuse of privileged access. This determination should take into account factors such as (1) the level of privileged access that exists, (2) the security delay that such access is subject to, and (3) the "Lindiness" of the system.
A.3.3 - Required Risk Capital Required Risk Capital Core The risk of an abuse of privileged access in one protocol is unlikely to be correlated with the risk of an abuse of privileged access in an unrelated protocol. Therefore, the risks from small exposures to even relatively risky protocols are likely to be diversified away. In contrast, very large exposures to even relatively safe protocols can create a risk to a Star Agent and potentially to Sky itself if there is an abuse of privileged access, especially if multiple Star Agents have the same exposure. To account for this, the calculation of Instance Admin RRC should take into account the risk rating, the level of exposure of the Star, and the level of exposure of the Sky Ecosystem.
A.3.3 - Implementation Implementation Core The implementation of the calculation of Instance Admin RRC is specified in A.3.3 - Instance Administrative RRC Calculation.
A.3.3 - Total Risk Capital Total Risk Capital Core The documents herein define the conceptual framework for types of capital that contribute to a Star Agent's Total Risk Capital (TRC). Star Agents must maintain at all times a level of TRC that exceeds their Aggregate RRC or be subject to penalties.
A.3.3 - Total Risk Capital Definition Total Risk Capital Definition Core Total Risk Capital is capital that is currently eligible, available, and verifiably under the Star's control. For capital to be included in a Star Agent's TRC, it must be currently deployable towards covering its Required Risk Capital obligations. Consequently, in-flight capital (e.g., assets being bridged) does not contribute towards a Star's TRC. Similarly, commitments for future capital, such as Ecosystem Accords for renting Star-External Junior Risk Capital (SEJRC) or Tokenized External Junior Risk Capital (TEJRC) that have been agreed upon by counterparties but are not yet formally codified within the Atlas, cannot contribute towards a Star's TRC until such formalization is complete.
A.3.3 - Types Of Risk Capital Types Of Risk Capital Core TRC comprises two categories based on loss absorption seniority: Junior Risk Capital (JRC) and Senior Risk Capital (SRC), further divided by source.
A.3.3 - Junior Risk Capital Junior Risk Capital Core Junior Risk Capital (JRC) is the first capital to absorb losses on investments under the Allocation System. Junior Risk Capital must experience 100% losses before any losses are absorbed by Senior Risk Capital.
A.3.3 - Junior Risk Capital Types Junior Risk Capital Types Core The documents herein define the types of Junior Risk Capital.
A.3.3 - Internal Junior Risk Capital (IJRC) Internal Junior Risk Capital (IJRC) Core

Internal Junior Risk Capital is capital owned by the Star Agent itself. It serves as the foundation for the Star's risk capacity: the amount of IJRC directly dictates the maximum External JRC the Star can source (governed by the External Per Internal ratio) and provides the primary capacity for enabling Senior Risk Capital (via the Senior Per Junior ratio), while also bearing the initial impact of any losses (the Tip JRC mechanism). IJRC must be eligible assets held in the Star Agent's designated treasury account (e.g., SubProxy), controlled by the Star's root governance.

See A.3.3 - External Per Internal Ratio, A.3.3 - Senior Per Junior Ratio, and A.3.3 - JRC Loss Allocation Rules.
A.3.3 - Types Of Eligible Assets For IJRC Types Of Eligible Assets For IJRC Core

The documents herein define the types of assets that qualify as Internal Junior Risk Capital.

These types will be specified in a future iteration of the Risk Framework.
A.3.3 - Star-External Junior Risk Capital (SEJRC) Star-External Junior Risk Capital (SEJRC) Core SEJRC is JRC rented from another Star Agent via the A.2.4 - Junior Risk Capital Rental Primitive. The capital remains in the lender's treasury but counts towards the borrower's JRC amount. SEJRC is represented by a registered Ecosystem Accord signifying that a specified amount of the lending Agent's JRC (held within the lender's treasury) is designated to count towards the borrowing Agent's JRC requirement for the duration and terms specified in the Accord.
A.3.3 - Tokenized External Junior Risk Capital (TEJRC) Tokenized External Junior Risk Capital (TEJRC) Core Tokenized External Junior Risk Capital is capital provided by external capital providers depositing sUSDS into the Tokenized External Junior Risk Capital smart contract, from which Stars can encumber funds. The details of this contract will be specified in a future iteration of the Atlas.
A.3.3 - JRC Loss Allocation Rules JRC Loss Allocation Rules Core This document defines the conceptual framework for distributing losses within the JRC layer.
A.3.3 - Initial Loss Absorption By "Tip JRC" Initial Loss Absorption By "Tip JRC" Core

The Tip JRC mechanism dictates that losses from a distinct risk event are first absorbed entirely by the Star Agent's Internal Junior Risk Capital (IJRC), up to a specific threshold amount. This threshold amount is calculated as a percentage of Total JRC and is specified in A.3.3 - JRC Loss Allocation Parameters.

Only losses exceeding this threshold amount trigger absorption by other Junior Risk Capital components - specifically, the remaining IJRC and External Junior Risk Capital. This initial absorption solely by IJRC ensures that Star Agents are highly incentivized to prevent losses and avoids the need to resolve disputes regarding the allocation of small losses to EJRC providers.
A.3.3 - Post-Tip JRC Loss Allocation Post-Tip JRC Loss Allocation Core If a loss event exceeds the Tip JRC amount, the remaining loss is allocated pro-rata across the rest of the JRC capital. This includes the remaining Internal Junior Risk Capital (Total IJRC minus the Tip amount) and all External Junior Risk Capital (Star External Junior Risk Capital plus Tokenized External Junior Risk Capital).
A.3.3 - Per-Event Basis Per-Event Basis Core

The JRC loss allocation rules are applied independently based on the total losses attributed to each distinct risk event. The concept of "per-event basis" is crucial; the classification of a distinct risk event (classifying losses as one large event versus multiple smaller ones) can dictate whether the Tip JRC threshold is breached.

Breaching the threshold activates the pro-rata sharing mechanism for any losses exceeding the Tip JRC amount, distributing such excess losses between both the remaining Internal JRC (IJRC) and all External JRC (EJRC). Conversely, if the threshold is not breached for an event, the loss is contained entirely within the Tip layer and absorbed solely by IJRC.

The operational process for the determination of distinct risk events will be defined in a future iteration of the Atlas.
A.3.3 - Senior Risk Capital Senior Risk Capital Core

Senior Risk Capital (SRC) is protected from losses relative to Junior Risk Capital. Senior Risk Capital only begins to absorb losses after Junior Risk Capital has experienced 100% losses and absorbs 100% of losses thereafter.

Senior Risk Capital can be originated from Sky Core on a monthly basis as part of the Monthly Settlement Cycle; Star Agents can also rent Senior Risk Capital from each other.
A.3.3 - Senior Risk Capital Types Senior Risk Capital Types Core The documents herein define the types of Senior Risk Capital.
A.3.3 - Internal Senior Risk Capital Internal Senior Risk Capital Core Internal Senior Risk Capital (ISRC) is capital provided from Sky Core's Surplus Buffer. The composition of Internal Senior Risk Capital will be specified in more detail in a future iteration of the Atlas.
A.3.3 - External Senior Risk Capital External Senior Risk Capital Core External Senior Risk Capital (ESRC) is capital provided from the srUSDS smart contract, which allow users to provide USDS to Sky Core to serve as senior risk capital in exchange for higher returns. The mechanics of this are specified in A.3.3 - External Senior Risk Capital And srUSDS System.
A.3.3 - Total Risk Capital Sourcing Ratios Total Risk Capital Sourcing Ratios Core The documents herein define the required relationship and constraints between the different types of Total Risk Capital. These ensure that the Star Agent maintains the appropriate level of Internal Junior Risk Capital relative to its External and Senior capital exposures, ensuring sufficient "skin in the game" with respect to its investments.
A.3.3 - Definition Of Ratios Definition Of Ratios Core The documents herein define the Total Risk Capital sourcing ratios.
A.3.3 - External Per Internal Ratio External Per Internal Ratio Core The External Per Internal (EPI) ratio determines the maximum amount of External Junior Risk Capital (SEJRC and TEJRC combined) that a Star Agent can source directly based on its held Internal Junior Risk Capital (IJRC). This acts as the primary constraint ensuring a baseline level of the Star's own capital backs its external JRC sourcing. The required External Per Internal ratio is specified in A.3.3 - External Per Internal (EPI) Ratio Value.
A.3.3 - Senior Per Junior Ratio Senior Per Junior Ratio Core

The Senior Per Junior (SPJ) ratio defines the effectiveness of each type of Junior Risk Capital (IJRC, SEJRC, TEJRC) in supporting Senior Risk Capital (SRC). Specifically, it quantifies how many units of SRC (whether Originated or Rented) can be activated or "enabled" per unit of a given JRC type.

A Star Agent's overall "SPJ capacity" is calculated by summing the potential enablement contributed by each type of JRC it holds (IJRC, SEJRC or TEJRC), where each contribution equals the amount of that JRC type multiplied by its specific SPJ ratio.

Since SRC only absorbs losses after JRC is depleted, the SPJ enablement mechanism validates that sufficient JRC backing exists, allowing enabled SRC to be counted as part of the Star Agent's total eligible Risk Capital. Therefore, a Star Agent might hold a certain amount of OSRC or rented SRC, but only the portion that is successfully "enabled" by its JRC according to the SPJ ratios is accounted by the system as eligible capital contributing towards the Star's satisfaction of its Required Risk Capital. The required ratio of Senior Per Junior is specified in A.3.3 - Senior Per Junior (SPJ) Ratio Values.
A.3.3 - Alternative Use Of SPJ Capacity To Source External Junior Risk Capital Alternative Use Of SPJ Capacity To Source External Junior Risk Capital Core

A Star Agent may optionally choose to deploy all or some portion of its calculated SPJ capacity not to enable Senior Risk Capital, but instead to source additional External Junior Risk Capital. This provides a secondary mechanism to increase the total JRC potentially beyond the amount initially constrained by the EPI ratio applied solely to IJRC.

Crucially, the EJRC tranche acquired through utilizing SPJ capacity is permanently accounted for as having an SPJ ratio of zero (0). It contributes to the JRC buffer but provides no capacity itself for enabling SRC in any subsequent calculations. This contrasts with EJRC sourced normally via the EPI ratio, which retains its standard SPJ capacity.
A.3.3 - Interaction Between Ratios And SPJ Capacity Interaction Between Ratios And SPJ Capacity Core

The sourcing of External Junior Risk Capital and enablement of Senior Risk Capital involves a sequential application of the Risk Capital sourcing ratios in conjunction with the Star Agent's deployment of its SPJ capacity.

First, the EPI ratio sets the initial limit for sourcing standard, SPJ-bearing EJRC based solely on the Star Agent's IJRC.Second, the total SPJ capacity is calculated from the Star Agent's resulting JRC pool (IJRC + any EPI-sourced EJRC).

Finally, this total calculated SPJ capacity can be allocated by the Star Agent to enable SRC (standard use), and/or to source additional, non-SPJ-bearing EJRC using the mechanism described under A.3.3 - Alternative Use Of SPJ Capacity To Source External Junior Risk Capital. Any specific portion of the total SPJ capacity allocated towards sourcing EJRC cannot simultaneously be allocated towards enabling SRC.
A.3.3 - A2 - Implementation Implementation Section This Section defines the current implementation of the Risk Capital framework.
A.3.3 - Required Risk Capital Calculation Implementation Required Risk Capital Calculation Implementation Core The documents herein define the implementation of the risk framework for calculating required Total Instance RRC.
A.3.3 - Instance Financial RRC Implementation Instance Financial RRC Implementation Core The documents herein define the implementation of the risk framework for calculating Instance Financial RRC.
A.3.3 - Asset Class Specific Implementation Asset Class Specific Implementation Core The documents herein define the calculation of Instance Financial RRC for specific asset classes. In the near term, the only implementation that is defined is for lending markets. In the future additional implementations will be added herein.
A.3.3 - Lending Markets Lending Markets Core The documents herein define the calculation of Instance Financial RRC for lending markets.
A.3.3 - Process For Calculating Instance Financial RRC Process For Calculating Instance Financial RRC Core The documents herein define the process for calculating Instance Financial RRC for lending markets.
A.3.3 - Calculate Probability Of Default Calculate Probability Of Default Core

The first step is calculating the Probability Of Default $PD$. $PD$ is calculated using the following formula:

$$\text{PD} = N(-d_1) + N(-d_2) \left( \frac{\sum_{i=1}^n \text{LT}i V_0^i}{\sum{j=1}^m D_0^j} \right)^{-2a}$$

Here $N$ is the normal cumulative probability distribution function.

The parameters of this formula are specified in the subdocuments herein.
A.3.3 - Leverage Adjusted Drift To Risk Ratio Leverage Adjusted Drift To Risk Ratio Core

The Leverage Adjusted Drift To Risk Ratio $a$ is calculated as follows:

$$a = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^n w_U^i (r_c^i + r_s^i) - \sum_{j=1}^m w_D^j (r_d^j + r_s^j) + \rho_{UD} \sigma_U \sigma_D - \sigma_U^2}{\sigma_U^2 + \sigma_D^2 - 2 \rho_{UD} \sigma_U \sigma_D}$$
A.3.3 - Distance To Default Distance To Default Core

The Distance To Default $d_1$ is calculated using the following formula:

$$d_1 = \frac{\ln\left( \frac{\sum_{i=1}^n \text{LT}i V_0^i}{\sum{j=1}^m D_0^j} \right) + \left( \sum_{i=1}^n w_U^i (r_c^i + r_s^i) - \sum_{j=1}^m w_D^j (r_d^j + r_s^j) + \rho_{UD} \sigma_U \sigma_D - \sigma_U^2 \right) T}{\sqrt{\sigma_U^2 + \sigma_D^2 - 2 \rho_{UD} \sigma_U \sigma_D} \sqrt{T}}$$
A.3.3 - Downward Adjusted Distance To Default Downward Adjusted Distance To Default Core

The Downward Adjusted Distance To Default $d_2$ is calculated using the following formula:

$$d_2 = \frac{\ln\left( \frac{\sum_{i=1}^n \text{LT}i V_0^i}{\sum{j=1}^m D_0^j} \right) - \left( \sum_{i=1}^n w_U^i (r_c^i + r_s^i) - \sum_{j=1}^m w_D^j (r_d^j + r_s^j)+ \rho_{UD} \sigma_U \sigma_D - \sigma_U^2 \right) T}{\sqrt{\sigma_U^2 + \sigma_D^2 - 2 \rho_{UD} \sigma_U \sigma_D} \sqrt{T}}$$
A.3.3 - Total Variance Of Underlying Asset Portfolio Total Variance Of Underlying Asset Portfolio Core

The Total Variance Of Underlying Asset Portfolio $\sigma_U^2$ is calculated using the following formula:

$$\sigma_U^2 = \sum_{i,k=1}^n w_U^i w_U^k \sigma_V^i \sigma_V^k \rho_{V,ik}$$
A.3.3 - Total Variance Of Debt Portfolio Total Variance Of Debt Portfolio Core

The Total Variance Of Debt Portfolio $\sigma_D^2$ is calculated using the following formula:

$$\sigma_D^2 = \sum_{j,l=1}^m w_D^j w_D^l \sigma_D^j \sigma_D^l \rho_{D,jl}$$
A.3.3 - Correlation Between Asset Portfolio And Debt Portfolio Correlation Between Asset Portfolio And Debt Portfolio Core

The Correlation Between Asset Portfolio And Debt Portfolio $\rho_{UD}$ is calculated using the following formula:

$$\rho_{UD} = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^n \sum_{j=1}^m w_U^i w_D^j \sigma_V^i \sigma_D^j \rho_{VD,ij}}{\sqrt{\sigma_U^2 \sigma_D^2}}$$
A.3.3 - Weight Of Asset In Underlying Asset Portfolio Weight Of Asset In Underlying Asset Portfolio Core

The weight of asset $i$ in the underlying asset portfolio $w_U^i$ is calculated using the following formula:

$$w_U^i = \frac{\text{LT}i V_0^i}{\sum{k=1}^n \text{LT}_k V_0^k}$$
A.3.3 - Weight Of Debt Instrument In Debt Portfolio Weight Of Debt Instrument In Debt Portfolio Core

The weight of debt instrument $j$ in the debt portfolio $w_D^j$ is calculated using the following formula:

$$w_D^j = \frac{D_0^j}{\sum_{l=1}^m D_0^l}$$
A.3.3 - Return On Asset Return On Asset Core The Return On Asset $r_c^i$ of an asset $i$ is the yield earned for supplying the asset in the lending market.
A.3.3 - Asset Yield Asset Yield Core The Asset Yield $r_s^i$ of an asset $i$ is the income yield of the asset and would include any dividends or interest paid by the asset and/or asset issuer, including staking rewards for yield-bearing assets.
A.3.3 - Cost Of Debt Cost Of Debt Core The Cost Of Debt $r_d^j$ of a debt instrument $j$ is the interest rate on the debt.
A.3.3 - Debt Yield Debt Yield Core The Debt Yield $r_s^j$ of a debt instrument $j$ is the income yield on the debt asset. It includes any dividends or interest paid by the debt asset and/or debt asset issuer, including staking rewards for yield-bearing debt assets.
A.3.3 - Correlation Coefficient Correlation Coefficient Core The correlation coefficient $\rho$ between two instruments is the correlation of block-weighted log returns of those assets over the last 365 days. In the documents herein, the correlation coefficient is followed by subscripts indicating the relevant instruments. For example, $\rho_{UD}$ is the correlation between the underlying asset portfolio $U$ and the debt portfolio $D$ as specified in A.3.3 - Correlation Between Asset Portfolio And Debt Portfolio. The subscript may begin with $V$ or $D$ to indicate whether the relevant instruments are part of the asset portfolio or debt portfolio. For example, $\rho_{VD,ij}$ is the correlation coefficient between the asset $i$ and the debt instrument $j$.
A.3.3 - Loan To Value Ratio Loan To Value Ratio Core

The Loan To Value Ratio $LT_i$ of an asset $i$ is the ratio of the debt backed by an asset to the value of the asset backing it:

$$LT_i = \frac{D_0^i}{V_0^i}$$
