A.3.3 - Asset Value Asset Value Core The Asset Value $V_0^i$ of an asset $i$ is the market value of that asset.
A.3.3 - Debt Value Debt Value Core The Debt Value $D_0^i$ of a debt instrument is the notional value of the debt.
A.3.3 - Time Horizon Time Horizon Core The Time Horizon $T$ is the time horizon in years over which the Probability Of Default is being estimated. The value of the $T$ parameter is 1.
A.3.3 - Calculate Loss Given Default Calculate Loss Given Default Core

The second step is calculating the Loss Given Default $LGD$. $LGD$ is calculated using the following formula:

$$LGD = min(1 - \frac{(1 - LP) * (1 - S)}{LT}, 0)$$

Here $min$ is the mathematical minimum function that returns the lower of the two specified parameters.

The parameters of this formula are specified in the subdocuments herein. All of these parameters should be specified as decimal numbers. For example, 3% should be specified as 0.03.
A.3.3 - Liquidation Penalty Liquidation Penalty Core The Liquidation Penalty $LP$ is the contractually agreed upon liquidation penalty if the asset is liquidated to satisfy the debt.
A.3.3 - Slippage Slippage Core The Slippage $S$ is the estimated slippage for liquidating the entire position in one block.
A.3.3 - Liquidation Threshold Liquidation Threshold Core The Liquidation Threshold $LT$ is the value of the debt as a percentage of the collateral value at which the lender may liquidate the collateral to satisfy the debt.
A.3.3 - Calculate Asset Correlation Coefficient Calculate Asset Correlation Coefficient Core

The third step is to calculate the Asset Correlation Coefficient $R$. $R$ is calculated as follows:

$$R = a \times \left(1 - e^{-K \times PD}\right) + b \times \left(1 - \left(1 - e^{-K \times PD}\right)\right)

$$Here $e$ is the base of the natural logarithm.

The parameters of this formula are specified in the subdocuments herein.
A.3.3 - Lower Bound Lower Bound Core The Lower Bound $a$ is an estimate of the correlation between assets during "calm" periods. It is set of 0.13.
A.3.3 - Upper Bound Upper Bound Core The Upper Bound $b$ is an estimate of the correlation between assets during "stressful" market environments. It is set to 0.33.
A.3.3 - Sensitivity Coefficient Sensitivity Coefficient Core The Sensitivity Factor K is a tuning parameter indicating how quickly the correlations transition between $a$ and $b$. It is set to 10.
A.3.3 - Calculate Capital Requirement Without Buffers Calculate Capital Requirement Without Buffers Core

The fourth step is to calculate the Capital Requirement Without Buffers $K$. $K$ is calculated as follows:

$$K = \left[ LGD \times N\left( \frac{N^{-1}(PD) + \sqrt{R} \cdot N^{-1}(0.999)}{\sqrt{1-R}} \right) - PD \times LGD \right]$$

Here $N$ is the cumulative normal probability distribution function and $N^{-1}$ is the inverse cumulative normal probability distribution function.
A.3.3 - Calculate Required Risk Capital Calculate Required Risk Capital Core

The final step is to calculate the Instance Financial RRC $RRC$. $RRC$ is calculated as follows:

$$\text{RRC} = K \times \frac{1}{CR} \times \text{EAD} \times \text{ECR}$$

The parameters of this formula are specified in the subdocuments herein.
A.3.3 - Capital Ratio Capital Ratio Core The Capital Ratio $CR$ is the capital ratio without additional buffers. It is set to 8.75%.
A.3.3 - Exposure At Default Exposure At Default Core The Exposure At Default $EAD$ is the total amount of funds from the Allocation System that have been deployed into the decentralized lending protocol.
A.3.3 - Effective Capital Ratio Effective Capital Ratio Core The Effective Capital Ratio $ECR$ is the capital ratio included additional capital buffers established by Sky Governance as part of the Risk Framework. There are currently no additional capital buffers so the $ECR$ is equal to the $CR$, which is 8.75%.
A.3.3 - Covered Protocols Covered Protocols Core The calculation of Instance Financial RRC for lending markets is applicable to the following protocols:
  • Aave v2
  • Aave v3
  • SparkLend
  • Morpho
  • Maple
The application by a Star Agent of the risk framework for lending markets to any protocols not listed above must be approved by its Operational Executor Agent. The Operational Executor shall consult with the Stability Scope Advisors and the Stability Facilitators in making this determination. Any such approval must be posted to the Sky Forum under the tag for the Star Agent.
A.3.3 - Exceptions Exceptions Core The documents herein define exceptions to the calculation of Instance Financial RRC for specific lending protocols.
A.3.3 - Maple Maple Core Because Maple accepts Native BTC and Native SOL as collateral, alternative Slippage parameters should be used for these collaterals. See A.3.3 - Slippage. The alternative Slippage parameters to be used are specified in the documents herein.
A.3.3 - Native BTC Slippage Parameters Native BTC Slippage Parameters Core

The Slippage for a Native BTC exposure is calculated as half the Slippage for an ETH exposure of the same USD amount:

$$\text{slippage}{btc} = \frac{\text{slippage}{eth} }{2}$$

For example, if the Slippage for a $40M ETH exposure is 2% then the Slippage for a $40M Native BTC exposure would be 1%.
A.3.3 - Native SOL Slippage Parameters Native SOL Slippage Parameters Core

The Slippage for a Native SOL exposure is calculated as double the Slippage for an ETH exposure of the same USD amount:

$$\text{slippage}{sol} = 2 \times \text{slippage}{eth}$$

For example, if the Slippage for a $40M ETH exposure is 2% then the Slippage for a $40M Native SOL exposure would be 4%.
A.3.3 - Fluid Fluid Core The Instance Financial RRC Ratio for Fluid is 3%.
A.3.3 - Reference Implementation Reference Implementation Core

A reference implementation of the calculation of Instance Financial RRC for lending markets is included herein.


              import math
              from collections import defaultdict
              import numpy as np
              from scipy.stats import norm

              # Constants
              RISK_FREE_RATE = 0.04 # SOFR
              TIME_HORIZON = 1 # 1 year

              class FinancialRRCModel:
                def __init__(self):
                  # For demo purposes, we hardcode a dummy correlation map
                  self.token_correlation_map = {
                    'TOKENA': {'TOKENB': 0.5},
                    'TOKENB': {'TOKENA': 0.5},
                  }

                def _calculate_effective_volatility(self, list_1, list_2):
                  """
                    Calculate the effective variance between two sets of positions.
                  """
                  effective_variance = 0.0
                  for sym1, pos1 in list_1.items():
                    for sym2, pos2 in list_2.items():
                      if sym1 == sym2:
                        corr = 1.0
                      else:
                        corr = self.token_correlation_map.get(sym1, {}).get(sym2, 
                               self.token_correlation_map.get(sym2, {}).get(sym1, 0.0))
                      effective_variance += (
                        pos1["share"]
                        * pos2["share"]
                        * pos1["volatility_30d"]
                        * pos2["volatility_30d"]
                        * corr
                      )
                  return effective_variance

                def _estimate_rrc_for_position(self, wallet_data):
                  """
                    Estimate the required-risk capital (RRC) for a given wallet_data dict.
                  """
                  # 1) compute effective volatilities
                  var_coll = self._calculate_effective_volatility(
                    wallet_data["collateral_positions"],
                    wallet_data["collateral_positions"],
                  )
                  var_debt = self._calculate_effective_volatility(
                    wallet_data["debt_positions"],
                    wallet_data["debt_positions"],
                  )
                  vol_coll = math.sqrt(var_coll)
                  vol_debt = math.sqrt(var_debt)

                  # 2) correlation collateral↔debt
                  cov_cd = self._calculate_effective_volatility(
                    wallet_data["collateral_positions"],
                    wallet_data["debt_positions"],
                  )
                  corr_cd = cov_cd / (vol_coll * vol_debt) if vol_coll * vol_debt > 0 else 0.0

                  # 3) drift terms
                  eff_coll_rate = sum(p["share"] * p["supply_apy_30d"]
                                      for p in wallet_data["collateral_positions"].values())
                  eff_borrow_rate = sum(p["share"] * p["borrow_apy_30d"]
                                      for p in wallet_data["debt_positions"].values())
                  eff_stake_rate = sum(p["share"] * p["staking_apy_30d"]
                                      for p in wallet_data["collateral_positions"].values())

                  drift_cd = (
                      eff_coll_rate + eff_stake_rate - eff_borrow_rate + (var_debt - var_coll) / 2
                  )

                  vol_cd = math.sqrt(
                    max(var_coll + var_debt - 2 * corr_cd * vol_coll * vol_debt, 0)
                  )

                  # 4) Black-Cox inputs
                  a = (drift_cd - vol_cd**2 / 2) / (vol_cd**2) if vol_cd > 0 else 0.0
                  L = wallet_data["collateral_usd_lt"]
                  D = wallet_data["debt_usd"]
                  log_term = math.log(L / D) if L > 0 and D > 0 else float("-inf")
                  denom = vol_cd * math.sqrt(TIME_HORIZON) if vol_cd > 0 else 1e-10

                  d1 = (log_term + (drift_cd - vol_cd**2/2) * TIME_HORIZON) / denom
                  d2 = (log_term - (drift_cd - vol_cd**2/2) * TIME_HORIZON) / denom

                  # 5) Probability of Default
                  try:
                    pd = (
                        norm.cdf(-d1)
                        + norm.cdf(-d2) * (L / D) ** (-2 * a)
                    )
                  except OverflowError:
                    pd = 1.0
                  pd = max(0.0, min(pd, 1.0))

                  # 6) Loss Given Default
                  recovery = sum(
                    p["share"] * (1 - p["liquidation_penalty"]) * (1 - p["slippage"]) / p["liquidation_threshold"]
                    for p in wallet_data["collateral_positions"].values()
                  )
                  lgd = max(0.0, min(1 - recovery, 1.0))

                  # 7) Exposure at Default
                  ead = sum(
                    debt["debt_usd"] * math.exp((RISK_FREE_RATE + debt["borrow_apy_30d"]) * TIME_HORIZON)
                    for debt in wallet_data["debt_positions"].values()
                  )

                  # 8) Asset Correlation Coefficient
                  a_acc, b_acc, c_acc = 0.13, 10, 0.33
                  exp_term = math.exp(-b_acc * pd)
                  acc = a_acc * (1 - exp_term)/(1-math.exp(-b_acc)) + c_acc*(1 - (1-exp_term)/(1-math.exp(-b_acc)))

                  # 9) Credit risk weight
                  default_threshold = (
                    norm.ppf(max(pd, 1e-10)) + math.sqrt(acc) * norm.ppf(0.999) ) / math.sqrt(1 - acc)
                    credit_risk = max(lgd * norm.cdf(default_threshold) - lgd * pd, 0)

                  # 10) RRC
                  rrc = credit_risk * ead
                  return rrc

              # -------- DEMO USAGE --------
              if __name__ == "__main__":
                # 1) Build a dummy wallet_data structure
                wallet_data = {
                  "collateral_positions": {
                    "TOKENA": {
                      "share": 0.6,
                      "volatility_30d": 0.2,
                      "supply_apy_30d": 0.05,
                      "staking_apy_30d": 0.02,
                      "liquidation_penalty": 0.1,
                      "liquidation_threshold": 0.8,
                      "slippage": 0.01,
                    },
                    "TOKENB": {
                      "share": 0.4,
                      "volatility_30d": 0.25,
                      "supply_apy_30d": 0.04,
                      "staking_apy_30d": 0.015,
                      "liquidation_penalty": 0.12,
                      "liquidation_threshold": 0.85,
                      "slippage": 0.015,
                    },
                  },
                  "debt_positions": {
                    "TOKENA": {
                      "share": 0.7,
                      "volatility_30d": 0.2,
                      "borrow_apy_30d": 0.06,
                      "debt_usd": 100_000,
                    },
                    "TOKENB": {
                      "share": 0.3,
                      "volatility_30d": 0.25,
                      "borrow_apy_30d": 0.07,
                      "debt_usd": 50_000,
                    },
                  },
                  "collateral_usd_lt": 200_000,
                  "debt_usd": 150_000,
                }

                # 2) Instantiate and run
                model = FinancialRRCModel()
                rrc = model._estimate_rrc_for_position(wallet_data)
                print(f"Estimated Required Risk Capital (RRC): ${rrc:,.2f}")
A.3.3 - Instance Smart Contract RRC Implementation Instance Smart Contract RRC Implementation Core The documents herein define the implementation of the risk framework for calculating Instance Smart Contract RRC.
A.3.3 - Defining Relevant Smart Contracts Defining Relevant Smart Contracts Core The first step in calculating Instance Smart Contract RRC with respect to an Allocation System opportunity is to identify the set of relevant smart contracts for the opportunity.
A.3.3 - Identifying Exposure Contracts Identifying Exposure Contracts Core First, all relevant smart contracts must be identified. Relevant smart contracts are those that are critical for the project being invested in, including core business logic, vaults, token contracts, and proxy implementations.
A.3.3 - Reliance On External Sources Reliance On External Sources Core External sources such as third party data providers, security consultants, and project documentation may be used to help identify relevant smart contracts. However, the Star Agent deploying funds from the Collateral Portfolio into the opportunity retains overall responsibility for the reasonableness of identifying the relevant smart contracts.
A.3.3 - Locating Verified Code Locating Verified Code Core Second, the source code for each relevant contract must be obtained. The source code should be obtained for the deployed version of the contract using an appropriate block explorer (e.g. Etherscan for Ethereum Mainnet or L2s). The source code should include any dependencies or inherited library contracts that are part of the live system.
A.3.3 - Smart Contract Risk Rating Calculation Smart Contract Risk Rating Calculation Core

The second step in calculating the Instance Smart Contract RRC with respect to an Allocation System opportunity is to calculate the Smart Contract Risk Rating $SCRR$ for the covered smart contracts identified in A.3.3 - Defining Relevant Smart Contracts. The $SCRR$ is calculated as follows:

$$\text{SCRR} = min[\text{CAP}, (\text{SR} + \text{CCR}) \times \text{LAF} \times {AAF}]

$$Here $min$ is the mathematical minimum function that returns the lesser of the specified parameters.

The parameters of this formula are specified in the subdocuments herein.
A.3.3 - Smart Contract Risk Rating Cap Smart Contract Risk Rating Cap Core The Smart Contract Risk Rating Cap $\text{CAP}$ is a temporary cap on the Smart Contract Risk Rating. The value of the $CAP$ is 30.
A.3.3 - Starting Rate Starting Rate Core The Starting Rate $SR$ is an arbitrary starting risk rating for protocols. The value of the $SR$ is 25.
A.3.3 - Code Complexity Rating Code Complexity Rating Core

The Code Complexity Rate $CCR$ is a measure of the complexity of the code of the smart contracts used by the protocol. The $CCR$ is calculated as follows:

$$CCR = \text{CCRMax} \times min(1, \frac{\text{RawCCR} + 1}{\text{CCRUpperBound} + 1})$$

Here the $min$ function is the mathematical minimum function that returns the lesser of the specified parameters.

The parameters of this formula are specified in the subdocuments herein.
A.3.3 - Code Complexity Rating Maximum Code Complexity Rating Maximum Core The Code Complexity Rating Maximum $\text{CCRMax}$ is the maximum Code Complexity Rating for a protocol. The $\text{CCRMax}$ is set to 75.
A.3.3 - Code Complexity Rating Upper Bound Code Complexity Rating Upper Bound Core The Code Complexity Rating Upper Bound $\text{CCRUpperBound}$ is an arbitrary factor to normalize the Raw Code Complexity Rating. The $\text{CCRUpperBound}$ is set to 8,500.
A.3.3 - Raw Code Complexity Rating Raw Code Complexity Rating Core

The Raw Code Complexity Rating $\text{RawCCR}$ is an unnormalized measure of the complexity of the code of the smart contracts that implement the protocol. The $\text{RawCCR}$ is calculated as follows:

$$\text{RawCCR}=(\text{TCC} \times \text{CCweight}) + (\text{TDP} \times \text{DPweight}) + (\text{TEC} \times \text{ECweight}) + (\text{ID} \times \text{IDweight}) + (\frac{\text{CS}}{\text{CSfactor}} \times \text{CSweight})$$

The parameters of this formula are specified in the subdocuments herein.
A.3.3 - Total Cyclomatic Complexity Total Cyclomatic Complexity Core Cyclomatic complexity measures the number of independent execution paths through a unit of code. The total cyclomatic complexity score is the sum of the cyclomatic complexity of each of the covered smart contracts.
A.3.3 - Cyclomatic Complexity Weight Cyclomatic Complexity Weight Core The Cyclomatic Complexity Weight $\text{CCweight}$ is a weighting factor indicating the relative importance of the Total Cyclomatic Complexity versus other factors. It is set to 1.
A.3.3 - Total Decision Points Total Decision Points Core Decision points measure the number of branching points where conditional logic is applied. The Total Decision Points are the total number of Decision Points in all functions in the covered smart contracts.
A.3.3 - Decision Points Weight Decision Points Weight Core The Decision Points Weight $\text{DPweight}$ is a weighting factor indicating the relative importance of the Total Decision Points versus other factors. It is set to 0.5.
A.3.3 - Total External Calls Total External Calls Core Total External Calls is the count of all external calls (e.g. call, delegatecall) made in the covered smart contracts.
A.3.3 - External Calls Weight External Calls Weight Core The External Calls Weight $\text{ECweight}$ is a weighting factor indicating the relative importance of the Total External Calls versus other factors. It is set to 1.5.
A.3.3 - Inheritance Depth Inheritance Depth Core Inheritance Depth is the maximum number of inheritance levels in any contract in the covered contracts.
A.3.3 - Inheritance Depth Weight Inheritance Depth Weight Core The Inheritance Depth Weight $\text{IDweight}$ is a weighting factor indicating the relative importance of the Inheritance Depth versus other factors. It is set to 5.
A.3.3 - Code Size Code Size Core Code Size is the total number of lines of code in the covered contracts, excluding tests and documentation.
A.3.3 - Code Size Factor Code Size Factor Core The Code Size Factory is an arbitrary factor to normalize the Code Size relative to other parameters. It is set to 1,000.
A.3.3 - Code Size Weight Code Size Weight Core The Code Size Weight $\text{CSweight}$ is a weighting factor indicating the relative importance of the Code Size versus other factors. It is set to 1.
A.3.3 - Lindy Adjustment Factor Lindy Adjustment Factor Core

The Lindy Adjustment Factor $\text{LAF}$ is a measure of the "Lindiness" of the smart contracts and is based on the idea that vulnerable smart contracts with large TVL for a significant period of time would have already been hacked. Therefore, protocols with a greater time integrated TVL are safer, all other things equal, than protocols with a lower time integrated TVL. The $\text{LAF}$ is calculated as follows:

$$\text{LAF} = max(0, 1 - \frac{ln(1 + \lambda \times \text{AGEeff})}{ln(1 + \lambda \times \text{max})})$$

Here $max$ is the mathematical maximum function that returns the greater of the specified parameters and $ln$ is the natural logarithm.

The parameters of this formula are specified in the subdocuments herein.
A.3.3 - Decay Factor Decay Factor Core The Decay Factor $lambda$ is a tuning parameter that represents an estimate of how quickly the risk of a set of smart contracts decreases as its effective age increases. The value of $lambda$ is set to 0.1.
A.3.3 - Maximum Age Maximum Age Core The Maximum Age $\text{max}$ is the effective age, in months, at which the risk of a set of smart contracts has decayed to zero. The value of $\text{max}$ is set to 60.
A.3.3 - Effective Age Effective Age Core

The Effective Age $\text{AGEeff}$ is the age of the contracts adjusted for the TVL of the contracts. The $\text{AGEeff}$ is calculated as follows:

$$\text{AGEeff}=\text{CA} \times ln(1 + \frac{\text{gmTVL}}{\text{TVLthreshold}})$$

Here $ln$ is the natural logarithm.The parameters of this formula are specified in the subdocuments herein.
A.3.3 - Contract Age Contract Age Core The contract age $\text{CA}$ is the average age, in months, of each of the relevant contracts. The age of each relevant contract should be measured based on the time elapsed between the date the contract was deployed and the date of calculation.
A.3.3 - Geometric Mean Total Value Locked Geometric Mean Total Value Locked Core The Geometric Mean Total Value Locked $\text{gmTVL}$ is the geometric mean of the daily TVL over the contract age.
A.3.3 - Total Value Locked Threshold Total Value Locked Threshold Core The Total Value Locked Threshold $\text{TVLthreshold}$ is a factor used to normalize the Geometric mean Total Value Locked. The $\text{TVLthreshold}$ is set to 100,000,000.
A.3.3 - Audit Adjustment Factor Audit Adjustment Factor Core

The Audit Adjustment Factor ${AAF}$ is a measure of the extent to which security audits reduce the risk of a set of smart contracts by identifying and remediating vulnerabilities before they can be exploited. The ${AAF}$ is calculated as follows:

$$\text{AAF} = \text{AF} \times \text{BaseRisk}$$

The parameters of this formula are specified in the subdocuments herein.
A.3.3 - Base Risk Base Risk Core The Base Risk $\text{BaseRisk}$ is a base risk factor in the absence of any audits. The $\text{BaseRisk}$ is set to 70.
A.3.3 - Audit Factor Audit Factor Core

The Audit Factor $AF$ is a measure of the extent to which the Base Risk is reduced by audits. The $AF$ is calculated as:

$$AF = \Pi{[1 - \text{effAuditValue} \times \text{decayFactor}]}$$

The audit from each audit firm with the highest product of Effective Audit Value and Delay factor should be included in this calculation.

The parameters of this formula are specified in the subdocuments herein.
A.3.3 - Effective Audit Value Effective Audit Value Core

The Effective Audit Value $\text{effAuditValue}$ measures the effectiveness of a single audit in reducing the risk of a set of smart contracts and is a function of the percent of the code covered by the audit and the reputation of the audit firm. The $\text{effAuditValue}$ is calculated as:

$$\text{effAuditValue} = \text{effectivenessCoefficient} \times \text{coverage}$$

The parameters of this formula are specified in the subdocuments herein.
A.3.3 - Coverage Coverage Core

The Coverage $\text{coverage}$ is a measure of the percent of a set of smart contracts that were covered in the scope of an audit. The $\text{coverage}$ is calculated as:

$$\text{coverage} = \frac{\text{LinesOfCodeCovered}}{\text{TotalLinesOfCode}}$$

The parameters of this formula are specified in the subdocuments herein.
A.3.3 - Lines Of Code Covered Lines Of Code Covered Core The Lines Of Code Covered $\text{LinesOfCodeCovered}$ is the number of lines of code of the relevant contracts that were within the scope of the audit, excluding documentation and tests.
A.3.3 - Total Lines Of Code Total Lines Of Code Core The Total Lines Of Code $\text{TotalLinesOfCode}$ is the total number of lines of code of the relevant contracts, excluding documentation and tests.
A.3.3 - Effectiveness Coefficient Effectiveness Coefficient Core The Effectiveness Coefficient $\text{effectivenessCoefficient}$ is a measure of the effectiveness of the particular audit firm and is estimated based on the tier of the audit firm.
A.3.3 - Audit Firm Tiers Audit Firm Tiers Core Audit firms are divided into two tiers: top-tier and mid-tier.
A.3.3 - Top-Tier Effectiveness Coefficient Top-Tier Effectiveness Coefficient Core The Effectiveness Coefficient of a top-tier audit firm is set to 0.8.
A.3.3 - Mid-Tier Effectiveness Coefficient Mid-Tier Effectiveness Coefficient Core The Effectiveness Coefficient of a mid-tier audit firm is set to 0.5.
A.3.3 - Audit Firms By Tier Audit Firms By Tier Core

The subdocuments herein categorize specific audit firms into the top-tier and mid-tier categories. Audits from firms other than the ones specified herein may not be included in the calculation of the Audit Adjustment Factor.

The Protocol Security Workstream Lead must review this categorization on a regular basis and update it as necessary.
A.3.3 - List Of Top-Tier Audit Firms List Of Top-Tier Audit Firms Core The top-tier audit firms are:
  • ChainSecurity
  • OpenZeppelin
  • ConsenSys Diligence
A.3.3 - List Of Mid-Tier Audit Firms List Of Mid-Tier Audit Firms Core The mid-tier audit firms are:
  • Quantstamp
  • SlowMist
  • PeckShield
  • Halborn
  • Certora
  • Hunter Security
  • Omniscia
  • Spearbit
  • yAudit
  • MixBytes
  • Cyfrin
  • SECBIT Labs
  • Bramah Systems
  • Zokyo
  • Guardian Audits
  • Zellic
  • Code4rena
  • Pashov
  • ABDK
  • Decurity
  • OtterSec
  • WatchPug
  • Sigma Prime
  • TrailOfBits
  • Cantina
  • Oxorio
  • Enigma Dark
  • Runtime Verification
  • Pessimistic
  • Solidified
  • StErMi
  • Sherlock
A.3.3 - Decay Factor Decay Factor Core

The Decay Factor $decayFactor$ is a parameter indicating how rapidly the effectiveness of audits in reducing risk decreases over time. The $decayFactor$ is calculated as follows:

$$decayFactor =\begin{cases}1 & \text{if } auditAge \leq 2 \\\frac{10 - auditAge}{8} & \text{if } 2 < auditAge < 10 \\0 & \text{if } auditAge \geq 10\end{cases}$$

The parameter of this formula is specified in the subdocument herein.
A.3.3 - Audit Age Audit Age Core The Audit Age $auditAge$ is the age, in years, of the audit. The age of the audit should be measured based on the time elapsed between the date the audit report was issued and the date of calculation.
A.3.3 - Smart Contract Risk Required Risk Capital Calculation Smart Contract Risk Required Risk Capital Calculation Core The third step in calculating the Instance Smart Contract RRC with respect to an Allocation System opportunity is to calculate the Instance Smart Contract RRC as a function of the Smart Contract Risk Rating.
A.3.3 - Calculation Of Instance Smart Contract RRC Percentage Based on Risk Category Calculation Of Instance Smart Contract RRC Percentage Based on Risk Category Core The methodology used to calculate the Instance Smart Contract RRC as a percentage of the exposure depends on the Risk Rating $r$ of the protocol as specified in the documents herein.
A.3.3 - Low Risk Protocols Low Risk Protocols Core Low risk protocols are ones with a Risk Rating between less than or equal to 25. The methodology for low risk protocols is specified in the documents herein.
A.3.3 - Calculate F1 Parameter Calculate F1 Parameter Core For low risk protocols, the F1 parameter $f_{1}$ should first be calculated using the methodology specified in A.3.3 - F1 Function.
A.3.3 - Calculate Required Capital Percentage Using Piecewise Function With F1 Thresholds Calculate Required Capital Percentage Using Piecewise Function With F1 Thresholds Core The Required Capital Percentage should then be calculated by inputting the F1 parameter calculated in A.3.3 - Calculate F1 Parameter into the Piecewise Function specified in A.3.3 - Piecewise Function using the F1 thresholds specified in A.3.3 - Kink Threshold.
A.3.3 - Medium Risk Protocols Medium Risk Protocols Core Medium risk protocols are ones with a Risk Rating greater than 25 but less than or equal to 50. The methodology for medium risk protocols is specified in the documents herein.
A.3.3 - Calculate F1 Parameter Calculate F1 Parameter Core For medium risk protocols, the F1 parameter $f_{1}$ should first be calculated using the methodology specified in A.3.3 - F1 Function.
A.3.3 - Calculate F2 Parameter Calculate F2 Parameter Core The F2 parameter $f_{2}$ should then be calculated using the methodology specified in A.3.3 - F2 Function.
A.3.3 - Calculate Required Capital Percentage Using F1 Piecewise Function Calculate Required Capital Percentage Using F1 Piecewise Function Core The Required Capital Percentage using the F1 Piecewise Function should then be calculated by inputting the F1 parameter calculated in A.3.3 - Calculate F1 Parameter into the Piecewise Function specified in A.3.3 - Piecewise Function using the F1 thresholds specified in A.3.3 - Kink Threshold.
A.3.3 - Calculate Required Capital Percentage Using F2 Piecewise Function Calculate Required Capital Percentage Using F2 Piecewise Function Core The Required Capital Percentage using the F2 Piecewise Function should then be calculated by inputting the F2 parameter calculated in A.3.3 - Calculate F2 Parameter into the Piecewise Function specified in A.3.3 - Piecewise Function using the F2 thresholds specified in A.3.3 - Maximum Threshold.
A.3.3 - Calculate Blended Average Required Capital Percentage Calculate Blended Average Required Capital Percentage Core

The final Required Capital Percentage $x$ should be calculated as a weighted average of the F1 Required Capital Percentage and the F2 Required Capital Percentage as follows:

$$x = b \times \alpha \times f_2 + (1 - \alpha) \times f_1$$

The parameters of this formula are defined in the subdocuments herein.
A.3.3 - Constant Factor Constant Factor Core The constant factor $b$ is set to 0.15.
A.3.3 - Alpha Alpha Core

Alpha $\alpha$ is a weighting factor indicating how close the Risk Rating is to the threshold for a High Risk Protocol versus the threshold for a Low Risk Protocol. It is calculated as:

$$\alpha = \dfrac{r - 25}{50 - 25}$$

Here $r$ is the Risk Rating of the protocol.
A.3.3 - F1 Required Capital Percentage F1 Required Capital Percentage Core The F1 Required Capital Percentage $f_1$ is the figure calculated as the output of A.3.3 - Calculate Required Capital Percentage Using F1 Piecewise Function.
A.3.3 - F2 Required Capital Percentage F2 Required Capital Percentage Core The F2 Required Capital Percentage $f_2$ is the figure calculated as the output of A.3.3 - Calculate Required Capital Percentage Using F2 Piecewise Function.
A.3.3 - High Risk Protocols High Risk Protocols Core High risk protocols are ones with a Risk Rating greater than 50 but less than or equal to 75. The methodology for high risk protocols is specified in the documents herein.
A.3.3 - Calculate F2 Parameter Calculate F2 Parameter Core For high risk protocols, the F2 parameter $f_{2}$ should first be calculated using the methodology specified in A.3.3 - F2 Function.
A.3.3 - Calculate Required Capital Percentage Using Piecewise Function With F2 Thresholds Calculate Required Capital Percentage Using Piecewise Function With F2 Thresholds Core The Required Capital Percentage should then be calculated by inputting the F2 parameter calculated in A.3.3 - Calculate F2 Parameter into the Piecewise Function specified in A.3.3 - Piecewise Function using the F2 thresholds specified in A.3.3 - Maximum Threshold.
A.3.3 - Extreme Risk Protocols Extreme Risk Protocols Core Extreme risk protocols are ones with a Risk Rating greater than 75. The methodology for extreme risk protocols is specified in the documents herein.
A.3.3 - Maximum Required Risk Capital Percentage Maximum Required Risk Capital Percentage Core For extreme risk protocols, the required capital percentage is automatically set to 100%.
A.3.3 - Calculation Of Instance Smart Contract RRC Value Calculation Of Instance Smart Contract RRC Value Core The Instance Smart Contract RRC is equal to the product of (1) the Instance Smart Contract RRC Percentage calculated from A.3.3 - Calculation Of Instance Smart Contract RRC Percentage Based on Risk Category and (2) the exposure to the Allocation System opportunity.
A.3.3 - Inputs To Instance Smart Contract RRC Calculations Inputs To Instance Smart Contract RRC Calculations Core The documents herein define functions and parameters that are used in multiple parts of the methodology for calculating the Instance Smart Contract RRC based on the Smart Contract Risk Rating specified in A.3.3 - Calculation Of Instance Smart Contract RRC Percentage Based on Risk Category.
A.3.3 - Piecewise Function Piecewise Function Core

The Piecewise Function $RCC(x)$ calculates a percentage risk capital requirement based on an input $x$ and is defined as follows:

$$\text{RCC}(x) =\begin{cases}a & \text{if } x \le x_{\text{start}}, \\[8pt]b \times \dfrac{x - x_{\text{start}}}{x_{\text{kink}} - x_{\text{start}}} & \text{if } x_{\text{start}} < x \le x_{\text{kink}}, \\[8pt]b \;+\; c \;\dfrac{x - x_{\text{kink}}}{x_{\text{max}} - x_{\text{kink}}}& \text{if } x_{\text{kink}} < x < x_{\text{max}}, \\[8pt]d& \text{if } x \ge x_{\text{max}}.\end{cases}$$
A.3.3 - Low Risk Parameter Low Risk Parameter Core The low risk parameter $a$ is the output of the piecewise function when the input is at or below the starting threshold. The $a$ parameter is set to 0.
A.3.3 - Medium Risk Parameter Medium Risk Parameter Core The medium risk parameter $b$ is the output of the piecewise function when the input is equal to the kink threshold. The $b$ parameter is set to 0.25.
A.3.3 - High Risk Parameter High Risk Parameter Core The high risk parameter $c$ is the incremental value above the $b$ parameter that the piecewise function will output when the input is equal to the maximum threshold. The $c$ parameter is set to 0.75.
A.3.3 - Extreme Risk Parameter Extreme Risk Parameter Core The extreme risk parameter $d$ is the output of the piecewise function when the input is equal to or greater than the maximum threshold. The $d$ parameter is set to 1.
A.3.3 - Thresholds Thresholds Core The documents herein define the thresholds for the piecewise function.
A.3.3 - Starting Threshold Starting Threshold Core

The Starting Threshold $x_{\text{start}}$ is calculated as follows:

$$x_{\text{start}}(r) = i \times (r_i - r)$$

Here $r$ is the Risk Rating.

The parameters of this formula are defined in A.3.3 - Threshold Parameters.
A.3.3 - Maximum Threshold Maximum Threshold Core

The Maximum Threshold $x_{\text{max}}$ is calculated as follows:

$$x_{\text{max}}(r) = x_{\text{start}}(r) + i_{max}$$

Here $r$ is the Risk Rating.

The parameters of this formula are defined in A.3.3 - Threshold Parameters.
A.3.3 - Kink Threshold Kink Threshold Core

The Kink Threshold $x_{\text{kink}}$ is calculated as follows:

$$x_{\text{kink}}(r) = x_{\text{start}}(r) \;+\; i_{kink} \times\bigl[\;x_{\text{max}}(r)\;-\;x_{\text{start}}(r)\bigr]$$

Here $r$ is the Risk Rating.

The parameters of this formula are defined in A.3.3 - Threshold Parameters.
A.3.3 - Threshold Parameters Threshold Parameters Core The documents herein define inputs that are used to calculate the Starting Threshold, Maximum Threshold, and Kink Threshold. These parameters differ depending on whether the piecewise function is invoked with F1 threshold parameters or F2 threshold parameters.
A.3.3 - F1 Threshold Parameters F1 Threshold Parameters Core The documents herein define the F1 threshold parameters.
A.3.3 - Rating Point Scaling Coefficient Rating Point Scaling Coefficient Core The value of the Rating Point Scaling Coefficient $i$ is 0.01.
A.3.3 - Reference Inflection Risk Rating Reference Inflection Risk Rating Core The value of the Reference Inflection Risk Rating $r_i$ is 50.
A.3.3 - Maximum Interval Width Maximum Interval Width Core The value of the Maximum Interval Width $i_{max}$ is 0.50.
A.3.3 - Kink Location Fraction Kink Location Fraction Core The value of the Kink Location Fraction $i_{kink}$ is 0.75.
A.3.3 - F2 Threshold Parameters F2 Threshold Parameters Core The documents herein define the F2 threshold parameters.
A.3.3 - Rating Point Scaling Coefficient Rating Point Scaling Coefficient Core The value of the Rating Point Scaling Coefficient $i$ is 0.02.
A.3.3 - Reference Inflection Risk Rating Reference Inflection Risk Rating Core The value of the Reference Inflection Risk Rating $r_i$ is 75.
A.3.3 - Maximum Interval Width Maximum Interval Width Core The value of the Maximum Interval Width $i_{max}$ is 0.50.
A.3.3 - Kink Location Fraction Kink Location Fraction Core The value of the Kink Location Fraction $i_{kink}$ is 0.75.
A.3.3 - F1 And F2 Functions F1 And F2 Functions Core The documents herein define the F1 and F2 functions.
A.3.3 - Variable Definitions Variable Definitions Core The documents herein define variables used in the F1 and F2 functions.
A.3.3 - Internal Exposure Internal Exposure Core The Internal Exposure $e_{\text{int}}$ is the Agent's allocation to the protocol.
A.3.3 - Total Exposure Total Exposure Core The Total Exposure $e_{\text{tot}}$ is the Sky Ecosystem's aggregate allocation to the protocol.
A.3.3 - Internal Liquid Surplus Internal Liquid Surplus Core The Internal Liquid Surplus $s_{\text{liq}}$ is equal to the Total Risk Capital of the Agent.
A.3.3 - Exposure Beyond Surplus Exposure Beyond Surplus Core The Exposure Beyond Surplus $E_{\text{beyond}}$ is the difference between the Sky Ecosystem's aggregate allocation to the protocol and aggregate internal liquid surplus of all Agents.
A.3.3 - Total Collateral Total Collateral Core The Total Collateral $C_{\text{tot}}$ is the total USDS and Dai debt in the system.
A.3.3 - F1 Function F1 Function Core

The F1 parameter $f_{1}$ is calculated as follows:

$$f_{1} = \dfrac{E_{\text{beyond}}}{C_{\text{tot}}}$$

The parameters of this function are defined in A.3.3 - Variable Definitions.
A.3.3 - F2 Function F2 Function Core

The F2 parameter $f_2$ is calculated as follows:

$$f_{2} = \dfrac{e_{\text{int}} + a \,\bigl(e_{\text{tot}} - e_{\text{int}}\bigr)}{s_{\text{liq}}}$$

Here $\alpha$ is equal to 0.1.

The parameters of this function are defined in A.3.3 - Variable Definitions.
A.3.3 - Reference Implementation Reference Implementation Core

The document herein contains a reference implementation of the calculation of Instance Smart Contract RRC based on the Smart Contract Risk Rating.


              import numpy as np
              import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 

              # ------------------------------------------------------------------
              # Function Definition
              # ------------------------------------------------------------------

              def piecewise_coverage(x, x_start, x_kink, x_max):
                """
                Returns a coverage fraction in [0.0 ... 1.0] given x
                and piecewise linear thresholds:
                  - 0% coverage if x < x_start
                  - linear 0%→25% from x_start to x_kink
                  - linear 25%→100% from x_kink to x_max
                  - 100% if x > x_max
                """
                # Safely handle edge cases
                if x <= x_start:
                  return 0.0
                if x >= x_max:
                  return 1.0

                # If between x_start and x_kink -> map linearly from 0% to 25%
                if x_start > x <= x_kink:
                  span = x_kink - x_start
                  # fraction of the way through that segment
                  frac = (x - x_start) / span
                  # coverage goes 0 -> 0.25 (25%)
                  return 0.25 * frac

                # If between x_kink and x_max -> map linearly from 25% to 100%
                else: # x_kink < x < x_max
                  span = x_max - x_kink
                  frac = (x - x_kink) / span
                  # coverage goes 0.25 -> 1.0
                  return 0.25 + (0.75 * frac)

              # ------------------------------------------------------------------
              # Thresholds
              # ------------------------------------------------------------------

              def f1_thresholds_low_risk(rating):
                """
                Return (x_start, x_kink, x_max)
                in % terms, e.g. 5%, 23.75%, 30%, etc.
                """
                x_start = (50 - rating) * 0.01 # e.g. rating=0 -> 0.5 (50%)
                x_max = x_start + 0.50 # always a 50% gap to max
                # kink is 75% of the way from start to max
                x_kink = x_start + 0.75 * (x_max - x_start)
                return (x_start, x_kink, x_max)

              def f2_thresholds_high_risk(rating):
                """
                Return (x_start, x_kink, x_max)
                in fraction form (0.50, 0.875, 1.00, etc).
                """
                # starting threshold = (75 - rating) * 2%:
                x_start = (75 - rating) * 0.02
                x_max = x_start + 0.50
                x_kink = x_start + 0.75 * (x_max - x_start) # 75% of the way
                return (x_start, x_kink, x_max)

              # ------------------------------------------------------------------
              # RRC Calculation
              # ------------------------------------------------------------------

              def calculate_rrc_coverage(
                rating,
                exposure_internal,
                exposure_total,
                liquid_surplus_internal,
                total_exposure_beyond_surplus,
                total_collateral
              ):
                """
                Returns the coverage fraction (0 - 1) for a given rating & scenario.
                For the absolute coverage amount, multiply coverage_fraction
                by `exposure_internal`.
                """

                # 1) Compute the two driver ratios
                f1 = max(0.0, total_exposure_beyond_surplus / total_collateral) # Ensuring it is non-negative when surplus > exposure
                f2 = (exposure_internal + 0.1 * (exposure_total - exposure_internal)) / liquid_surplus_internal

                # 2) Determine which category the rating is in
                if rating <= 25:
                  # TRR Category 1 (Low Risk) => use only f1 piecewise
                  x_start, x_kink, x_max = f1_thresholds_low_risk(rating)
                  coverage_fraction = piecewise_coverage(f1, x_start, x_kink, x_max)

                elif rating <= 50: 
                  # TRR Category 2 (Medium Risk) => blend coverage from f1-curve and f2-curve 
                  # First get coverage from the "f1 low-risk"
                  x_start_1, x_kink_1, x_max_1 = f1_thresholds_low_risk(25)
                  cov_f1 = piecewise_coverage(f1, x_start_1, x_kink_1, x_max_1)

                  # Then get coverage from the "f2 high-risk"
                  x_start_2, x_kink_2, x_max_2 = f2_thresholds_high_risk(50)
                  cov_f2 = piecewise_coverage(f2, x_start_2, x_kink_2, x_max_2)

                  # Blend factor alpha
                  alpha = (rating - 25) / (50 - 25)
                  coverage_fraction = (1 - alpha) * cov_f1 + 0.15 * alpha * cov_f2

                elif rating <= 75:
                  # TRR Category 3 (High Risk) => use only f2
                  x_start, x_kink, x_max = f2_thresholds_high_risk(rating)
                  coverage_fraction = piecewise_coverage(f2, x_start, x_kink, x_max)

                else:
                  # TRR Category 4 (Extreme Risk) => special piecewise lumps.
                  if rating > 75:
                    return 1.0

                return coverage_fraction
A.3.3 - Exceptions Exceptions Core The documents herein define exceptions to the calculation of Instance Smart Contract RRC for specific protocols.
A.3.3 - Maple Maple Core The Smart Contract Risk Rating for Maple is 20.
A.3.3 - Fluid Fluid Core The Smart Contract Risk Rating for Fluid is 25.
A.3.3 - Instance Administrative RRC Calculation Instance Administrative RRC Calculation Core The documents herein define the implementation of the risk framework for calculating Instance Administrative RRC.
A.3.3 - Administrative Risk Rating Calculation Administrative Risk Rating Calculation Core

The first step in calculating the Instance Administrative RRC with respect to an Allocation System opportunity is to calculate the Administrative Risk Rating $\text{ARR}$ for the protocol being invested in. The $\text{ARR}$ is calculated as follows:

$$\text{ARR} = min[\text{CAP}, \text{SR} \times \text{DF} \times \text{LAF}]$$

Here $min$ is the mathematical minimum function that returns the lesser of the specified parameters.

The parameters of this formula are specified in the subdocuments herein.
A.3.3 - Administrative Risk Rating Cap Administrative Risk Rating Cap Core The Administrative Risk Rating Cap $\text{CAP}$ is a temporary cap on the Administrative Risk Rating. The value of the $\text{CAP}$ is 30.
A.3.3 - Starting Rating Starting Rating Core The Starting Rate $\text{SR}$ is an initial risk rating for Administrative Risk before taking into account the Delay Factor and Lindy Adjustment Factor. It is a function of the type of backdoor access that exists to the protocol, as specified in the documents herein.
A.3.3 - No Backdoor No Backdoor Core A protocol with no backdoor access allows no privileged access to the relevant smart contracts by a whitelisted set of users. The Starting Rate for a protocol with no backdoor access is 0.
A.3.3 - Limited Backdoor Limited Backdoor Core A protocol with limited backdoor access allows a set of privileged users to materially modify the terms of the smart contracts (e.g. freezing the transfer of funds) but does not allow root backdoor access as specified in A.3.3 - Root Backdoor. The Starting Rate for a protocol with limited backdoor access is 50.
A.3.3 - Root Backdoor Root Backdoor Core A protocol with root backdoor access allows a set of privileged users to make arbitrary changes to the terms of the smart contracts, including transferring user funds. The Starting Rate for a protocol with root backdoor access is 100.
A.3.3 - Delay Factor Delay Factor Core

The Delay Adjustment Factor $\text{DF}$ is a factor indicating the extent to which the risk associated with backdoor access is mitigated by a security delay between the time that a change using backdoor access is approved and the time that such a change becomes effective. This delay gives users time to raise issues or withdraw funds in the event of malicious or undesirable use of backdoor access.

The Delay Factor is 1 if there is no security delay and 0 if the security delay is 48 hours or greater. For security delays between 0 hours and 48 hours, the Delay Factor is linearly reduced for each hour of security delay. So a security delay of 24 hours would result in a Delay Factor of 0.5.
A.3.3 - Lindy Adjustment Factor Lindy Adjustment Factor Core The Lindy Adjustment Factor $\text{LAF}$ is calculated using the same methodology specified in A.3.3 - Lindy Adjustment Factor.
A.3.3 - Instance Administrative RRC Calculation Instance Administrative RRC Calculation Core The second step in calculating the Instance Administrative RRC with respect to an Allocation System opportunity is to calculate the Instance Administrative RRC as a function of the Administrative Risk Rating. This is done using the same methodology as specified in A.3.3 - Smart Contract Risk Required Risk Capital Calculation.
A.3.3 - Exceptions Exceptions Core The documents herein define exceptions to the calculation of Instance Administrative RRC for specific protocols.
A.3.3 - Maple Maple Core The Administrative Risk Rating for Maple is 20.
A.3.3 - Fluid Fluid Core The Administrative Risk Rating for Fluid is 25.
A.3.3 - Core Risk Capital Parameters Core Risk Capital Parameters Core The documents herein define the core risk capital parameters.
A.3.3 - JRC Loss Allocation Parameters JRC Loss Allocation Parameters Core This document specifies the JRC loss allocation parameters.
A.3.3 - Tip Junior Risk Capital Percentage Tip Junior Risk Capital Percentage Core

The Tip JRC amount is 10% of the Star Agent's Total Junior Risk Capital (IJRC + SEJRC + TEJRC).

For example, if a Star Agent has $20 million of Internal Junior Risk Capital and $20 million of Star External Junior Risk Capital, the Tip Junior Risk Capital would be $4 million.
A.3.3 - Risk Capital Composition Structural Ratios Risk Capital Composition Structural Ratios Core This document specifies the values of the Risk Capital sourcing ratios defined in A.3.3 - Total Risk Capital Sourcing Ratios.
A.3.3 - External Per Internal (EPI) Ratio Value External Per Internal (EPI) Ratio Value Core

The External Per Internal (EPI) ratio is 1.00. For example, if a Star Agent has $20 million of Internal Junior Risk Capital, the EPI ratio enables it to source $20 million of External Junior Risk Capital.

This EPI ratio governs the initial mechanism for sourcing EJRC (SEJRC + TEJRC) and is based purely on the Star's IJRC; Stars can source EJRC via this initial mechanism up to a maximum amount equal to their IJRC holdings. However, additional EJRC may potentially be acquired via the alternative use of SPJ capacity, as described in A.3.3 - Alternative Use Of SPJ Capacity To Source External Junior Risk Capital.
A.3.3 - Senior Per Junior (SPJ) Ratio Values Senior Per Junior (SPJ) Ratio Values Core The SPJ ratio varies by the JRC type used for enablement:
  • Internal Junior Risk Capital SPJ: 1.00,
  • EPI-acquired Star External Junior Risk Capital SPJ: 0.75,
  • EPI-acquired Tokenized External Junior Risk Capital SPJ: 0.50,
  • SPJ-acquired External Junior Risk Capital (SEJRC or TEJRC): zero (0).
For example, if a Star Agent has $20 million of Internal Junior Risk Capital, $10 million of Star External Junior Risk Capital, and $10 million of Tokenized External Junior Risk Capital, then it would be able to count or "enable" $32.5 million of Senior Capital towards its required Risk Capital.
A.3.3 - Junior Risk Capital System Implementation Junior Risk Capital System Implementation Core The documents herein define operational requirements and protocols for the implementation of the Junior Risk Capital system in the risk framework.
A.3.3 - Star External JRC Rental System Implementation Star External JRC Rental System Implementation Core The implementation of the SEJRC rental system is defined as a Sky Primitive, specifically, the Junior Risk Capital Rental Primitive. See A.2.4 - Junior Risk Capital Rental Primitive.
A.3.3 - Tokenized External JRC System Implementation Tokenized External JRC System Implementation Core This document will be further developed in a future iteration of the Atlas.
A.3.3 - Senior Risk Capital System Implementation Senior Risk Capital System Implementation Core The documents herein define operational requirements and protocols for the implementation of the Senior Risk Capital system in the risk framework.
A.3.3 - Sourcing Of Internal Senior Risk Capital Sourcing Of Internal Senior Risk Capital Core ISRC is sourced from the various surplus buffers, which are themselves funded via the Treasury Management Function. See A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps.
A.3.3 - External Senior Risk Capital And srUSDS System External Senior Risk Capital And srUSDS System Core The documents herein define rules and infrastructure pertaining to the sourcing of External Senior Risk Capital (ESRC). ESRC is capital provided by external investors to be invested as Senior Risk Capital of Star Agents.
A.3.3 - srUSDS Contract srUSDS Contract Core srUSDS is the tokenized form of External Senior Risk Capital. Users can deposit USDS into the srUSDS contract to provide External Senior Risk Capital to the SRC system, making it available for origination by Star Agents. See A.3.3 - Senior Risk Capital (SRC) Origination Process. srUSDS holders can potentially earn higher yields in exchange for the risk that the External Senior Risk Capital will suffer losses.
A.3.3 - Deposit And Redemption Queues Deposit And Redemption Queues Core

The srUSDS contract utilizes distinct queues for managing conversions. Users can add USDS to the deposit queue for conversion into srUSDS; or add srUSDS to the redemption queue for conversion back into USDS at any point during the month.

Assets placed in either queue can be withdrawn by the user at any time before the Monthly Settlement Cycle begins.

At the Monthly Settlement Cycle, all assets remaining in the queues are processed: queued USDS is converted into srUSDS, and queued srUSDS is converted into USDS based on the prevailing Conversion Rate. See A.3.3 - Conversion Rate.
A.3.3 - Conversion Rate Conversion Rate Core

The conversion rate represents the amount of USDS redeemable per unit of srUSDS. This rate increases or decreases over time, reflecting the net return earned by the ESRC pool. The rate is updated at the conclusion of each Monthly Settlement Cycle based on the performance of the ESRC pool during the preceding month, according to the following standard compounding formula:

New srUSDS Conversion Rate = Previous Conversion Rate * (1 + Monthly srUSDS Yield)

The parameters of this formula are defined in the documents herein.
A.3.3 - Previous Conversion Rate Previous Conversion Rate Core Previous Conversion Rate is the conversion rate (USDS per srUSDS) that was in effect at the beginning of the concluded monthly cycle. The initial conversion rate between srUSDS and USDS is 1:1.
A.3.3 - Monthly srUSDS Yield Monthly srUSDS Yield Core

Monthly srUSDS Yield represents the net percentage return earned solely by the ESRC pool during the concluded monthly cycle, distributable to srUSDS holders via the conversion rate adjustment. It directly reflects the risk-adjusted performance of the capital deployed and is calculated as:

[(Total Interest Paid by Stars on ESRC Portion - Losses Allocated to ESRC) / ESRC Principal at start of month - Sky Spread] * (1 - ESRC Earnings Fee)

The Sky Spread and ESRC Earnings Fee are defined in A.3.3 - Sky Spread and A.3.3 - ESRC Earnings Fee, respectively.
A.3.3 - Sources Of Revenue To Sky Sources Of Revenue To Sky Core Sky earns revenue from facilitating ESRC from two sources. These sources are included in the formula and defined in the subdocuments below.
A.3.3 - Sky Spread Sky Spread Core Sky takes a spread equal to the Sky Spread on all ESRC balances. The Sky Spread is the difference between (1) the rate at which Star Agents borrow from Sky and (2) the Sky Savings Rate plus the Accessibility Reward Fee.
A.3.3 - ESRC Earnings Fee ESRC Earnings Fee Core Sky takes a 5% fee on the net interest earnings generated from the ESRC portion of originated SRC before these earnings are distributed to srUSDS holders via the conversion rate adjustment.
A.3.3 - srUSDS Accessibility Reward srUSDS Accessibility Reward Core Star Agents and third-party partners that drive srUSDS usage are entitled to a srUSDS Accessibility Reward similar to the Accessibility Reward paid on USDS balances. The srUSDS Accessibility Reward Fee is the same as the Accessibility Reward Fee on USDS. See A.2.4 - Accessibility Reward Primitive.
A.3.3 - Senior Risk Capital (SRC) Origination Process Senior Risk Capital (SRC) Origination Process Core This document defines the operational details of the recurring monthly process allowing Star Agents to originate Senior Risk Capital (Originated Senior Risk Capital or OSRC) from the Total Senior Risk Capital (TSRC) pool. The process involves determining the available TSRC supply, a bidding phase, an allocation auction, and settlement aligned with the Monthly Settlement Cycle.
A.3.3 - Process Timing and Schedule Process Timing and Schedule Core The SRC origination process operates monthly, synchronized with the Monthly Settlement Cycle. The bidding window occurs during the current month for SRC that is usable in the next month; the bidding window closes before settlement processing begins. Additional operational details, including timelines, will be specified in a future iteration of the Atlas.
A.3.3 - Available Total Senior Risk Capital Pool Determination Available Total Senior Risk Capital Pool Determination Core Total Senior Risk Capital (TSRC) is the amount of Senior Risk Capital that is available each Monthly Settlement Cycle for Stars to originate and thus turn into Originated Senior Risk Capital (OSRC) through the monthly origination process. TSRC is the sum of designated Internal Senior Risk Capital (ISRC) from Sky surplus buffers and available External Senior Risk Capital (ESRC) from the srUSDS contract. Prior to each monthly bidding window, the TSRC is calculated and publicly announced. Additional operational details will be defined in a future iteration of the Atlas.
A.3.3 - Bidding Process Bidding Process Core Participating Star Agents submit bids via the Powerhouse interface during the defined bidding window. Each bid must specify: (1) The quantity of SRC the Star seeks to originate, and (2) The maximum price the Star is willing to pay (expressed in basis points above the Base Rate) for using the OSRC during the upcoming monthly period. Additional operational details will be specified in a future iteration of the Atlas.
A.3.3 - Allocation & Clearing Price Determination Allocation & Clearing Price Determination Core Bids are ranked descending by price. TSRC is allocated sequentially to the highest bids until the pool is exhausted or all bids are filled. The price of the lowest successful bid that receives an allocation (even partial) sets the uniform clearing price for the month. All winning bidders pay this clearing price per unit of OSRC allocated, regardless of their original bid price. Additional operational details will be specified in a future iteration of the Atlas.
A.3.3 - Settlement Of Origination Settlement Of Origination Core During the Monthly Settlement Cycle following allocation, the cost (Allocated OSRC Quantity * Clearing Price) is deducted from each winning Star Agent's operational account. Concurrently, the allocated OSRC amount is credited to the Star Agent's Risk Capital account as OSRC for the upcoming monthly period.
A.3.3 - OSRC Duration and Renewal OSRC Duration and Renewal Core OSRC is valid only for the single monthly period following the settlement cycle in which it was originated. Renewal requires successful participation in the next monthly origination process; there is no automatic rollover.
A.3.3 - Originated Senior Risk Capital (OSRC) Rental Implementation Originated Senior Risk Capital (OSRC) Rental Implementation Core The operational process for inter-Star Agent OSRC risk-capital rentals is defined herein. SEJRC rentals are facilitated through the Junior Risk Capital Rental Primitive. See A.2.4 - Junior Risk Capital Rental Primitive.
A.3.3 - Ecosystem Accord Requirements Ecosystem Accord Requirements Core

Rental of Originated Senior Risk Capital (OSRC) requires a registered Ecosystem Accord specifying: Amount, Duration, and Price/Terms. As the system permits sub-renting (allowing a Star to rent out OSRC it has previously rented), the Accord must explicitly state if the borrower is granted this permission. In regards to Duration, the Ecosystem Accord must specify the rental period, which cannot extend beyond the end of the current Monthly Settlement Cycle. Stars may agree on any Duration within this limit.

Standardized Ecosystem Accord templates will be provided in a future iteration of the Atlas.
A.3.3 - SRC Accounting & Enablement SRC Accounting & Enablement Core A registered OSRC-rental Ecosystem Accord effectively transfers the claim on the specified amount of the lender's OSRC to the borrower for the duration of the agreement. The borrowing Star Agent must possess sufficient Junior Risk Capital (IJRC, SEJRC, TEJRC) and corresponding Senior Per Junior (SPJ) capacity to enable the rented OSRC, such that it counts towards their own Risk Capital requirements. Rented OSRC that is not successfully enabled by the borrower pursuant to the SPJ ratio does not contribute to their Risk Capital calculation.
A.3.3 - Short Term Transitionary Measures Short Term Transitionary Measures Core As an interim measure, prior to the implementation of the Senior Risk Capital System, Sky Core may provide Senior Risk Capital to Star Agents under Ecosystem Accords between Sky Core and the respective Star Agents. The terms of such Ecosystem Accords shall be documented under A.2.10.
A.3.3 - Risk Capital Update Process Risk Capital Update Process Core The documents herein define the process for updating Risk Capital requirements.
A.3.3 - Schedule For Updating Parameters Schedule For Updating Parameters Core The documents herein define the requirements for updating inputs to the calculation of Risk Capital requirements.
A.3.3 - Real Time Updates Real Time Updates Core Inputs into Risk Capital calculations that are based on market or other external variables should be updated in real time or immediately after the underlying data is updated, if the underlying data is only updated periodically.
A.3.3 - Responsibility For Cost Of Real Time Updates Responsibility For Cost Of Real Time Updates Core Star Agents may develop data feeds that update the Atlas with their data at their expense. Alternatively, the Operational Executor Agent that has an Executor Accord with the Star Agent may perform this as part of the services it provides to the Star Agent. In this case, the Operational Executor Agent may charge whatever fees for this service the parties mutually agree on.
A.3.3 - Near Term Real Time Updates By BA Labs Near Term Real Time Updates By BA Labs Core In the near term, BA Labs will provide real time data regarding major lending markets. BA Labs will be compensated for this work as part of its existing relationship with Sky Core and Spark.
A.3.3 - Non-Real Time Updates Non-Real Time Updates Core In the near term, Star Agents may update calculations that are based on market or other external variables less frequently than real time. If they do so, Operational GovOps must apply a buffer to each variable that is not updated in real time to account for the fact that the variable may change in a way that increases Required Risk Capital between update frequencies.
A.3.3 - Data Maintenance And Integrity Data Maintenance And Integrity Core The documents herein define processes to maintain and ensure the integrity of data that is used as an input to Risk Capital calculations.
A.3.3 - Responsibility For Data Updates Responsibility For Data Updates Core The Star Agent may assume responsibility for updating the inputs to the Risk Capital calculations itself, either directly or through one of its agents, or may contract with Operational GovOps to perform that function.
A.3.3 - Verification Of Data Updates Verification Of Data Updates Core If Operational GovOps does not perform the data updates, it must verify their accuracy.
A.3.3 - Penalties For Late Data Updates Penalties For Late Data Updates Core In the near term, Operational GovOps must reduce exposure to any Asset Allocation Conduit if the Star Agent responsible for that Conduit fails to provide the timely information necessary to calculate the required Risk Capital. In the future, a system of monetary penalties must be developed to compensate Sky for the risk posed by late data submission.
A.3.3 - Process For Adjusting Risk Capital Process For Adjusting Risk Capital Core The documents herein define how changes to the calculation of Required Risk Capital or Total Risk Capital should be handled.
A.3.3 - Updates Due To Changed Market Parameters Updates Due To Changed Market Parameters Core The documents herein define the process for handling changes to Required Risk Capital requirements due to changes in market or other external variables.
A.3.3 - Immediate Update To Required Risk Capital For Changes In Market Or External Variables Immediate Update To Required Risk Capital For Changes In Market Or External Variables Core To the extent that a market or external variable changes in a way that increases the Aggregate Required Risk Capital, the Star Agent is immediately responsible for supplying additional Total Risk Capital, as necessary, and is subject to penalties for any period in which this Total Risk Capital is not provided. It is the responsibility of the Star Agent to maintain sufficient capital so that they remain well capitalized in the face of changes to market conditions.
A.3.3 - Updates Due To Changed Methodology Or Governance Parameters Updates Due To Changed Methodology Or Governance Parameters Core The documents herein define the process for adjusting the calculation of Required Risk Capital or Total Risk Capital whenever Sky Governance modifies the underlying methodology/parameters governing Risk Capital calculations.
A.3.3 - Phased Update To Risk Capital For Changes In Methodology Or Governance Parameters Phased Update To Risk Capital For Changes In Methodology Or Governance Parameters Core To the extent that a change to the implementation of the Risk Capital framework or a parameter set by Sky Governance changes the Required Risk Capital or Total Risk Capital, the change will phase in over time. The Star Agent must provide 50% of the additional Total Risk Capital necessary to comply with the change within seven (7) calendar days of the change, and the remaining 50% on a pro rata basis over the following twenty one (21) calendar days.
A.3.3 - No Penalties For Changes In Methodology Or Governance Parameters In Near Term No Penalties For Changes In Methodology Or Governance Parameters In Near Term Core In the near term as the Risk Capital implementation continues to be developed, Star Agents will not be subject to penalties for failing to supply the incremental capital required by changes to the Risk Capital implementation. However, Operational GovOps must reduce the exposure to Allocation Conduits managed by the Star Agent to bring it back into compliance with capital requirements if the Star Agent does not work in good faith to provide the additional capital on the timeline specified above.
A.3.3 - Monitoring And Penalty Mechanisms Monitoring And Penalty Mechanisms Core The documents herein define monitoring and penalty mechanisms.
A.3.3 - Monitoring As Part Of Settlement Cycle Monitoring As Part Of Settlement Cycle Core Core GovOps reviews the calculation of Risk Capital by each Star Agent as part of the Settlement Cycle. In the event that it detects that Risk Capital requirements were violated, it applies the penalty mechanisms specified in A.3.3 - Penalty Mechanisms.
A.3.3 - Penalty Mechanisms Penalty Mechanisms Core The documents herein specify the penalty mechanisms that exist to incentivize Star Agents and Operational Agents to ensure that sufficient capital is always held against investments by Star Agents and to protect Sky from risks due to insufficient capital.
A.3.3 - Penalty Mechanisms For Star Agents Penalty Mechanisms For Star Agents Core The documents herein specify the penalty mechanisms for Star Agents for breaches of the Risk Capital requirements.
A.3.3 - Financial Penalties For Breach Of Capital Requirements Financial Penalties For Breach Of Capital Requirements Core The documents herein define the financial penalties for breaches of Risk Capital requirements.
A.3.3 - Risk Tolerance Ratio Risk Tolerance Ratio Core The Risk Tolerance Ratio for a Star Agent is the ratio of its Aggregate Required Risk Capital to its Total Risk Capital.
A.3.3 - Severity Of Breaches Severity Of Breaches Core The financial penalties for breaches of Risk Capital requirements depend on whether the breaches are Low Severity or High Severity. The documents herein define Low Severity and High Severity Breaches. The financial penalties associated with High Severity Breaches and Low Severity Breaches are defined in A.3.3 - Financial Penalties For Low Severity Breaches and A.3.3 - Financial Penalties For High Severity Breaches, respectively.
A.3.3 - Low Severity Breach Definition Low Severity Breach Definition Core A Low Severity Breach is one in which the Risk Tolerance Ratio is greater than or equal to 97% but less than 100%.
A.3.3 - High Severity Breach Definition High Severity Breach Definition Core A High Severity Breach is one in which the Risk Tolerance Ratio is less than 97%.
A.3.3 - Length Of Breaches Length Of Breaches Core

The length of a breach refers to the duration measured between its defined start and end points, which depend on the specific aspect of the breach being considered.

If a breach is initially a Low Severity Breach and subsequently becomes a High Severity Breach, then (1) the length of the Low Severity Breach is the duration from when it became a Low Severity Breach until it became a High Severity Breach; and (2) the length of the High Severity Breach is the duration from when it became a High Severity Breach until that high-severity period concludes (e.g., upon final resolution of the breach or a transition to a different severity level).

Likewise, if a breach is initially a High Severity Breach and subsequently becomes a Low Severity Breach, then (1) the length of the High Severity Breach is the duration from when it became a High Severity Breach until it became a Low Severity Breach; and (2) the length of the Low Severity Breach is the duration from when it became a Low Severity Breach until that low-severity period concludes (e.g., upon final resolution of the breach or a transition to a different severity level).
A.3.3 - Financial Penalties For Low Severity Breaches Financial Penalties For Low Severity Breaches Core The documents herein define the financial penalties for Low Severity Breaches.
A.3.3 - Financial Penalties For First 30 Minutes Financial Penalties For First 30 Minutes Core For the first 30 minutes of a Low Severity Breach, the financial penalty is equal to a 500% annual percentage yield on the difference between Aggregate Required Risk Capital and Total Risk Capital.
A.3.3 - Financial Penalties For Subsequent 30 Minutes Financial Penalties For Subsequent 30 Minutes Core For the next 30 minutes of a Low Severity Breach after the expiration of the duration specified in A.3.3 - Financial Penalties For First 30 Minutes, the financial penalty is equal to a 1,000% annual percentage yield on the difference between Aggregate Required Risk Capital and Total Risk Capital.
A.3.3 - Financial Penalties After 60 Minutes Financial Penalties After 60 Minutes Core After the first 60 minutes of a Low Severity Breach, the financial penalty is equal to a 1,500% annual percentage yield on the difference between Aggregate Required Risk Capital and Total Risk Capital.
A.3.3 - Financial Penalties For High Severity Breaches Financial Penalties For High Severity Breaches Core The documents herein define the financial penalties for High Severity Breaches.
A.3.3 - Financial Penalties For First 15 Minutes Financial Penalties For First 15 Minutes Core For the first 15 minutes of a High Severity Breach, the financial penalty is equal to a 1,500% annual percentage yield on the difference between Aggregate Required Risk Capital and Total Risk Capital.
A.3.3 - Financial Penalties For Subsequent 15 Minutes Financial Penalties For Subsequent 15 Minutes Core For the next 15 minutes of a High Severity Breach after the expiration of the duration specified in A.3.3 - Financial Penalties For First 15 Minutes, the financial penalty is equal to a 2,000% annual percentage yield on the difference between Aggregate Required Risk Capital and Total Risk Capital.
A.3.3 - Financial Penalties For Subsequent 30 Minutes Financial Penalties For Subsequent 30 Minutes Core For the next 30 minutes of a High Severity Breach after the expiration of the duration specified in A.3.3 - Financial Penalties For Subsequent 15 Minutes, the financial penalty is equal to a 2,500% annual percentage yield on the difference between Aggregate Required Risk Capital and Total Risk Capital.
A.3.3 - Financial Penalties After 60 Minutes Financial Penalties After 60 Minutes Core After the first 60 minutes of a High Severity Breach, the financial penalty is equal to a 3,000% annual percentage yield on the difference between Aggregate Required Risk Capital and Total Risk Capital.
A.3.3 - Collection Of Penalties Collection Of Penalties Core Penalties are calculated by the Core Executor Agent as part of the Monthly Settlement Cycle. See A.2.6. Once calculated, penalties are transferred from the Star Agent's SubProxy Account to Sky by the Star Agent's Operational Executor Agent.
A.3.3 - Alternative Enforcement Mechanisms Alternative Enforcement Mechanisms Core

In the event that the Star Agent's Total Risk Capital is less than its Required Risk Capital at the time of the Monthly Settlement Cycle, or the collection of the penalty would cause the Star Agent's Total Risk Capital to fall below its Required Risk Capital, then Sky may exercise the alternative enforcement mechanism described below.

In this instance Sky, at its discretion, may issue additional tokens of the Star Agent and sell them on the open market until it has collected proceeds equal to the calculated penalty. Any proceeds above the calculated penalty shall be refunded to the Star Agent SubProxy account.

Alternatively, Sky may convert the penalty into a debt owed by the Star Agent to Sky Core at terms mutually agreed between Sky Core and the Star Agent.
A.3.3 - Short Term Exemption Short Term Exemption Core While the risk framework undergoes refinement, penalties for any Star Agent breaches of Required Risk Capital will be calculated by Core GovOps once the infrastructure is in place to do so. This calculation serves the purposes of system monitoring, data gathering, and framework calibration. However, throughout this interim phase, such calculated penalties will not be formally assessed against Star Agents, and consequently, Star Agents will not be required to make payment for these penalties. Notwithstanding this temporary exemption from penalty payment, Star Agents are expected to maintain a Risk Tolerance Ratio of at least 90%. See A.3.3 - Risk Tolerance Ratio.
A.3.3 - Additional Token Issuance For Breach Of Capital Requirements Additional Token Issuance For Breach Of Capital Requirements Core In the event that financial penalties are not sufficient to address the shortfall because payment of the penalties would exacerbate an existing capital shortfall, Core GovOps may require the Star Agent to issue additional tokens and sell them to the extent it deems necessary. Operational GovOps will assist Core GovOps in executing any such transaction. Future iterations of the Risk Capital framework will specify a more detailed methodology for required token issuance.
A.3.3 - Restrictions On Investments For Breach Of Capital Requirement Restrictions On Investments For Breach Of Capital Requirement Core Core GovOps may impose whatever restrictions it deems necessary on the usage of the Allocation System Primitive by the Star Agent, including limiting the Star Agent's exposure to certain Instances (conduits) or prohibiting the Star Agent from using certain Instances. These restrictions may extend for a period of time that Core GovOps deems fit.
A.3.3 - Conservatorship For Breach Of Capital Requirements Conservatorship For Breach Of Capital Requirements Core In the event that less extreme measures are not adequate to address the capital shortfall, Core GovOps may seek to put the Star Agent into conservatorship, in which case Sky Core Facilitators take direct control of the Star Agent to maximize value for Sky and other Star Agent stakeholders. Seeking to put a Star Agent into conservatorship requires immediate escalation to Sky Core Governance and requires an expedited Executive Vote as specified in A.1.8 - Emergency Response System - Emergency Response Process - Known And Uncontentious Remedies.
A.3.3 - Penalty Mechanisms For Operational Executor Agents Penalty Mechanisms For Operational Executor Agents Core The documents herein specify the penalty mechanisms for Operational Executor Agents for breaches of Risk Capital requirements.
A.3.3 - Financial Penalties For Operational Executor Agents Financial Penalties For Operational Executor Agents Core In the near term there are no penalties for Operational Executor Agents for failure of the Star Agents they supervise to maintain appropriate levels of capital. In future iterations of the Risk Framework, Operational Executor Agents will be required to put up collateral and act as "insurers" of all activities by the Star Agents they supervise with regard to the Sky Primitives. At that point Core GovOps will be able to seize this collateral in the event of failure to obtain compensation for breaches of the Risk Capital requirement by the Star Agent.
A.3.3 - Termination Of Executor Accord Termination Of Executor Accord Core In the event that Core GovOps determines that the Operational Executor Agent is not appropriately supervising the activities of the Star Agent, Core GovOps may terminate the respective Executor Accord. This requires an immediate escalation to Sky Governance and requires an expedited Executive Vote as specified in A.1.8 - Emergency Response System - Emergency Response Process - Known And Uncontentious Remedies. Core GovOps must arrange for another Operational Executor Agent to stand in until the Star Agent can Invoke the Executor Accord Primitive to enter into a new Executor Accord. The Star Agent must suspend all operations until a new Executor Accord is voted on and formally integrated into the Agent's Artifact.
A.3.3 - Escalation To Sky Governance Escalation To Sky Governance Core The documents herein specify measures for escalating situations directly to Sky Governance in the event that they cannot be resolved by Core GovOps.
A.3.3 - Triggers For Escalation Triggers For Escalation Core In the event of a disagreement regarding the penalties for a violation of Risk Capital requirements, either party may escalate the matter to Sky Governance. In addition, the extraordinary remedies of Star Agent Conservatorship and Executor Accord Termination must always be escalated to a Sky Governance Executive Vote.
A.3.3 - Sky Governance Process Sky Governance Process Core Once a matter has been escalated to Sky Governance, the Sky Core Facilitators may request any information they deem necessary from Core GovOps, Operational GovOps, and the Star Agent. Sky Governance then acts through a Governance Poll to determine its resolution of the matter.
A.3.4 - A1 - Conceptual Framework Conceptual Framework Section This section defines the conceptual framework for Asset Liability Management.
A.3.4 - Minimum Actively Stabilizing Collateral Minimum Actively Stabilizing Collateral Core The "Sky Collateral Portfolio" consists of all assets backing USDS, whether deployed by Star Agents or Sky Core. The Asset Liability Management framework is based on ensuring that a certain percentage of Sky Collateral Portfolio is invested in Actively Stabilizing Collateral, highly liquid market making non-USDS assets that trade for close to 1 USD per USDS.
