There have been several instances where users entered official Sky forums/chats to understand why they had been suddenly liquidated, despite historically comfortable collateralization ratios (https://forum.makerdao.com/t/an-assessment-first-hand-experience-and-recommendations-from-the-aave-offboarding/11836). This is, understandably, a poor user experience. Even with liquidation penalties set to 0%, the forced unwinding of levered positions conceivably can result in user losses, as well as potentially taxable events. This Section defines procedures concerning the dissemination of information about upcoming collateral offboarding on a best-effort basis. The objective is to minimize the number of users who are unaware of the offboarding prior to getting their positions liquidated.
A.3.9 - Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Legacy Context Specific Goals Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Legacy Context Specific Goals Core Specific Goals:1. Codify a series of good-faith communication efforts.2. Provide an easy-to-follow process for Sky contributors to follow without significant burden.3. Minimize the number of users unaware of a collateral offboarding.4. Provide a method to bypass these requirements in the event a collateral is being offboarded due to serious security or solvency concerns.
A.3.9 - Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Technical Process Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Technical Process Core The subdocuments herein specify actions to be taken by specific actors within Sky when offboarding a vault type.
A.3.9 - Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Immediate Actions Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Immediate Actions Core Upon approval by Sky Governance to offboard a permissionless collateral type or vault type, the following actions are taken as soon as is practicable:• Set debt ceiling to zero (0) Dai or USDS.• Make an initial public announcement on all communication channels listed in A.3.9 - Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Communication Channels And Media Assets Listing.• Make a second public announcement on all communication channels in the above cited document no later than 14 calendar days after the initial public announcement.• Once the second public announcements have been made, set the liquidation penalty to 0%.
A.3.9 - Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Following Actions Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Following Actions Core Parameter changes designed to offboard users, such as changes to the liquidation ratio or stability fee, can only be implemented once 14 calendar days have passed following a second public announcement.
A.3.9 - Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Communication Channels And Media Assets Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Communication Channels And Media Assets Active Data Controller The process for adding, removing, and modifying communication channels and media assets, and the order of announcement publication, are defined as Active Data in A.3.9 - Communication Channels And Media Assets Listing. The Active Data is updated as follows:• The Responsible Party is the Communication Coordinator.• The Update Process must follow the protocol for 'Direct Edit'.
A.3.9 - Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Communication Coordinator Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Communication Coordinator Core The subdocuments herein define the Communication Coordinator role.
A.3.9 - Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Designated Responsible Party Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Designated Responsible Party Core The Communication Coordinator is designated the Responsible Party who is authorized to modify the Active Data document at A.3.9 - Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Communication Channels And Media Assets Listing.
A.3.9 - Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - The Current Communication Coordinator Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - The Current Communication Coordinator Active Data Controller The current Communication Coordinator is defined as Active Data in A.3.9 - Current Communication Coordinator. The Active Data is updated as follows:• The Responsible Party is the Governance Facilitators. • The Update Process must follow the protocol for 'Direct Edit' and must adhere to the additional requirements defined in A.3.9 - Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Requirements For Modification Of Current Communication Coordinator.
A.3.9 - Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Requirements For Modification Of Current Communication Coordinator Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Requirements For Modification Of Current Communication Coordinator Core If the current Communication Coordinator is no longer willing or able to fulfill this role, then the Governance Facilitator may appoint a new Communication Coordinator.• The Governance Facilitator is permitted to modify A.3.9 - Current Communication Coordinator by replacing the existing Communication Coordinator.• The new Communication Coordinator must have publicly communicated their willingness to fulfill the Communication Coordinator role.• The Governance Facilitator must publicly communicate that the modification has taken place.
A.3.9 - Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Expedited Offboarding Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Expedited Offboarding Core The subdocuments herein define an expedited offboarding process in the event a collateral type needs to be removed quickly due to security or solvency concerns.
A.3.9 - Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Requirements Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Requirements Core When a collateral type threatens the security or solvency of the Sky Protocol, an expedited offboarding is in order. Expedited offboardings override the timeline specified in A.3.9 - Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Technical Process and allow the immediate modification of all relevant parameters. Expedited offboardings must proceed pursuant to the following requirements:• The Offboarding Proposal must state that the offboarding should be expedited due to an emergency or urgent concern, as defined in A.1.8 - Emergency Voting System - Definition Of Emergency Situations.• The Offboarding Proposal must explicitly reference this Atlas document.
A.3.9 - Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Announcements Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Announcements Core The public announcements defined in A.3.9 - Measures For Endgame Transition - Offboarding Process - Technical Process must still be carried out. However, the timing of these announcements no longer constrains the modification of parameters. These announcements must also state that the offboarding is being expedited and explain the reasons for this accelerated process.
A.4.1 - A1 - Core Tokens - USDS Core Tokens - USDS Section USDS is the Stablecoin product of the Sky Protocol. It is designed to remain stable against USD, and its supply is regulated through the Peg Stability Module and the Allocation System, as governed by the Stability Scope.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - USDS - USDS Launch Core Tokens - USDS - USDS Launch Core In the Endgame Token Launch Phase, USDS is launched as an upgrade to Dai, offering new features, including Token Rewards. Dai can be exchanged to and from USDS at a rate of 1:1.
A.4.1 - A2 - Core Tokens - SKY Core Tokens - SKY Section SKY is the governance token of the Sky Protocol. It grants voting rights in the Sky Governance system. Its liquidity is boosted by the Smart Burn Engine, as governed by the Stability Scope.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Core Historically, MKR was the governance token of the Sky Protocol. As part of the transition to the Endgame, the technical infrastructure of the Sky Protocol must be upgraded to use SKY as its governance token rather than MKR. The upgrade will take place over three phases, as defined in the documents herein.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Approval Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Approval Core MKR Holders have voted to approve the deprecation of MKR as the governance token of the Sky Protocol with full knowledge of the changes being proposed. See https://vote.makerdao.com/polling/QmcZNZg3. This deprecation includes all actions defined in A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade, including, but not limited to, the removal of voting rights from MKR and the Delayed Upgrade Penalty.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Phase One Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Phase One Core The documents herein define Phase One of the upgrade from MKR to SKY as the governance token of the Protocol.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Phase One Timing Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Phase One Timing Core Phase One is expected to occur in the May 15, 2025 Executive Vote.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Phase One Actions Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Phase One Actions Core The actions specified in the documents herein will be taken as part of Phase One. These actions are authorized to proceed directly to an Executive Vote without a prior Governance Poll.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Disable Conversion From SKY To MKR In Existing Conversion Contract Core Tokens - SKY - Disable Conversion From SKY To MKR In Existing Conversion Contract Core The functionality to convert SKY to MKR in the existing converter contract located at 0xBDcFCA946b6CDd965f99a839e4435Bcdc1bc470B on the Ethereum Mainnet must be disabled.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Launch New MKR To SKY Conversion Contract Core Tokens - SKY - Launch New MKR To SKY Conversion Contract Core A new contract that allows upgrading from MKR to SKY must be deployed. This contract must have the following features:
  • it must allow upgrading from MKR to SKY at a conversion rate of 1 MKR to 24,000 SKY, subject to the Delayed Upgrade Penalty specified below;
  • it must not allow conversion from SKY to MKR;
  • it must support charging a Delayed Upgrade Penalty set by Sky Governance, which applies to all upgrades of MKR to SKY; and
  • the Delayed Upgrade Penalty must initially be set to 0%.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Disable MKR Flop Auctions Core Tokens - SKY - Disable MKR Flop Auctions Core MKR flop auctions must be disabled.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Disable Emergency Shutdown Module Core Tokens - SKY - Disable Emergency Shutdown Module Core The Emergency Shutdown Module must be disabled by setting the amount of MKR required to trigger it to infinity.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Launch New Chief Contract Core Tokens - SKY - Launch New Chief Contract Core A new Chief contract must be deployed to support voting with SKY instead of MKR. The following changes must be made to support upgrade to the new Chief contract:
  • the ds-pause contract must be set to be operated by the new Chief contract;
  • all MOM contracts must be set to be operated by the new Chief contract;
  • the maxYays parameter in the new Chief contract must be set to 5;
  • the launchThreshold in the new Chief contract must be set to 2,400,000,000 SKY (equivalent to 100,000 MKR); and
  • the liftCooldown must be set to 10 blocks.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Move Authority Of Spark Freezer MOM Contract To New Chief Contract Core Tokens - SKY - Move Authority Of Spark Freezer MOM Contract To New Chief Contract Core A Spark Spell must be triggered to move the authority of the Spark Freezer MOM contract to the new Chief contract. See A.1.9 - Sky Core Governance Security - Governance Security Delay Requirements - SparkLend Freezer Mom Exception.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Launch New SKY Oracle Core Tokens - SKY - Launch New SKY Oracle Core A new Oracle Security Module based on the Scribe SKY oracle must be deployed.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Add New SKY Oracle to Oracle Security Module MOM Contract Core Tokens - SKY - Add New SKY Oracle to Oracle Security Module MOM Contract Core The new SKY oracle must be added to the OSM_MOM contract. See A.1.9 - Sky Core Governance Security - Governance Security Delay Requirements - Oracle Freeze Exception.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Update Smart Burn Engine Parameters Core Tokens - SKY - Update Smart Burn Engine Parameters Core The parameters of the Smart Burn Engine must be updated as follows:
  • The oracle must be changed to the new SKY oracle; and
  • The rewardsDuration for the LSEV2-SKY-A USDS rewards contract must be set such that it is equal to the splitter.hop parameter.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Launch SKY Staking Core Tokens - SKY - Launch SKY Staking Core SKY Staking must be launched with the following parameters for borrowing against staked SKY:
  • Ilk: LSEV2-SKY-A
  • Farms: LSSKY → USDS (Add address when deployed)
  • Fee: 0
  • DC-IAM line: Set at discretion of Stability Facilitators in consultation with Stability Scope Advisors
  • DC-IAM gap: Set at discretion of Stability Facilitators in consultation with Stability Scope Advisors
  • DC-IAM ttl: Set at discretion of Stability Facilitators in consultation with Stability Scope Advisors
  • Only existing LSE-MKR-A users with drawn debt are allowed to migrate debt to LSEV2-SKY-A initially
  • Dust: 30,000
  • Duty: 20%
  • Mat: 125%
  • Calc: StairstepExponentialDecrease
  • Buf: 120%
  • Tail: 6,000 seconds
  • Cusp: 40%
  • Chip: 0.1%
  • Tip: 300 USDS
  • Stopped: 3
  • Chop: 13%
  • Hole: 250,000
  • Tau: 0 days
  • Cut: 0.99
  • Step: 60 seconds
  • LineMom: Yes
  • Tolerance: 0.5
  • Name: LockstakeSky
  • Symbol: lsSKY
  • Use new SKY Chronicle Scribe oracle instance OSM
  • Deny the CLIPPER_MOM from the new lockstake clipper
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Deploy New Vote Delegate Factory Contract Core Tokens - SKY - Deploy New Vote Delegate Factory Contract Core A new Vote Delegate factory contract must be deployed. The Vote Delegate factory contract must support deploying Delegate Contracts to which SKY holders and SKY Staking users can delegate their voting power.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Phase Two Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Phase Two Core The documents herein define Phase Two of the upgrade from MKR to SKY as the governance token of the Protocol.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Phase Two Timing Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Phase Two Timing Core Phase Two is expected to occur in the May 29, 2025 Executive Vote.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Phase Two Actions Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Phase Two Actions Core The actions specified in the documents herein will be taken as part of Phase Two. These actions are authorized to proceed directly to an Executive Vote without a prior Governance Poll.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Update Parameters For Staked Sky Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Phase Two Actions Core The parameters for staked SKY must be updated as follows:
  • USDS rewards on the LSEV2-SKY-A contract must be activated by setting the splitter.burn parameter to 50%;
  • the maxLine parameter must be set to 50,000,000 USDS;
  • the gap parameter must be set to 25,000,000;
  • the ttl parameter must be set to 86,400 seconds; and
  • the autoline parameter must be enabled.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Adjust GSM Pause Delay Core Tokens - SKY - Adjust GSM Pause Delay Core The GSM Pause Delay must be set to 24 hours. See A.1.9 - Sky Core Governance Security - Governance Security Delay Requirements - Pause Delay Current Value.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Revoke Migrator Authority Over Vat Contract Core Tokens - SKY - Revoke Migrator Authority Over Vat Contract Core The Migrator contract authority over the Vat contract must be revoked. This authority was necessary for existing users of LSE-MKR-A to migrate to LSEV2-SKY-A but is no longer required.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Phase Three Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Phase Three Core The documents herein define Phase Three of the upgrade from MKR to SKY as the governance token of the Protocol.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Phase Three Timing Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Phase Three Timing Core Phase Three will occur in Executive Votes subsequent to the May 29, 2025 Executive Vote. Unlike Phases One and Two, Phase Three will occur over multiple future Executive Votes.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Phase Three Actions Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Phase Three Actions Core The actions specified in the documents herein will be taken as part of Phase Three. These actions are authorized to proceed directly to an Executive Vote without a prior Governance Poll.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Develop SKY Flop Auctions Core Tokens - SKY - Develop SKY Flop Auctions Core Functionality for SKY flop auctions must be developed.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Offboard Borrowing Against Staked MKR Core Tokens - SKY - Offboard Borrowing Against Staked MKR Core Seal Engine (LSE-MKR-A) must be offboarded as a collateral type. This will require retiring the existing SKY wrapped oracle and removing it from the MegaPoker keeper as well as other actions that will be identified at a future date.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Upgrade MKR In Pause Proxy To SKY Core Tokens - SKY - Upgrade MKR In Pause Proxy To SKY Core The MKR in the Pause Proxy contract must be upgraded to SKY.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Update Liquidation Parameters For Borrowing Against Staked SKY Core Tokens - SKY - Update Liquidation Parameters For Borrowing Against Staked SKY Core Once sufficient liquidity has been attained, liquidations must be enabled and parameters for LSEV2-SKY-A must be updated to normal levels.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Set Conversion Fee In MKR To SKY Conversion Contract To 1% Core Tokens - SKY - Set Conversion Fee In MKR To SKY Conversion Contract To 1% Core In the September 18, 2025 Executive Vote, the Delayed Upgrade Penalty for the new MKR to SKY conversion contract (see A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Launch New MKR To SKY Conversion Contract) must be set to 1%. Thereafter, the Delayed Upgrade Penalty must be increased gradually at the rate of 1 percentage point per three months.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Modification Of Phases Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Modification Of Phases Core The timing and contents of Phase One, Phase Two, and Phase Three may be adjusted by the Protocol Facilitators in consultation with relevant Ecosystem Actors.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Deflationary Tokenomics Core Tokens - SKY - Deflationary Tokenomics Core The documents herein set forth the core deflationary tokenomics of the SKY token.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Initial Token Supply Core Tokens - SKY - Initial Token Supply Core The initial token supply of SKY tokens is derived from the total number of legacy MKR tokens as of the launch of Sky, multiplied by the conversion ratio of 24,000. SKY is the exclusive governance token of the Sky Protocol and takes over all governance and economic rights previously held by MKR. See A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade Approval.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - No New Token Emissions Core Tokens - SKY - No New Token Emissions Core No new SKY tokens may be emitted except for (1) emissions required to recapitalize the protocol if it is at risk of insolvency (see A.3.7) and (2) temporary emissions that are being deprecated and fully offset by corresponding burns, resulting in no net increase to the intended long-term token supply (see A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Deprecated Emissions Mechanisms).
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Burning of Existing Tokens Core Tokens - SKY - Burning of Existing Tokens Core At the same time that no new SKY tokens are issued, SKY tokens are bought back and burned on a regular basis, using a portion of the Net Revenue of the Protocol as dictated by the Treasury Management Function. See A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Smart Burn Buffer. As a result, the total supply of SKY tokens will continue to decrease over time.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Deprecated Emissions Mechanisms Core Tokens - SKY - Deprecated Emissions Mechanisms Core The subdocuments herein define legacy mechanisms involving the issuance of new SKY tokens. Each of these mechanisms is being deprecated. While these mechanisms do not increase the net supply of SKY tokens, they must be replaced with solutions that do not involve any emissions of SKY tokens, as defined in the documents herein.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - SKY Token Rewards Emissions Core Tokens - SKY - SKY Token Rewards Emissions Core

USDS users are able to earn SKY Rewards. See A.4.3 - A2 - Savings Rate And Token Reward Mechanism - Token Reward Mechanism. These rewards are currently funded by emissions of new SKY tokens.

These ongoing emissions will be eliminated and replaced with a solution that funds these rewards using SKY held by the Sky Protocol.

At the same time that this new solution is implemented, SKY tokens equal to the total SKY emissions previously used to fund SKY Rewards, including the Early Bird Reward (see A.5.5 - Accessibility Campaigns - Early Bird Reward - Token Distribution), will be burned from SKY held by the Sky Protocol.

The combination of these actions will achieve a state where the number of total SKY tokens is exactly the same as if SKY Rewards had never been funded with protocol emissions.
A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Conversion Emissions Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Conversion Emissions Core

The legacy MKR to SKY conversion contract (Legacy Conversion Contract) burns MKR and mints new SKY. The new MKR to SKY conversion contract (New Conversion Contract) instead burns MKR and issues SKY from the existing supply of preminted SKY.

The Legacy Conversion Contract will be disabled as soon as practicable. To offset SKY minted by the Legacy Conversion Contract after the deployment of the New Conversion Contract, an equivalent amount of preminted SKY will be burned. This action will ensure the total SKY token supply remains as if these specific emissions from the Legacy Conversion Contract had not occurred.
A.4.2 - A1 - SkyLink - Multichain Support Native Mechanisms SkyLink - Multichain Support Native Mechanisms Section SkyLink deployments support features including the Savings Rate Mechanism (including sUSDS), the Token Rewards Mechanism and the SKY Staking Mechanism.
A.4.3 - A1 - Savings Rate And Token Reward Mechanism - Savings Rates Savings Rate And Token Reward Mechanism - Savings Rates Section The Savings Rate Mechanism includes both the legacy Dai Savings Rate Mechanism and the Sky Savings Rate. The Sky Savings Rate includes a built-in sUSDS mechanism. The Savings Rate is governed by the Stability Scope.
A.4.3 - A2 - Savings Rate And Token Reward Mechanism - Token Reward Mechanism Savings Rate And Token Reward Mechanism - Token Reward Mechanism Section The Token Rewards Mechanism provides SKY rewards to USDS users. Agent tokens are also distributed through a Token Rewards Mechanism.
A.4.3 - Savings Rate And Token Reward Mechanism - Token Reward Mechanism - SKY Token Rewards Savings Rate And Token Reward Mechanism - Token Reward Mechanism Core

With each Executive Vote, the distribution of SKY token rewards to USDS holders is normalized to ensure the effective yield provided by these rewards equals the Sky Savings Rate (SSR) for the upcoming period. The effective yield is defined as: (Total Market Value of Distributed SKY Tokens / Total Eligible USDS Balance).

To achieve this normalization, the quantity of SKY token rewards to be distributed is determined through the following calculation, performed for each normalization period:

  1. Determine Target Reward Value: Calculate the total US dollar value required to meet the SSR for the period: (Total Eligible USDS Balance * SSR).
  2. Determine SKY Token Quantity: Divide the Target Reward Value (from step 1) by the Current Market Price of SKY (determined at the time of the Executive Vote).
A.4.4 - A1 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking Section SKY holders can stake their tokens via the SKY Staking Mechanism available on Ethereum Mainnet and SkyLink Deployments. SKY stakers earn voting rewards sourced from the Sky Treasury Management Function. In lieu of USDS rewards, SKY stakers can choose to earn Agent Token Rewards, including SPK and the tokens of other Star Agents incubated by the Launch Project. SKY stakers can also borrow USDS against their staked collateral using the SKY-backed borrowing mechanism defined herein.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY Staking Voting Rewards SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY Staking Voting Rewards Core The documents herein define the SKY Staking Voting Rewards. SKY stakers may choose between receiving USDS or Agent Token rewards.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY Staking Voting Rewards - Sources of Voting Rewards SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY Staking Voting Rewards - Sources of Voting Rewards Core SKY stakers are eligible to receive voting rewards sourced from the Sky Treasury Management Function (TMF) or the Agent Token Distribution mechanism defined in A.4.5.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY Staking Voting Rewards - Sources of Voting Rewards - Treasury Management Function-Derived Voting Rewards SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY Staking Voting Rewards - Sources of Voting Rewards - Treasury Management Function-Derived Voting Rewards Core USDS rewards are distributed via two distinct mechanisms based on the staker’s activity level: the High Activity Staking Reward (HASR) and the Standard Activity Staking Reward (SASR). SASR is the base reward when funding from the Treasury Management Function is available; HASR is an additional boost reserved for High-Activity wallets. See A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 2: High Activity Staking Rewards - Payout From High Activity Staking Rewards Buffer.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY Staking Voting Rewards - Sources of Voting Rewards - Treasury Management Function-Derived Voting Rewards - Activity Levels SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY Staking Voting Rewards - Sources of Voting Rewards - Treasury Management Function-Derived Voting Rewards - Activity Levels Core At the Monthly Settlement Cycle, all SKY-staking wallets are tagged as High Activity or Standard Activity, pursuant to the criteria defined in A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 2: High Activity Staking Rewards - High Activity Staker Qualification and A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Standard Activity Staker Qualification. Only High Activity wallets share HASR; both High and Standard Activity wallets share SASR.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY Staking Voting Rewards - Sources of Voting Rewards - Treasury Management Function-Derived Voting Rewards - High Activity Staking Rewards SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY Staking Voting Rewards - Sources of Voting Rewards - Treasury Management Function-Derived Voting Rewards - High Activity Staking Rewards Core The High Activity Staking Rewards (HASR) is a boosted reward provided to High Activity wallets. The HASR amount is distributed each monthly cycle pro-rata to the SKY stake of all High Activity wallets. High Activity wallets receive SASR (when funding is available) plus their separate HASR boost.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY Staking Voting Rewards - Sources of Voting Rewards - Treasury Management Function-Derived Voting Rewards - Standard Activity Staking Rewards SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY Staking Voting Rewards - Sources of Voting Rewards - Treasury Management Function-Derived Voting Rewards - Standard Activity Staking Rewards Core The Standard Activity Staking Rewards (SASR) is the base reward shared by all wallets with Standard Activity status or higher. When funding is available, the SASR amount is distributed each monthly cycle pro‑rata to the SKY stake of every Standard or High Activity wallet.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY Staking Voting Rewards - Sources of Voting Rewards - Agent Token Distribution Voting Rewards SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY Staking Voting Rewards - Sources of Voting Rewards - Agent Token Distribution Voting Rewards Core SKY stakers are eligible to receive Agent Token rewards as specified in A.4.5. At the Monthly Settlement Cycle, Agent Tokens are distributed pro‑rata, by staked SKY, among wallets that have opted to receive a specific Agent Token for the cycle. To qualify for Agent Token payout a wallet must satisfy the Standard Activity criteria specified in A.2.5 - Treasury Management - Treasury Management - Allocation Steps - Step 4: Smart Burn And Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Standard Activity Staking Rewards - Payout From Standard Activity Staking Rewards Buffer.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing Core SKY stakers can borrow USDS against their staked SKY collateral. This borrowing will be facilitated exclusively by the yUSDS system which will provide protocol-independent, or segregated, risk capital. The yUSDS system is currently in development; its elements are outlined in the subdocuments below. During the transition period to the yUSDS system, the protocol-dependent SKY-backed borrowing system remains operational and is governed by A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - Short Term Transitionary Measures.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - yUSDS Function SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - yUSDS Function Core yUSDS is a yield-bearing token representing USDS deposited into the yUSDS contract. Its primary function is to provide segregated risk capital for the SKY-backed borrowing mechanism. Users convert USDS to yUSDS to provide this capital and earn the yUSDS Rate. See A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - yUSDS Rate. yUSDS can be converted back to USDS subject to available unutilized liquidity in the yUSDS converter contract.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - yUSDS Rate SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - yUSDS Rate Core The variable yield earned by yUSDS holders is calculated using the formula:

            yUSDS Rate = Utilization * (SKY Borrow Rate - yUSDS Accessibility Reward) + (1 - Utilization) * Sky Savings Rate

Depositors earn a rate derived from the SKY Borrow Rate less the yUSDS Accessibility Reward on the utilized portion of their capital and the Sky Savings Rate on the unutilized portion.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - yUSDS Rate - Parameters Definition SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - yUSDS Rate - Parameters Definition Core The parameters of the yUSDS Rate formula are further defined in the documents herein.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - yUSDS Rate - Parameters Definition - Utilization Definition SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - yUSDS Rate - Parameters Definition - Utilization Definition Core Utilization is the percent of funds in the yUSDS contract that are used to fund borrowing against staked SKY.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - yUSDS Rate - Parameters Definition - SKY Borrow Rate Definition SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - yUSDS Rate - Parameters Definition - SKY Borrow Rate Definition Core SKY Borrow Rate is the SKY Borrow Rate defined in A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - SKY Borrow Rate.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - yUSDS Rate - Parameters Definition - Sky Savings Rate Definition SSKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - yUSDS Rate - Parameters Definition - Sky Savings Rate Definition Core Sky Savings Rate is the Sky Savings Rate defined in A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Sky Savings Rate.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - yUSDS Rate - Parameters Definition - yUSDS Accessibility Reward Definition SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - yUSDS Rate - Parameters Definition - yUSDS Accessibility Reward Definition Core yUSDS Accessibility Reward is defined in A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - yUSDS Accessibility Reward.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - yUSDS Holders' Risk Bearing SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - yUSDS Holders' Risk Bearing Core Holders of yUSDS accept the risk associated with providing capital for SKY-backed borrowing. In the event that the liquidation of a borrower's staked SKY collateral does not cover the outstanding debt, yUSDS balances will be subject to a haircut proportional to the shortfall. This mechanism ensures that the Sky Protocol is isolated from losses originating from the SKY-backed borrowing facility.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - Debt Ceiling SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - Debt Ceiling Core The maximum amount of USDS that can be borrowed against staked SKY is dynamically determined by, and equal to, the total amount of USDS currently held within the yUSDS contract. This dynamic ceiling will replace the static DC-IAM module and parameters associated with protocol-dependent, SKY-backed borrowing.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - SKY Borrow Rate SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - SKY Borrow Rate Core The interest rate charged to borrowers (SKY Borrow Rate) is dynamic and market-driven, based on the utilization of funds within the yUSDS contract. This dynamic rate will replace the static Stability Fee parameter associated with protocol-dependent, SKY-backed borrowing.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - SKY Borrow Rate - Rate Setting Mechanism SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - SKY Borrow Rate - Rate Setting Mechanism Core The SKY Borrow Rate adjusts to target a 90% utilization rate of the USDS in the yUSDS contract. When yUSDS utilization is below 90%, the rate gradually decreases; when above 90%, it gradually increases. The SKY Borrow Rate cannot fall below the SKY Borrow Minimum Rate. See A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - SKY Borrow Rate - SKY Borrow Minimum Rate.
The specific parameters and formula governing the rate of adjustment will be specified in a future iteration of the Atlas.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - SKY Borrow Rate - SKY Borrow Minimum Rate SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - SKY Borrow Rate - SKY Borrow Minimum Rate Core The SKY Borrow Minimum Rate is calculated according to the following formula:

            SKY Borrow Minimum Rate = Sky Savings Rate + yUSDS Accessibility Reward

The formula ensures the SKY Borrow Minimum Rate covers the baseline cost of capital (Sky Savings Rate) plus the incentive cost (yUSDS Accessibility Reward), preventing value-draining arbitrage where users could borrow below the Sky Savings Rate.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - SKY Borrow Rate - SKY Borrow Minimum Rate - Parameters Definition SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - Sky Borrow Rate - SKY Borrow Minimum Rate - Parameters Definition Core The parameters of the SKY Borrow Minimum Rate formula are further defined in the documents herein.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - SKY Borrow Rate - SKY Borrow Minimum Rate - Parameters Definition - Sky Savings Rate Definition SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - SKY Borrow Rate - SKY Borrow Minimum Rate - Parameters Definition - Sky Savings Rate Definition Core Sky Savings Rate is defined in A.3.2 - Core Stability Parameters - Parameters - Sky Savings Rate.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - SKY Borrow Rate - SKY Borrow Minimum Rate - Parameters Definition - yUSDS Accessibility Reward Definition SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - SKY Borrow Rate - SKY Borrow Minimum Rate - Parameters Definition - yUSDS Accessibility Reward Definition Core yUSDS Accessibility Reward is defined in A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - yUSDS Accessibility Reward.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - yUSDS Risk Parameters SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - yUSDS Risk Parameters Core This document defines the liquidation parameters for SKY-backed loans funded via yUSDS. These parameters will be specified in a future iteration of the Atlas.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - yUSDS Accessibility Reward SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - SKY-Backed Borrowing - yUSDS Accessibility Reward Core The yUSDS Accessibility Reward is an incentive mechanism, similar to the USDS Accessibility Reward, designed to encourage Star Agents and Integrators to promote yUSDS adoption. See A.2.4 - Accessibility Reward Primitive. It is calculated as a percentage of the yUSDS balance associated with a Reward Code. The reward is initially set at 0.05% for the Integrator portion and 0.05% for the Star Agent Management Fee, totaling 0.1%.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - Short Term Transitionary Measures SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - Short Term Transitionary Measures Core The documents herein define short-term logic for SKY staking rewards and SKY-backed borrowing pending the implementation of the Sky Treasury Management Function and the yUSDS system. Short-term logic regarding MKR staking rewards and MKR-backed borrowing is also included herein.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - Short Term Transitionary Measures - Short Term Staking SKY Rewards SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - Short Term Transitionary Measures - Short Term Staking SKY Rewards Core USDS rewards for SKY stakers will be enabled as specified in A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade. Until the Treasury Management Function (TMF) is live, USDS rewards for SKY stakers will be temporarily funded by the Smart Burn Engine; this interim mechanism will be discontinued once the TMF becomes operational.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - Short Term Transitionary Measures - Short Term Staking Rewards - SKY Staking Rewards Parameters SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - Short Term Transitionary Measures - Short Term Staking Rewards - SKY Staking Rewards Parameters Core When SKY Staking launches, the short-term Staking Rewards parameters will be specified in this document pursuant to A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Update Smart Burn Engine Parameters.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - Short Term Transitionary Measures - Short Term SKY-Backed Borrowing SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - Short Term Transitionary Measures - Short Term SKY-Backed Borrowing Core SKY-backed borrowing will be enabled as specified in A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade. In the short term, pending the development of the yUSDS system, SKY-backed borrowing will be funded directly by Sky. This funding must be replaced by the yUSDS system as soon as the yUSDS system is developed.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - Short Term Transitionary Measures - Short Term SKY-Backed Borrowing - SKY-Backed Borrowing Parameters SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - Short Term Transitionary Measures - Short Term SKY-Backed Borrowing - SKY-Backed Borrowing Parameters Core When SKY Staking launches, the risk parameters for SKY-backed borrowing funded directly by Sky will be specified in this document pursuant to A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Launch SKY Staking and A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - Update Liquidation Parameters For Borrowing Against Staked SKY.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - Short Term Transitionary Measures - Short-Term MKR Staking Rewards SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - Short Term Transitionary Measures - Short-Term MKR Staking Rewards Core As the legacy governance token of the Sky Protocol, MKR stakers are currently eligible for USDS rewards. This functionality will be phased out as specified in A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade. The documents herein define the parameters for USDS rewards to MKR stakers during this interim period.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - Short Term Transitionary Measures - Short-Term MKR Staking Rewards - MKR Staking Rewards Parameters SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - Short Term Transitionary Measures - Short-Term MKR Staking Rewards - MKR Staking Rewards Parameters Core The short-term staking rewards parameters are:
  • rewardsDistribution: Set to the Splitter
  • rewardsDuration: 15,649 seconds
  • farms (Whitelisted set of farms to choose from): LsMkrUsdsFarm
  • fee (Exit fee): 0%
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - Short Term Transitionary Measures - Short-Term MKR-Backed Borrowing SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - Short Term Transitionary Measures - Short-Term MKR-Backed Borrowing Core Borrowing against staked MKR is currently supported and funded directly by Sky. This functionality will be phased out as specified in A.4.1 - Core Tokens - SKY - MKR To SKY Upgrade. The documents herein define the risk parameters for MKR-backed borrowing during this interim period.
A.4.4 - SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - Short Term Transitionary Measures - Short-Term MKR-Backed Borrowing - MKR-Backed Borrowing Parameters SKY Staking Mechanism - SKY Staking - Short Term Transitionary Measures - Short-Term MKR-Backed Borrowing - MKR-Backed Borrowing Parameters Core The current risk parameters for MKR-backed borrowing funded directly by Sky are:
  • Cut: 0.99
  • Step: 60 seconds
  • Buf: 1.20
  • Cusp: 0.40
  • Tail: 6,000 seconds
  • Chip: 0.1%
  • Tip: 300 DAI
  • Calc: StairstepExponentialDecrease
  • Ilk.chop: 8%
  • Tolerance: 0.5
  • Dust: 30,000 DAI
  • Ilk.hole: 3M DAI
  • Stability Fee: 20%
  • spotter[ilk].mat (Liquidation Ratio): 125%
  • DC-IAM line: 45M
  • DC-IAM gap: 45M
  • DC-IAM ttl: 30 minutes
A.5.2 - A1 - Brand Identity Brand Identity Section This Section defines the management and use of Sky's brand identity.
A.5.2 - Brand Identity - Website And Domain Brand Identity - Website And Domain Core The IP rights of the Sky website must be transferred to an entity similar to the Dai Foundation.
A.5.2 - Brand Identity - Dai Brand Identity - Dai Core Dai must remain as a valid token and product, with no actively maintained brand presence beyond community assets, educational material and its token name.
A.5.4 - A1 - Accessibility Communication Channels Accessibility Communication Channels Section This Section defines rules for managing accessible communication channels to enhance public access to, and interaction with, the Sky Ecosystem. These communication channels are distinct from Sky's governance-focused communication channels.
A.5.4 - Accessibility Communication Channels - External Platforms Accessibility Communication Channels - External Platforms Core Sky must support the accessibility of the Sky Ecosystem by paying Ecosystem Actors to maintain accounts and channels on external platforms, such as Twitter and Telegram. These accounts may develop and share Accessibility content that follows the brand guidelines.
A.5.4 - Accessibility Communication Channels - Budget Accessibility Communication Channels - Budget Core The Accessibility communication channel budget is available to maintain the tasks described in A.5.4 - A1 - Accessibility Communication Channels and its subdocuments.
A.5.4 - Accessibility Communication Channels - Budget - Amount Accessibility Communication Channels - Budget - Amount Core The Accessibility communication channel budget is:• 0 USDS per month, implemented with DssVest. It is a monthly recurring budget.
A.5.4 - Accessibility Communication Channels - Budget - Modification Accessibility Communication Channels - Budget - Modification Core The Accessibility Facilitator can propose to modify the budget by posting a message in the Sky Core Forum specifying the proposed new value. This triggers a Governance Poll in the Weekly Governance Cycle that edits the value if it is accepted.
A.5.5 - A1 - Accessibility Campaigns Accessibility Campaigns Section This Section defines infrastructure and processes pertaining to accessibility campaigns.
A.5.5 - Accessibility Campaigns - Accessibility Facilitators Responsibility Accessibility Campaigns - Accessibility Facilitators Responsibility Core The Accessibility Facilitators must research and develop a framework for long-term Accessibility Campaigns.
A.5.5 - Accessibility Campaigns - Early Bird Reward Accessibility Campaigns - Early Bird Reward Core As a part of the brand reveal phase, the Accessibility Facilitators set up an Early Bird Reward System. The Early Bird Reward System rewarded all users signing up before the launch date of USDS and SKY with double the SKY rewards for the first month following launch. The accumulated SKY rewards were paid out as an airdrop as specified in A.5.5 - Accessibility Campaigns - Early Bird Reward - Token Distribution.
A.5.5 - Accessibility Campaigns - Early Bird Reward - Token Distribution Accessibility Campaigns - Early Bird Reward - Token Distribution Core To distribute the Early Bird Reward the following actions have been or will be taken: • 27,222,832.8 newly minted SKY, equal to 120% of the total estimated Early Bird Reward distributions, was transferred to the multisig wallet operated by the Accessibility Facilitators at the address 0x14D98650d46BF7679BBD05D4f615A1547C87Bf68 on the Ethereum Mainnet. • The remaining SKY in the 0x14D98650d46BF7679BBD05D4f615A1547C87Bf68 multisig that is not used to fund the MerkleDistributor will be burned by calling the burn function on the multisig. The estimated amount of SKY needed to fund the MerkleDistributor is 22,685,694.
A.5.8 - A1 - Location Resilience Location Resilience Section This Section defines requirements for Ecosystem Actors and Agents to implement limited filtering and full blocking of IPs.
A.5.8 - Location Resilience - Reduce Exposure To Locations Location Resilience - Reduce Exposure To Locations Core Ecosystem Actors in the Sky Ecosystem must actively explore and implement reasonably available options to reduce their infrastructure's exposure to locations identified in the following subdocuments as subject to either IP filtering ("limited filtering") or IP blocking ("full block").
A.5.8 - Location Resilience - Consequence For Non-Compliance Location Resilience - Consequence For Non-Compliance Core All frontends operated by Ecosystem Actors on behalf of Agents are required to follow the location-filtering rules defined in A.5.8 - A1 - Location Resilience and its subdocuments. The failure to adhere to these rules will result in penalties.
A.5.8 - Location Resilience - Limited Filtering Of Features & IPs Location Resilience - Limited Filtering Of Features & IPs Core Limited filtering requires frontends operated by Ecosystem Actors to avoid displaying or describing features to users with IPs flagged for limited filtering.
A.5.8 - Location Resilience - Limited Filtering Of Features & IPs - Restricted Features Location Resilience - Limited Filtering Of Features & IPs - Restricted Features Core

The features that must be restricted from being displayed or described to users flagged for Limited Filtering are:

  • Staking Rewards
  • Sky Savings Rate
  • Any other feature related to yield or rewards.
A.5.8 - Location Resilience - Limited Filtering Of Features & IPs - Flagged IPs Location Resilience - Limited Filtering Of Features & IPs - Flagged IPs Core Frontends must develop internal processes to determine their strategy for limited filtering, to ensure optimal balance of resilience and accessibility.
A.5.8 - Location Resilience - Full Block Location Resilience - Full Block Core Full block requires frontends operated by Ecosystem Actors to deny service of any kind to users with IPs flagged for Full Block.
A.5.8 - Location Resilience - Full Block - Flagged IPs Location Resilience - Full Block - Flagged IPs Core User IPs flagged for Full Block are:• Cuba• Iran• Syria• North Korea• Crimea and Sevastopol• Donetsk People's Republic• Luhansk People's Republic of Ukraine• Kherson Oblast• Zaporizhzhia Oblast
A.5.9 - A1 - Launch Project Launch Project Section This Section defines high-level objectives and requirements for the Launch Project. The Launch Project budget and the provisions for payout are defined in the subdocuments herein.
A.5.9 - Launch Project - Beta Launch Launch Project - Beta Launch Core The Beta Launch is a crucial milestone in the Launch Project, marking the time at which three key elements will be unveiled: the new brand, USDS and SKY.
A.5.9 - Launch Project - Objectives Launch Project - Objectives Core The subdocuments herein specify the Launch Project's objectives.
A.5.9 - Launch Project - Objectives - Coordinate Development Launch Project - Objectives - Coordinate Development Core The Launch Project must coordinate the development of the new brand with website, marketing and communications strategy. The Launch Project must also effectively integrate the ecosystem's smart contract development into the launch.
A.5.9 - Launch Project - Objectives - Develop Technology Launch Project - Objectives - Develop Technology Core The Launch Project must develop key AI and governance technology, and secure partnerships with high-value companies in relevant fields to rapidly anchor Sky's ability to leverage AI and governance technology.
A.5.9 - Launch Project - Objectives - Attract High-Value Actors Launch Project - Objectives - Attract High-Value Actors Core The Launch Project must work to attract high-value actors who are less traditionally prone to interact with the world of crypto.
A.5.9 - Launch Project - Objectives - Regulatory Outreach Launch Project - Objectives - Regulatory Outreach Core The Launch Project may also deal with various initiatives related to regulatory outreach or legal resilience efforts in the Sky Ecosystem.
A.5.9 - Launch Project - Objectives - Fund Infrastructure Launch Project - Objectives - Fund Infrastructure Core The Launch Project must fund security and other critical infrastructure needs for the Ecosystem as required during the bootstrapping phase.
A.5.9 - Launch Project - Objectives - Purpose System Launch Project - Objectives - Purpose System Core The Launch Project must explore options to help bootstrap the Purpose System and may request governance votes to allocate SKY from the Pause Proxy as grants or donations to relevant causes. Such payments must be approved through a SKY vote. Any approved payments will be funded separately; that is, they will not count against the Launch Project's budget.
A.5.9 - Launch Project - Objectives - Launch Season Work Launch Project - Objectives - Launch Season Work Core The Launch Project must prepare for its dissolution and replacement, following Beta Launch. Once the new brand has been revealed, significant transparency improvements for the Launch Project must also be implemented.
A.5.9 - Launch Project - Long Term Focus Launch Project - Long Term Focus Core The Launch Project's long-term focus must be on coordinating effective marketing and launch processes around the next launch phases; using communications and marketing to prepare the community for the potential of increased governance participation; and driving growth to the Ecosystem, Agents, and Sky Governance.
A.5.9 - Launch Project - Transparency Exception Launch Project - Transparency Exception Core The Launch Project is a one-time exception to the requirements for maximum end-to-end transparency for all governance processes, Facilitator decisions, and budget spending defined by the Atlas. Due to the unique opportunity presented by the new brand and its well-coordinated release alongside the Beta Launch, the Launch Project must optimize for creating the best possible first impression, given its potential to have an outsized impact on the long-term success of the entire Ecosystem.
A.5.9 - Launch Project - Transparency Exception - After Beta Launch Launch Project - Transparency Exception - After Beta Launch Core The Launch Project must follow a higher standard of transparency after the Beta Launch, when the first impression of the new brand and the overall launch process has already been set.
A.5.9 - Launch Project - Include Non-Crypto Key Partners Launch Project - Include Non-Crypto Key Partners Core The Launch Project must engage key non-crypto partners and, during the earliest phases, shield them from the unfamiliar challenges unique to decentralized governance and politics. This approach will enable them to participate successfully in the Beta Launch and gain a clear understanding of the system without unnecessary distractions.
A.5.9 - Launch Project - Budget Launch Project - Budget Core The budget available for the Launch Project is specified in A.5.9 - Launch Project - Budget - Amount. This is a one-time budget with no renewal. Payouts from the budget can be triggered by the Accessibility Facilitator through a message in the Sky Core Forum, specifying the amount for lump-sum payments or the DssVest parameters for DssVest payments, along with the recipient address. The payment is bundled directly into the next Executive Vote without requiring a Governance Poll. Each time a payout is made, the remaining budget in A.5.9 - Launch Project - Budget - Current Remaining Amount must be reduced to reflect the expenditure. Spending cannot exceed the total one-time budget.
A.5.9 - Launch Project - Budget - Amount Launch Project - Budget - Amount Core Initial one-time budget for the Launch Project:• 80,000,000 USDS• 360,000,000 SKY - The SKY can at most be spent at the rate of 48,000,000 SKY per month.
A.5.9 - Launch Project - Budget Remaining Amount Launch Project - Budget Remaining Amount Active Data Controller The remaining budget for the Launch Project is defined as Active Data in A.5.9 - Current Remaining Amount. The Active Data is updated as follows:• The Responsible Party is the Accessibility Facilitators.• The Update Process must follow the protocol for 'Direct Edit'.
A.5.9 - Launch Project - Sky on Solana Short Term Crosschain Strategy Launch Project - Sky on Solana Short Term Crosschain Strategy Core The Accessibility Facilitators must work with Advisors and Ecosystem Actors to research and implement a decentralized crosschain solution using Wormhole that enables the bridging of USDS to Solana.
Once the crosschain solution is implemented, the Accessibility Facilitators must use the USDS integration boost system to encourage integration and adoption of USDS on Solana.
A.5.9 - Launch Project - Sky Ecosystem Liquidity Bootstrapping Launch Project - Sky Ecosystem Liquidity Bootstrapping Core The Accessibility Facilitators must work with advisors and Ecosystem Actors to implement a liquidity bootstrapping program using up to 20 million USDS and 320 million SKY. These assets can be used for liquidity programs, or for liquidity infrastructure integration costs. Anything leftover from usage in liquidity programs must be returned to Sky control at the end of the bootstrapping program.
The funds can be paid into multisig accounts for future use via executive votes at will by the Accessibility Facilitators.
A.6.1 - A1 - List Of Star Agent Artifacts List Of Star Agent Artifacts Section The documents herein each set out the unique Artifact for a particular Star Agent. Star Agent Artifacts contain all rules, processes, parameters, and information relevant to the Star Agent. Star Agent Artifacts are collections of documents that define each Agent's strategic vision and day-to-day operational logic.
A.6.1 - A2 - List Of Executor Agent Artifacts List Of Executor Agent Artifacts Section The documents herein each set out the Artifacts for Executor Agent. Executor Agent Artifacts contain all rules, processes, parameters, and information relevant to the Agent.

Type Specifications

Doc No (or Temp Name) Name Type Type Overview Components Type Category Doc Identifier Rules Additional Logic
A.1.2 - Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Type Specification Type Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Type Specification Type Type Specification The Type Specification Type is used for Type Specification Documents that specify the characteristics of each of the different Document Types. It ensures that all Type Specifications contain all necessary information to make it easy to reason about whether a document follows the requirements for its type. "Type Name": The Type Name Component must contain the name of the Document Type"Type Overview": The Type Overview Component must contain high level information as human-readable text about the type, such as what it is used for and why it is necessary."Type Components": If the Type has Components, they must be specified in this Component as a nested object."Type Category": This Component must specify whether the Type is an Immutable Document, a Primary Document, a Supporting Document, or a Translation Document."Document Identifier Rules": This Component must specify as human-readable text rules related to the Document Identifier for Atlas Documents of this Type, and their locations in the Document Trees."Additional Logic": This Component can contain additional logic that applies to all Documents of the Type. Primary Document Type Specification Documents must follow the Document Identifier rules for Primary Documents. The rules specified in Type Specification Documents must be followed for all Atlas Documents.
A.1.2 - Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Atlas Preamble Type Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Atlas Preamble Type Type Specification The Atlas Preamble Type is used for the Atlas Preamble Document Tree which starts at the 0th position of the first layer of the Atlas. The Atlas Preamble details the Spirit of the Atlas in human-readable language, and specifies important definitions for understanding the Spirit of the Atlas, that must be used as context when interpreting all other parts of the Atlas. "Content": The content Component is very flexible and defines in broad human-readable language the Spirit of the Atlas. Immutable Document Atlas Preamble Documents are located at A.0 or as nested Documents one layer below A.0. Atlas Preamble Documents are immutable, foundational parts of the Atlas and their content must be considered when interpreting all other Atlas Documents.
A.1.2 - Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Scope Type Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Scope Type Type Specification The Scope Type is used for the six nonzero Immutable Documents of the first layer of the Atlas that directly describe focus areas, principles, rules and processes of Sky Governance. Scope Documents define the broad boundaries, requirements and objectives of each of the six Atlas Scopes, so that they together can fully cover all activities that are needed for Sky to function while maintaining its resilient equilibrium. "Content": The content Component is very flexible and defines in broad human-readable language core principles, rules and processes. Immutable Document Scope Documents have the Document Identifiers from A.1 to A.6. Scope Documents are immutable, foundational parts of the Atlas and their content must be considered when interpreting all principles, rules and processes of Atlas Documents nested below them
A.1.2 - Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Article Type Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Article Type Type Specification The Article Type is used for the second layer documents nested below the six Scope documents of the Atlas. They directly describe individual focus areas that together fully cover everything needed for the purpose of the Scope to be fulfilled. "Content": The content Component is very flexible and defines in broad human-readable language core principles, rules and processes of the specific focus area of the Scope that the Article covers, and provides the starting point, requirements, boundaries, and in some cases immutable specifications, needed to develop the Adaptive Documents that are nested at lower layers of the Document Trees to maximally fulfill their practical purpose without violating the Spirit of the Atlas. Immutable Document Article Documents have Document Identifiers one layer below the Scope Documents. Article Documents are immutable, foundational parts of the Atlas and their content must be considered when interpreting all principles, rules and processes of Atlas Documents nested below them.
A.1.2 - Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Section Type Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Section Type Type Specification The Section Type is used for the third layer of Immutable Documents nested under the Articles of each Scope in the Atlas. Section Documents provide additional structure and specification to the principles, rules and processes within the focus area of the Article. The Section Type acts as a foundation and boundary against misalignment of the Adaptive Documents that are nested below it. Generally, Section Documents should be "atomized", or restricted to specifying only a single discrete unit of logic. "Content": The content Component is very flexible and provides in-depth human-readable language to elaborate on the specific principles, rules, and processes that operationalize the Section's parent Article. Immutable Document Section Documents have Document Identifiers one layer below the Article Documents. Section Documents are immutable parts of the Atlas and their content must be considered when interpreting all principles, rules and processes of Adaptive Documents nested below them.
A.1.2 - Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Core Type Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Core Type Type Specification The Core Type is the basic building block of the Primary Documents. Core Documents flexibly specify the core principles, rules and processes required to fulfil the specifications made by the Immutable Documents with a focus on clarity, practicality and applicability. "Content": The content Component is very flexible and defines in human-readable language core principles, rules or processes, or subcomponents thereof. Primary Document Core Documents follow the Document Identifier Rules of Primary Documents. Core Documents have Document Identifiers that are 4 layers or deeper in the Document Tree, and cannot contain 0's [zeros]. Within these constraints, Core Documents can have whatever Document Identifier that is useful for their purpose.
A.1.2 - Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Supporting Root Type Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Supporting Root Type Type Specification The Supporting Root Type is used to mark the beginning of the Supporting Document subtree of an Immutable or Primary Document. All Immutable and Primary Documents must have a Supporting Root. Supporting Document Supporting Root Documents must always be located at the .0 position of its Target Document. The Supporting Root Documents have no function other than structurally acting as a directory for nested Supporting Documents in a standardized format. All Immutable Documents and Primary Documents must have a Supporting Root Document attached.
A.1.2 - Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Original Context Data Type Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Original Context Data Type Type Specification Original Context Data Documents explain the intention and reasoning behind the content of its Target Document, to make interpretation and extrapolation of its contents easier, and provide additional information to other forms of analysis. Original Context Data helps anchor the fundamental purpose and meaning of the target document to its original context, and should help mitigate cultural drift over time. Original Context Data can contain unstructured data used for genesis data integration of early Atlas Documents. Original Context Data Documents can form nested subtrees to organize their data if relevant. "Content": The Content Component should contain all relevant information to understand the intention and reasoning behind the wording and elements of the main Document. Supporting Document Original Context Data Documents must always be located at the .0.1 position of their Target Document, or nested in a subtree of Original Context Data Documents below the .0.1 position. The Original Context Data Document should be in a finished form alongside the creation or modification of its Target Document, as it aims to capture the original context and intention of the contents of the Target Document. However, it can and should be modified if new evidence and data comes to light that helps to better describe the original context and intention of the Target Document, or if new perspectives or new external events makes it possible and useful to modify the Original Context Data Document in a way that doesn't contradict its earlier language.
A.1.2 - Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Element Annotation Directory Type Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Element Annotation Directory Type Type Specification The Element Annotation Directory Type is a directory used to list all of the Element Annotation Documents pertaining to a Target Document. "Directory index": This Component should contain a list of the Element Annotation Documents contained within, with keys being the document identifiers and values being their document names. Supporting Document Element Annotation Directory Documents must always be located at the .0.3 position of their Target Document.
A.1.2 - Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Element Annotation Type Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Element Annotation Type Type Specification Element Annotation Documents provide further specification of the semantic meaning of vague or ambiguous terms in the Target Document. Element Annotation Documents can also briefly define technical jargon that is unique to the Target Document. Element Annotation Documents can be thought of as serving a function similar to that of a footnote: they can provide useful context or commentary. Element Annotations should be as concise as possible. "Element": The Element Component should contain the unique word or phrase from the Target Document that is being annotated."Annotation": The Annotation Component should concisely disambiguate and bound the semantic meaning of problematic terms in the Target Document. Such terms can be vague, ambiguous or technical jargon specific to the Target Document. Supporting Document Element Annotation Documents must always be located as subdocuments to the Element Annotation Directory Document of their Target Document. Element Annotation documents are located at the .0.3.X position, with X being the incremented number. Element Annotation Documents should be updated as necessary to reflect changes in the understanding or interpretation of the Element and/or any related Atlas document, while maintaining consistency with the Target Document. The Element Annotation should not contradict its Target Document or other context data of the Target Document.The "Name" property of each Element Annotation Document instance must follow a standardized template: the annotated Element is listed first, followed by a hyphen, and the phrase "Element Annotation".
A.1.2 - Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Facilitator Action Tenet Directory Type Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Facilitator Action Tenet Directory Type Type Specification The Facilitator Action Tenet Directory Type is a directory Type used to list all of the Facilitator Action Tenet Documents that pertain to a Target Document. Facilitator Action Tenet Documents specify adjudication principles and guidelines that are directly derived from the Target Document. When a controversy concerns the Target Document, the Facilitators must consult and apply the pertinent Action Tenet(s) in their decision-making. "Directory index": This Component should contain a list of the Facilitator Action Tenets contained within, with keys being the document identifiers and values being their document names. Supporting Document Facilitator Action Tenet Directory Documents must always be located at the .0.4 position of their Target Document.
A.1.2 - Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Facilitator Action Tenet Type Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Facilitator Action Tenet Type Type Specification The Facilitator Action Tenet Type is used to provide concrete adjudication principles derived from its Target Document. It distills the governance logic of the Target Document into a concise principle to guide Facilitators in resolving disputes related to the Target Document. The practical application of the Tenet is demonstrated by its "Scenario" Subdocuments. "Content": The Tenet Component specifies the adjudication logic, principle or doctrine that is directly derived from the Target Document. This Component can include policy statements underpinning the adjudication principle. Such policy statements can highlight the values that are served by, or the benefits gained from, adhering to the Tenet. When facing edge cases, these policy statements can help Facilitators to extrapolate from the Tenet's logic to achieve the most suitable outcome. Supporting Document Facilitator Action Tenet Documents must always be located as subdocuments of the Facilitator Action Tenet Directory Document (which latter is located at position .0.4) of their Target Document. Action Tenet documents are located at the .0.4.X position, with X being the incremented number. Facilitator Action Tenet Documents are likely to be necessary supplements for interpreting the Immutable Document types, as these tend to have generalized, broad language. The Core Document type has the function of operationalizing the Immutable Documents, and thus its language will tend to be far more specific and concrete. For that reason, Action Tenet Supporting Documents may not be necessary for a particular Core Document. This is not a hard-coded rule, however. The determination of whether an Action Tenet Document is needed for any given Atlas document should always be tailor-made.Action Tenet Documents should be created and updated as necessary to reflect changes in governance practices, provide clarity on decision-making processes, and enhance understanding of governance principles and rules. The examples should not contradict their Target Document or other Supporting Documents of the Target Document.If the Action Tenet can be anchored to a specific term from the Target Document, that term is listed first; followed by a hyphen; and then, an abstract of the Action Tenet logic, e.g.: "Organizational Drift - ACs' Mandate When Instigating Action Can Be Traced Back to a Discrete Entity". If the Action Tenet cannot be anchored to a specific term from the Target Document, the "Name" property should simply summarize the Action Tenet logic, e.g.: "Evaluating AC breach of role-specific requirement vs. general requirement".
A.1.2 - Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Facilitator Action Precedent Directory Type Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Facilitator Action Precedent Directory Type Type Specification Facilitator Action Precedent Directory Documents list all of the Facilitator Action Precedent Documents that pertain to a Target Document. Facilitator Action Precedent Documents record data about Facilitator Actions, including ongoing actions, that are primarily based on interpretation of content of the Target Document. "Directory index": This Component should contain a list of the Facilitator Action Precedents contained within, with keys being the document identifiers and values being their document names. Supporting Document Facilitator Action Precedent Directory Documents must always be located at the .0.5 position below their Target Document. A Facilitator Action Precedent Directory Document must be updated whenever a new Facilitator Action Precedent Document is added that meaningfully changes what should be contained in the Directory overview Component.
A.1.2 - Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Facilitator Action Precedent Type Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Facilitator Action Precedent Type Type Specification The Facilitator Action Precedent Type is used to record all the relevant data related to a Facilitator Action, to serve as precedent for future Facilitator Actions and decision-making processes. It is also used for ongoing Facilitator Actions, and the creation of a Facilitator Action Precedent is the formal method that Facilitators use to record Atlas Interpretations, take action against misalignment, or explicitly approve ecosystem activity. "Input": The Input Component must contain a description of the situation or context in which the Facilitator Action takes place. This could include any relevant information, such as the state of governance or the specific issue at hand."Output": The Output Component must contain a description of the Facilitator's action and the outcome or decision that resulted from it. This should provide a clear illustration of how the Facilitator responded to the situation."Label": The Label Component indicates whether the Facilitator's action is considered aligned or misaligned according to the principles and rules of governance. This judgment is intended to guide future actions and decisions. If the label is misaligned, it must also specify the penalty that is applied to the Facilitator for misalignment. The Label must always be marked as Aligned when it is created by the Facilitator, and further action by Sky Governance can directly modify this later according to the specifications of the Atlas Documents relevant to appealing Facilitator Actions. Supporting Document Facilitator Action Precedent Documents must always be located as subdocuments of the Facilitator Action Precedent Directory Document of their Target Document. Facilitator Action Precedent Documents should be created and updated as necessary to reflect changes in governance practices, provide clarity on decision-making processes, and enhance understanding of governance principles and rules. The Precedents should not contradict their Target Document or other Supporting Documents of the Target Document.
A.1.2 - Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Active Data Controller Type Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Active Data Controller Type Type Specification Active Data Controller Documents are Primary Documents that can have Active Data Documents attached to them as Supporting Documents; these latter contain variable state that can be directly modified by Facilitators and other processes external to the standard Weekly Governance Cycle or Monthly Governance Cycle (i.e., the Atlas Edit Proposal process). Active Data can be lists of authorized actors, parameters, or externally collected data being prepared for data integration with the Atlas. "Content": The Content Component of Active Data Controller Documents is used to define: 1) the entities who are authorized to modify the child Active Data Documents and 2) the authorized process by which said Active Data Documents are modified. If applicable, the Custom Components format and requirements of the Active Data Documents must be defined as well. Primary Document Active Data Controller Documents follow the Document Identifier Rules of Primary Documents. Active Data Controller Documents have Document Identifiers that are 4 layers or deeper in the Document Tree, and cannot contain 0's [zeros]. Within these constraints, Active Data Controller Documents can have whatever Document Identifier that is useful for their purpose. Active Data Controller Documents must have an Active Data Directory Document located below it at the .0.6 position. The Active Data Controller Document can reference its Active Data subdocuments for its own logic. This allows Active Data Documents to be self-improving and adaptive at high speeds.
A.1.2 - Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Active Data Directory Type Atlas Documents - Structure, Categories, And Types Of Atlas Documents - The Active Data Directory Type Type Specification The Active Data Directory Type is a directory Type used to list all of the Active Data Documents that pertain to an Active Data Controller Document. Active Data Documents contain variable state that can be directly modified by Facilitators and other processes external to the standard Atlas Edit Weekly Cycle or Atlas Edit Monthly Cycle (i.e., the Atlas Edit Proposal process). "Directory overview": This Component should contain a brief explanation of overall patterns and themes of the Active Data Documents contained within. Supporting Document Active Data Directory Documents must always be located at the .0.6 position of their Active Data Controller Document or Budget Controller Document. An Active Data Directory Document should be updated whenever a new Active Data Document is added that meaningfully changes what should be contained in the Directory overview Component.
